TITLE.XREF: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1996 (No. 2)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit all words after "that", substitute:
"the bill be withdrawn from the Notice Paper and not restored until the Government:
(a) gives an unequivocal undertaking not to cap legitimate claims under the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme;
(b) gives an unequivocal undertaking that it will honour its election commitment not to introduce new taxes or extend existing taxes by increasing the Diesel Fuel Excise; and

(c) has properly settled the outstanding issues in its negotiations with the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association, the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies, the Amalgamated Prospectors and Leaseholders Association and the Minerals Council of Australia".

At close of play last night I had almost concluded my remarks on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996. The opposition is moving an amendment to the second reading of this bill. Our amendment has been circulated in the chamber. It is an amendment which puts the onus back on the government to, in our view, honour the undertakings that it foreshadowed with the industry. Our purpose in moving this amendment is to require the government to come clean and say that, as a result of its negotiations with the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association, the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies, the Amalgamated Prospectors and Leaseholders Association and the Minerals Council of Australia, it should now honour its undertaking and declare that it will not put a cap on legitimate claims for diesel fuel rebate.

Those senators who are aware of this issue know that the government entered into negotiations with the industry. The industry sought that there be no cap applied to growth in areas of legitimate entitlement, whereas the government sought to limit the scope of this rebate. The scope of the rebate has been limited, but the cap has not been formally announced by the government. We believe that, in order to honour the understandings reached in those negotiations, the government should now make that declaration.

Our amendment also seeks an unequivocal undertaking that the government honours its election commitment. In the election it said that it would neither introduce new taxes nor extend existing taxes. By narrowing further the scope of the diesel fuel rebate scheme, you in fact extend existing taxes. But the particular point of our amendment is to seek an indication from the government that it will not be increasing the amount of diesel fuel excise, so that it can be consistent with what it told the electors at the last national poll. I therefore commend this amendment to the chamber.

I note as well that Senator Murray, of the Australian Democrats, has moved an amendment to the second reading motion. That amendment is in many respects the antithesis of what we the opposition have proposed. It therefore will not be a surprise to anyone to find that we will not be supporting the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats.

Let me conclude on this bill by saying that diesel fuel taxes were introduced initially in order to cover the cost of road maintenance and building and it was levied initially on major transport users of the roads. It has become of course levied across all industry where the diesel fuel is used. A rebate is provided because to tax inputs on production in agriculture and in mining is to make our producers uncompetitive in the domestic and international markets. An input tax does that. It pushes up the price of the good and reduces the competitiveness of Australian industry.

BREAK.PARA: We think that the diesel fuel rebate should account for a removal of that uncompetitiveness and should be done across the board where it has been introduced. That is to say: where an input tax applies, with certain qualifications the rebate should be operative so that we are not putting a brake on growth, economic development and the possibility of employment. This bill narrows the application of the rebate and is a backdoor way of simply grabbing money from the industry which will in fact put a brake on its development and its ability to create employment, and it is done by narrowing the application of the rebate.

We will be moving several amendments in the committee stage of this legislation in order to direct the bill to its original and proper intent. We will be looking for support for that in the chamber. I hope it is forthcoming so that this industry can have prospects of further growth and prospects of further advantage to the national economy and to employment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose Labor's amendment to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). The amendment effectively gives further assurances to the mining industry about this diesel fuel rebate. Senator Cook has put Labor firmly in the position of being even more in support of this massive handout to the mining industry than the conservatives. This is at a time when, right across the board, social welfare in this country is being cut to ribbons.

SPEECH.PARA: We are seeing massive cuts to education and health. A whole range of job creation schemes has gone west, and in the past there have been cuts to spending on the environment. But sheltered from all that is the mining industry's massive handout on a platter of some $800 million each year for doing nothing. They simply get their taxes handed back to them. If only other citizens could get that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't support those other cuts either.

—I accept that. But it is strangely at odds with the effort being put into protecting the mining industry and all its chief executive officers, including six in BHP alone, who will this year be taking home more than $1 million—one of them more than $3 million—in their wage package deal.

SPEECH.PARA: The government and Labor opposition are saying, `Let's give these people $800 million. Let's give BHP alone a cheque for over $100 million for nothing—just a return on their taxes. Everybody else has to pay those taxes on diesel fuel, but we will give the miners—'

TALK.START.PARA: —But they don't.

—We have two sections here: one is the farming community and the second is the mining community. I am picking out the mining community as being given special treatment. We see that the farming community is in hard times but we cannot say that for the mining industry. I am saying that you will not find too many farmers out there who are taking home $1 million in pay deals, but you will find plenty of mining chief executive officers who are doing just that.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we have the government giving the mining industry $800 million, based on a past Labor Party arrangement. The government says that it cannot make ends meet. It is cutting to ribbons a whole range of things. It has even cut out a $2.9 million book allowance for street kids who try to get back into education. That has been cut out because the government could not find money for it. But it can find $800 million for mining companies to help pad the million‐dollar‐plus salaries going to their chief executive officers. It is absurd. It is obscene. It is the stuff of division in this country as we see it move towards the haves having more and the have‐nots having less.

The Labor Party, through this amendment, is saying, `Let's protect them even further. Let's not put any cap on the current diesel fuel rebate, and let's get an unequivocal undertaking that the government will stick by its election commitment not to introduce new taxes or extend existing taxes by increasing the diesel fuel excise.' That might be consistent for the Labor Party, but to me it sits strangely at odds with the government's ability to cut deep into the social welfare net that we have in this country.

I can understand where the Labor Party is coming from because, when in office, it also pursued an economic rationalist program. It was aimed at giving assistance to resource extraction industries, like the woodchip industry and the mining industry. I think they can look after themselves. They do well enough from effectively being given a natural resource, which belongs to the people of Australia, for their own profitability.

I am not naive enough to believe that people are going to be able to look forward to the future that they aspire to without minerals and without wood products, and so on. But what I object to is the serial reduction in the requirements for those who make such huge profits out of the natural resources of this country to (a) give a fair return to the people who own those resources and (b) abide by reasonable environmental protection in respect of where they can and cannot extract those resources and how they extract those resources when they get to them. Serially, under Labor, and now with a foot on the accelerator under the conservatives, those reasonable requirements of government for a fair return of natural resources to the people and a wise protection of the environment are being dismantled.

We have the situation where the Labor Party is saying, `The Liberals and Nationals aren't doing a good enough job for the mining companies. We want to shelter them in respect of not only the profitability of the mineral extraction business which they are in but also this massive handout from government to these massively rich corporations and their corporate executives.' Not for one minute would I entertain supporting this Labor amendment. The Australian Greens will be opposing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to advise the Senate that the Democrats will not be supporting the Labor amendment.

—I would like to thank all senators for their contributions, except for Senator Brown who of course goes on with his normal bile and vitriol that he has become famous for in this place. There were some fairly sensible contributions and I would like to comment on them.

BREAK.PARA: I will respond to Senator Cook who has taken the lead for the opposition on this matter. I will not go over all the stuff that went through the economics committee. This is not the place to do it. I could not help but note the remarks by the Clerk in regard to committees and their effectiveness. This is a matter that was very well aired in the economics committee and to repeat the whole process in the committee stage of the bill makes a mockery of the committee system and everyone in Senate should take that on board.

Senator Cook made the point throughout that somehow this government had not honoured its agreements. I must respond to this in a few words. When the government came into office it found that—and this is something that the previous government attempted to address but not successfully—the diesel fuel rebate was growing exponentially at a rate that was far greater than the growth of the industry and inflation. As a result of that, meetings were convened with the mining industry and the problem put on the table. It was a different approach to the one taken by the previous government through the then minister, Senator Schacht, who fact attempted to sandbag the industry. The problem was put on the table. The industry took what I believe was a very responsible approach to work with the government to address it.

In the process of addressing that problem, the industry offered up certain proposals that were accepted by the government. This included things like 3½‐tonne vehicles and addressing the Dampier Salt case. I might point out that the problem with the Dampier Salt case was not so much Dampier Salt itself, but the flow‐on effects that could have occurred. Customs estimated that, if these had been pursued legally by other parts of the mining industry where the diesel fuel rebate would have applied but which is not the intent of the act, it may well have cost revenue about $100 million.

Senator Cook mentioned that the government did break an election undertaking. This is not the case. This was done in cooperation with the industry. Senator Murphy in his speech talked about the limestone mines. He indicated that I may well have misled an estimates committee when I pointed out that the removal of the diesel fuel rebate for limestone was in fact done by the previous government. Just to make absolutely sure on that, I did a double check and that is exactly the case. What happened when we came into government was that an amendment was put through to an act which enabled limestone used for agricultural purposes to actually get the diesel fuel rebate. In regard to limestone for cement making, that was removed by the previous government.

As someone suggested—and I think it might have been Senator Cook—there is some court case going on at the moment regarding extraction from minerals. However, that is a separate matter. Limestone is limestone and what it is used for in the mine is calcine and it is then used in the cement industry. The question of the mining of limestone was certainly dealt with by the previous government and not by this government.

In the committee stage I foreshadow that I will move amendments to this bill. I would also remind the Senate that when the bill was first introduced into the House of Representatives the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) foreshadowed that there would be amendments based on further discussions with the industry. At the time the economics committee met those amendments were not available. They were subsequently provided to members of that committee. In bringing forward these amendments, which I will introduce in the committee stage, account has been taken of the issues put to the Senate economics legislation committee in its hearing on the bill.

The government has decided not to proceed with defining `beneficiation' in an exhaustive way. Therefore, whether a process does or does not constitute beneficiation for the purpose of the diesel fuel rebate scheme will continue to be a matter to be decided on a case‐by‐case basis. In this connection the government has decided that the meaning of `beneficiation' should be settled based on technical evidence in the respect of the processes and should not involve market con siderations that might affect a decision as to how far the mineral ore is processed.

Accordingly, the government has decided to insert a clause in the bill to reflect this. The purpose of the amendment is to ensure that only technical considerations and not marketing considerations are taken into account—for example, when tribunals and courts assess whether a particular beneficiation process should be eligible for rebate.

The decision not to include a definition of `beneficiation' means that eligible mining activities, other than those explicitly identified for removal in the joint ministerial statement of 31 October 1996 made by Minister Prosser and myself, together with changes proposed to the legislation to avoid further widening of the scheme beyond its intent, will continue to be eligible. Rebate claims within the eligible category at, for example, Mount Isa will continue. Customs will ensure that only legitimate claims receive rebate and will pursue in courts or tribunals as necessary matters which are clearly outside the scope of the scheme and contrary to the government's intention.

While the definition of beneficiation will not proceed, the government has decided it remains necessary to address the recent AAT and federal court decisions which expanded the coverage of the scheme beyond which it was intended. Three decisions were involved: Dampier Salt, Dyno‐Westfarmers and Temco. These cases were all addressed in the original bill. However, in the light of the decision to not proceed with the definition of beneficiation, it is necessary to include an amendment that is specifically related to manganese—that is, the Temco case.

The decision to address these issues, in particular the common salt and manganese issues, is related to these products only and does not reflect the disposition that the question of beneficiation in relation to other minerals is to be determined broadly. The widening effects of these cases is also addressed in the amendment relating to market considerations mentioned earlier.

Following the decision not to provide a definition for the term beneficiation and the specific amendments to address the Temco case, the amendment to the definition of minerals is not only proceeded with but there is an amendment to clarify the provision covering return journeys from the place of beneficiation to the mining site. This amendment makes it clear that all stages that constitute a return journey, other than a sea leg, provided these are undertaken for the purpose of repeating the transport of minerals or ores for beneficiation, are eligible for rebate. In particular, the word `direct' has been removed from the provision.

The scope of the provision that covers the construction or maintenance of dams or other works to store or contain water is being extended. The amendment specifically provides that such activity is eligible for rebate when the storage facility is to be used to contain water which is obtained in conducting a mining operation—that is, the pumping out of water from a mine where the water contains contaminants as well as the storage water that has been contaminated in the mining operation that precludes its release into the environment. A regulation making power is being inserted to cater for any technological changes that may need to be accommodated under the term beneficiation.

The provision relating to the application of the revised eligibility criteria to fuel purchased prior to the date of commencement of the legislation has been amended. The revised version makes it clear that claims must be received by the Australian Customs Service within three months of the date of commencement of the legislation to be able to receive rebate under the previously existing conditions. Concerns have been expressed to the government that the record keeping provisions of the bill would be construed as prescriptive requiring the keeping of logbooks and operating records. This was never the government's intention.

The amendments to the diesel fuel record keeping obligations in proposed section 24OA(2) of the Customs Act 1901 and proposed section 128A(2) of the Excise Act 1901 clarify the proposed requirements to keep diesel fuel records by removing any suggestion that particular types of records have to be kept. The inclusion in the bill of a reference to logbooks and other operating records to evidence the actual nature of the use of fuel for which rebate has been claimed was intended to be an example of the type of record that might be kept.

If an applicant for diesel fuel rebate has other records which can substantiate the actual nature of the use of the fuel, these records will be sufficient for the purpose of the document retention obligation. The onus is on the user of the fuel to keep such records as are necessary to demonstrate that the actual use of the fuel was an eligible activity.

In concluding the debate on the bill, I would like to bring to the attention of the Senate the fact that the Federal Court has recently confirmed the decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal that vehicles known as mobile manufacturing units were eligible for rebate when they were driven on public roads to mine sites on the basis that the journeys undertaken by them could be characterised as integral to mining for minerals. In this context, the government regards the concept of rebate being paid for any activity that is regarded as integral to, connected with, associated with or related to, as being contrary to the scheme.

Rebates should only be paid for activities which fall squarely within one of the paragraphs of the definition of mining operations. The parliament has already determined the activities that have a sufficient connection with mining. Other than these activities, no other activities can be admitted to the scheme.

The bill contains an amendment to specifically negate the issue of rebate being paid for vehicles travelling on public roads in the mining operations category. This amendment ensures the rebate is not paid on fuels used to propel any vehicle on a public road, even if the journeys undertaken by the vehicle can otherwise be characterised as integral to one of the activities listed in the relevant definition. In so doing, the government is confirming that the diesel fuel rebate scheme is a targeted scheme. It is intended to pay rebate strictly in respect of those activities that form part of the definition of mining operations.

In conclusion, we will not be supporting the opposition's amendment. I would just like to point out that Senator Cook mentioned that the Democrats were going to move a second reading amendment, but I understand that that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The substance of our amendments is to eliminate the diesel rebate from mining, phasing it out over a period of three years. The first year would see the rebate rate per litre cut in half, the next year would see it cut in half again and in the third year it would be set at zero. Amendment 1 changes the commencement to eliminate the phased treatment of the current bill since the elimination of the rebate would require only one commencement.

I noticed the minister's response to Senator Brown was that he thanked all other participants in the second reading debate but distinguished Senator Brown by saying he would not thank him. I think it is very symbolic of the government's response to issues of environment and ecological sustainability—they do not thank anybody for pointing those out to them.

The mining rebate is a subsidy that costs taxpayers nearly a million dollars a year and it is rising each year. It is paid mainly to large transnational corporations that increasingly repatriate profits or invest them overseas. It is a low employment industry where imported workers and management are common. It is an industry which relies heavily on imports of production equipment. Rural communities, aside from mining company towns, generally see little of the money passing through the hands of these companies and their workers.

I remember following through a cost‐benefit analysis of North West Shelf liquefied natural gas and discovering that there was something like an 85 per cent import content for that particular issue. I am not singling out gas but I think there is a very high import component, and cost‐benefit analyses usually pick that out.

We see little of the money that is passing through the hands of these companies or their workers and this industry. There are some exceptions but, generally, they generate few local jobs. Any flow‐on effect is more likely to take place in large cities or overseas, and fly‐in/fly‐out arrangements are becoming more common. That is associated, obviously, with social incohesion as well.

Direct return for taxpayer dollars includes tax, though there are a number of areas other than diesel where mining companies get various deductions for their activities. For example, exploration is deductible under division 10 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, as are a whole raft of things classified as capital expenditure. Now we have seen an extension of what is considered to be rehabilitation.

Aside from tax, the return to the public is in the form of royalties or resource rents. This is essentially the payment to the public for the resource itself. Taxation is payable on any business but, in the case of mining, the actual resource—the ore, the mineral—should not be taken to be free or able to just be picked up. This is an Australian resource: a non‐renewable resource that needs to be managed. The people of Australia should benefit directly through payment from anyone taking this resource for their private profit, particularly where it is for the private profit of people in other nations.

Yet royalties and resource rents in Australia are extremely low. One reason we have so much bauxite mining here is that we undercut the royalties recommended by the International Bauxite Association, of which we are a founding member. The IBA recommendation on bauxite was over $10 per tonne for many years while Australia charged less than $1. The IBA was formed to protect bauxite supplying nations from distorting pricing where the price on bauxite and alumina, generally sold by the miners to its own refineries in another nation, were set at an artificially low rate that seemed to have little bearing on either the cost or value of the final product or the relative cost of transformation of the product.

In short, the profit was being placed on the final product and the intermediate products were being deemed to cost little more than the cost of actual extraction. Prices were, at times, claimed to be so low that companies like Alcoa in Western Australia have gone for years claiming losses and so paying no tax.

I will not repeat any more of the general arguments for eliminating the rebate for mining save to say there are already vast amounts of minerals that have been extracted and processed to varying degrees. What we need now is the will to reduce use, and to develop reuse and recycling technologies. Giving subsidies to mining is not the way to do that. In short, mining is not an area which has provided a high level of return on the subsidies we give. I believe it is time to stop paying people to dig up our resources and send them away. I believe it is also time to abandon the mentality of digging up resources then throwing them away. I commend my amendments to the Senate.

I would also like to add that the Senate on a number of occasions has heard me mention a report that was completed by the department of the environment in relation to environmental economics. They looked at all areas except mining. There was a glib or throwaway line that the reason mining was not included in relation to subsidies—monetary or environmental—that taxpayers end up paying various industries in resource extraction was that so much work had been done already. I do not thoroughly believe that explanation. The reason I do not believe it is it is such a big area; it is such a big industry; and it is such a powerful lobbying industry. It is well overdue that governments bite the proverbial bullet and look at the level of environmental and monetary subsidy that the industry gains.

I have found it difficult to get an answer when I have asked departments in Western Australia about the comparative levels between industries of subsidies paid and even comparative levels between industries of effective tax paid. It is time that we looked at that. If we want to have any idea of what benefits we gain from industry and what the impact is of state and federal money that has been put in, then we really have to have some sort of comparative study of, if you like, bang for your buck. If we are going to be honest, we cannot leave mining out of those comparisons.

So I would very much like to see environmental economics put in in relation to mining. But I would like even a straightforward assessment of how much effective tax is paid, how that compares with other industries and also what kind of total tax take or corporate welfare is paid across the sector from the taxpayers' dollar. That would be important for us when making decisions in the future about where our very hard earned taxpayer revenue goes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition can I say we will not be supporting the amendments moved by the Western Australian Greens. Let me in reply clearly put the position of the Australian Labor Party. Senator Margetts concluded her remarks by saying that she would welcome a cost‐benefit analysis of the effect of subsidies going to and from the mining industry as a basis for rational consideration of this industry, its importance and the taxing base in Australia—or words to that effect. One of the points that I made in my speech on the second reading is that there is no rational examination behind this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) has said, the Senate Economics Committee conducted an inquiry into this legislation. It was, indeed, a fulsome inquiry. It adduced a great deal of important and pertinent evidence. As a consequence of that inquiry I lodged 65, I think, questions to the government. One of them was about what study they had done as to the justification of moving as they have in this legislation—what cost‐benefit study have they done? I also asked what did they know about the effects on employment of increasing taxes on this industry and what did they know about the effects of increasing taxes on the development of this industry. No such study has been done, is the answer.

One of the reasons we take the point of view that we do is that before you move to extend taxes in a wholesale way, in absolute blatant breach of an election undertaking, there ought to be an obligation to see what the effects of that will be. Certainly, there has been a negotiating process—and I know the minister will draw that to my attention; and he rightly would. But it is a negotiating process that has been conducted not against the background of information but against the imperative of horse trading of elements of this package. It is the contention of those of us in the Labor Party that such a study should have been done.

It is not surprising to me that the Greens Western Australia should place—as obviously their mandate requires them to—a great deal of emphasis on the environment, in looking at the environment‐development conundrum. That is their mandate and their obligation. We in the Labor Party have to weigh in the balance the issues of both. The mining industry is a major export industry for Australia. It is a major economic part of the Australian economy and contributes to the national economic health as well as to employment. Certainly, it is an extractive industry, which means it has certain obvious and direct environmental consequences. We support the mining industry based on there being a rational and cohesive and properly enforced set of environmental regulation.

We do not say no to the mining industry; we say yes to the mining industry, within that environmental protective framework, including remediating sites after the completion of mining to bring back the native vegetation and habitat. In that way, we believe, you can strike a balance between the interests of the environment, which is an important imperative in our minds, and the economic value of the mining industry for Australia. I just want to get that on the record now so I do not have to keep coming back to this position later in the debate.

What has been said in support of this amendment is that the diesel fuel rebate is a subsidy for mining. But it is not a subsidy for mining. I draw the attention of the Senate to the evidence given by the industry to the Senate Economics Committee's inquiry on this. The industry volunteered the information—I do not think they were asked a direct question; and this is the relevant part that I call to mind of that evidence—that if the government wanted to extract further taxes it would be better for the government to do it by taxing the profits of the industry rather than by taxing the input costs to the industry. That is a quite sensible point of view because by taxing diesel fuel and pushing the cost of production up, you push the price of the final product up. This is a highly competitive international industry. If our prices are too high, we lose and jobs are lost in Australia; and economic consequences flow.

Sales are on price so, if we are competitive, greater volumes of sales are made, bringing greater returns and greater employment consequences. We can tax the profit from that. That can be the avenue for the public to recoup its interests in these activities. That is what the industry itself said, and I commend to honourable senators those comments in the Senate inquiry in which that was given as evidence.

Diesel fuel is an essential ingredient in the conduct of mining operations in remote mining communities. As I said yesterday, diesel fuel is taxed at 31c a litre in Australia. If you compare the cost in Australia of diesel fuel—as an essential input to production—to the cost of diesel fuel in other mining countries with which we compete, the cost here is by far and away the highest. I mentioned British Columbia, Chile and Indonesia as examples of major competing countries for Australia in the international minerals market. As a consequence of taxing diesel fuel, our diesel fuel cost is far higher than theirs.

By rebating that tax, you bring our industries back into a more competitive framework. You knock off that 31c and reduce the cost per litre to 28c. That compares to 25c per litre in British Columbia and Canada, 24c per litre in Chile and 21c per litre in Indonesia. We are then competing—as near as dammit—on the mythical level playing field in terms of the international market.

BREAK.PARA: What we are talking about here is a principle—that is recognised bipartisanly by governments—that there ought to be a rebate for that reason. The issue we are quibbling about is the extent of it and what areas should qualify for it. For those reasons, I do not support the amendments moved by Senator Margetts, with the greatest of respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to some of the comments from Senator Cook in relation to my amendments. I am afraid Senator Cook was not listening very carefully. I did mention environmental economics, but most of my speech was not about environmental comparisons. It was about the ability to see an industry in terms of its tax take and its benefits. That has not been done. There has not been a cost‐benefit analysis of this proposal by the government, and there has not been a direct comparison—that I know of—across sectors of industries, looking at tax takes, benefits, employment per unit, and so on, not just to give a comparison of the impact of changes in isolation—what does this little change mean in terms of the industry?—but looking at what the benefits of the whole industry are.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things I have been involved with in some communities in Western Australia is looking at entire proposals and saying, `What are all the benefits that this proposal brings? Think of every single benefit you can. Even write down the ones the company said—thousands of jobs, export income and so on. Write them all down. What time schedule is involved—who gets those benefits and over what time? Then look at all the costs to the company, the government and the community. Write them down. When are these paid—over what time schedule?' That is a very instructive exercise. I do not see why communities are the only ones having to do these studies—or, if they are, why we are not seeing them more. This is simply saying that, if we are going to make decisions about where government revenue goes or where it does not get charged, we ought to have some basis for that decision.

In Leonora in Western Australia, for instance, there is a fairly substantial Pancontinental proposal which may be bauxite—I would have to check. It is going over an extension of about 30 kilometres. If, for whatever costs and benefits, the company goes in, mines and leaves, and the community ends up with large pits at various stages over 30 kilometres—with the lens effect which that will have on the water system, the fauna and the flora and with impacts from potentially dangerous chemicals in the system—that is a real cost. It is too expensive for companies to fill in the holes, so they say, `We have given you these new wetlands.' However, that is a real cost which ought to be added into the system. If it is not, we are saying, `The community and the environment have to subsidise this industry', even more than we are subsidising it in this sense. That is what I am saying.

I am not just standing up and saying, `I am opposing mining because of the environmental impact.' What I am saying is, if we are making economic decisions about the level of support for the mining industry, we ought to have some basis for making those decisions. That is: what are the total benefits of this industry and to whom do these benefits go? Let us have a look at what benefits there are and over what time span we get them. What are the costs? If it includes tax, let us look at it honestly. Who gets the tax? What levels are, in effect, being paid by these industries? Let us look at the costs. Who is bearing these costs? If, in some instances, a disproportionate amount of cost is being borne by communities and that is not figured into the equation, why is that not figured into the equation? If the costs include long‐term effects like greenhouse effects, why are these not figured into the equation? Who is going to end up picking up the tab some time later?

These are the questions I am asking, and they are about as rationalist or rational as you can get. Should we not be making decisions about economic support based on accurate, comparative information? Senator Cook says, `No cost benefits were done on this issue.' I would say very little is done in terms of comparative studies across industries. I know that used to be the case in Western Australia; I do not know if it has improved since then.

BREAK.PARA: There are areas of black holes in relation to industry support. Often we are dependent on what companies say will be the benefits of their proposals. The actual books showing the incomings and outgoings are rarely available for public scrutiny. In Western Australia that scrutiny only happens when companies put their hand out for support. A few years ago at least, only about two or three companies per year had their incomings and outgoings scrutinised by the various state bodies to see how much they warranted the support of the taxpayer in Western Australia.

Those are the issues. I have talked about environmental economics because that is where the big gap is. We have done some studies. I believe departments have done some very useful studies which have looked at the levels of environmental subsidies that are going into resource extraction industries. These are real—people are paying them in the long run.

If we have left out mining, why? That is my question. I am trying to put some rationality into this argument because people would always like to paint the Greens as just having an emotional response or just having a response based on the environment only. Unfortunately, Senator Cook left out the fact that a lot of what I was talking about was also about employment. If we are saying that we are supporting this because of employment, how does it compare with other industries, and could we be making decisions which actually increase employment a lot more efficiently than what we are doing in relation to our subsidies of the mining industry? Those are the points that I would make; and I wanted to correct that perception, if there was a perception left at the end of Senator Cook's contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be supporting the Greens' amendments. I want to make a few points; and I do not want to delay the committee too much. I basically agree with most of what Senator Cook said. But let me just make a comment in regard to what Senator Margetts said. There have been studies done—you can localise them if you wish, and I will touch on one in a minute. The mining industry has the greatest investment potential in this country. It is the greatest contributor to export income: 60 per cent of all our merchandise export is in the mining industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Margetts mentioned gas. There is a lot of government revenue coming from gas apart from company profits. There is also the secondary taxation regime. You are probably aware, Senator, that some of the companies are suggesting that, when we go out into deeper waters, we should have another look at the secondary tax regime because we need to be competitive compared with other parts of the world. We believe our regime is competitive with the rest of the world but there are places where we are a little bit less competitive—one is the Gulf of Mexico and another is the North Sea off Britain.

You must also consider the spin‐off downstream effects. One of the things that I think we all want in this country—this is something that I pursued even before I came into this place—is more downstream processing. Because of the gas developments in Western Australia, we are now seeing a growth in the downstream processing of resources in respect of which this country is inherently wealthy. One factor is that we are blessed with lots of gas and another is that the very fortunate state of Western Australia is blessed with lots of iron ore.

The day before yesterday, I participated with the Vice‐Premier of China in the signing of two letters of intent with two companies involved in Western Australia in the direct reduction of iron ore. Whether those projects go ahead will depend on feasibility studies and a range of things like that. But it is in the interests of everyone that those projects involving companies in the resource industry do go ahead. Gas is now stimulating downstream processing, which was not there before, and that brings with it a whole lot of other things that are counted into the equation—the infrastructure development that would not normally occur and employment.

You argue that, from a mining industry point of view, direct employment is not so large. No‐one disagrees with that; it is very much a capital intensive industry. But the multiplier effects of the mining industry are huge. Conservatively, the figure is often given as four to one. So for every person employed directly on a mine, another four people are employed whether in the region, in a regional city or in a capital city—even, I might say Senator, Green activists find themselves employed.

TALK.START.PARA: —No; they do it for free most of the time.
—I have yet to see one, Senator. I have even heard figures in recent times where the multiplier might be well as high as seven to one.
—It's not.
—I beg your pardon?
—Order! Address your comments through the chair, Senator.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, let me go back to the diesel fuel rebate. It is just wrong to use the word `subsidy'. It is not truthful. The mining industry and the farming industry pay excise on diesel. Because they are diesel dependent, because they are our major export earning areas, because we must remain competitive and because they have no other option in the main, they get a diesel fuel rebate for work directly related to the mining and farming industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The mining industry does not get the full rebate of the excise it pays. My recollection is that they get 90 per cent. So even with growth in the industry, there is a contribution to government revenue because they do not get the full rebate by way of excise—they get 90 per cent. The farming industry, on the other hand, does get, I think it is, 100 per cent or close enough to it.

Just briefly, I do not want to continue this debate. This bill was introduced in December last year and we are debating it at this time. It is a budget measure from the 1996 budget and it is about time that we started to get more legislation through this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure what the minister was indicating in his comment that the bill has been around for all this time. Is he saying that we should not be debating it or that we should not be putting these views out in the community? What on earth is he saying—that we should not be debating it; that we should be pushing it through? What a load of nonsense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I will debate it, Mr Temporary Chairman. I would like to point out a couple of things about what the minister said. First of all, the minister referred to the multiplier effect. Whenever you find that an industry is having trouble justifying its claim that it lives, works and profits in the interests of job creation in the country, you will find that they resort to the multiplier number—pick a number out of the air, make it two, five or 10, it does not matter, and claim that that is the basis for the number of jobs that the industry supports.

SPEECH.PARA: Economists have for at least a decade been debunking that multiplier wish list as being insupportable. If you added up all the multipliers for all the industries in Australia, you would probably find that 10 times the number of workers are claimed to be supported by industry in Australia as there are workers in the work force. We have to look at the direct number of people employed. As the minister correctly indicated, the mining industry is, relatively speaking, job poor. Its aim is to downsize, to rationalise and to get rid of as many workers as possible. There is pretty clear incentive to do that because the fewer people you have on the payroll the more profits you make for the shareholders.

The interest of the mining corporations is, sensibly, to maximise the profit being returned to the shareholders. If there is one quicker way to reach that profitability than getting rid of workers it is to reach into the government coffers. That is what this diesel fuel rebate is about. It is about returning taxes that ought to be kept in the government coffers for the benefit of the nation.

Senator Cook said, `Let us not get rid of this scheme. If we have to get a better return for the people from the mineral resources industries, let us tax profit.' I have no doubt that the mining corporations would stand by that philosophy because they are multinational corporations very often and they are big on transfer pricing. They know how to manipulate prices between countries so that they can where necessary minimise the profitability of their operations in one country to avoid taxes.

If you are going to tax profitability you could look at the Savage River iron ore mine in Tasmania, established in 1965. It drove a pipeline through the rainforests of the Tarkine to Port Latter on the north coast, from where the iron ore has been exported to the northern hemisphere and, under the doyen of Labor politics for that decade, Eric Reece, paid no royalties whatever—not a cent. In latter years it paid minimal royalties, not least because the Greens were trying, in the Labor-Green accord period, to get the mining industry to pay a fair dollar for the rich mineral loads it was exploiting in Tasmania. But even then transfer pricing came into it. Whenever the Savage River mines looked like they were going to make a profit because world prices were up, they would send a letter to the owners in Asia saying,`We need to increase the cost of the iron ore we are sending to you for processing.' The price would go up, the profit would drop and profitability would mysteriously not increase according to world prices. The reverse also occurred.

The ability of international corporations to engage in transfer pricing is only one of the factors that allows them to get around paying a fair return to this country for the resources being extracted. These resources belong to the people of this country. I pose the simple query: how come Tasmanians have the lowest income per head of population of any of the Australian states, but the highest—

TALK.START.PARA: —You stop all the projects, that's why.

—Senator Parer drops himself further into the mire. The next part of the question is `with the highest per capita export of minerals, or amongst the highest, in the country?' The reason is that the mining companies manage to manipulate their profitability or to get out of paying a fair return to the Tasmanian exchequer simply through their ability to frighten weak-kneed politicians against increasing the royalties. In Tasmania in most years, through the 1980s at least, the royalties going to the government were less than the cost of running the Department of Mines, the extension service for the mining industry. People were actually paying through their taxes to support an industry which was extracting the people's resources in the poorest state in the country—resources which should have been returned, making it the richest state in the country. However, that is the way things stand.

SPEECH.PARA: Now we have this massive handout to the mining industry, which has phenomenal access to Minister Parer and to Prime Minister Howard, access that is not available to environmentalists, that is not available to Aboriginal lobbyists—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you tell the truth, you clown?

—You can get up and defend that, Senator Parer, but I submit to you that the access is of an entirely different nature. The business lunch system is alive and well and the mining corporations know how to use it. They have full-time, highly paid lobbyists in this place which ordinary community interests have no hope of emulating. So you can slag off at environmentalists, Minister, but in effect you are pointing to the captive situation that too many people in government have when it comes to this industry.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the environmental side of it is concerned, I wonder about the Century Zinc mine, which is on the way to getting the go-ahead—

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman. I want to know what relevance this has to the diesel fuel rebate. I am happy to debate Senator Brown on any of these issues at any time but we are dealing with a bill that has been sitting in this place since last December and he is waffling on, not doing this chamber any favours. I want to know what the relevance of that issue is to this debate.

—I will stop what he claims to be the waffle and ask a direct question. Let us get down to the debate. Could the minister tell the committee what the expected pay-out to the Century Zinc mine operators over the next five years will be through this scheme?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me tell you, Senator, in unequivocal terms what the pay-out of Century Zinc is. Century Zinc will add $600 million a year to our export incomes. Century Zinc is going to employ some thousands of people. Century Zinc has offered $61 million to the Aboriginal communities in the gulf. Century Zinc is going to employ something in the order of 300 Aboriginals in full‐time or contractual work. Century Zinc had the support of 90 per cent of the Waanyi people up in the Gulf. That is what these sorts of projects offer to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: You talk about diesel fuel. The other thing that Century Zinc will do in conjunction with the state and federal governments is give infrastructure to a part of Australia which did not have that infrastructure. You talk about spin-offs and multipliers. How about giving that some consideration.

Certainly where trucks are used, they will use diesel because there is no other way to power a truck, unless you want to do it with a windmill on the top. How about getting common sense into this particular debate. We are talking about a diesel fuel rebate. We are talking about tightening the scheme. We are talking about tightening it in conjunction with the mining industry—in other words, an arrangement with them whereby they recognise that the exponential growth could not continue. This bill tightens the scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister challenged me over waffle. I asked him for a specific figure. Let us get down to it. I did not ask for more waffle from him; I asked for a specific figure. What is the projected figure—the pay-out? How many millions of dollars is one of the world's most lucrative mines at Century Zinc going to be paid out under this scheme in the next five years? You must have the figures for that. It would be quite irresponsible not to.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about a multimillion dollar sum. Does the minister have that figure for the committee or has he come here unprepared to be able to give important figures like that and to properly inform this committee so that we can get on with the real debate?

TALK.START.PARA: —The only answer I will give you, Senator, is that, whatever diesel they use in the project, they will pay 35c a litre excise and they will get about 32c back, for eligible use.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister is totally unable to give an answer to that question. I was moving on to talk about the environmental detriment that that specific project is going to cost this country. It is incalculable. The company even failed to meet the—
—I rise on a point of order, Madam Temporary Chair. What has this got to do with the diesel fuel rebate? It is just a matter of relevance.

—I have been listening to the debate very carefully; and I have only just come into the chair. I would have to ask Senator Brown to ensure that his remarks go to the heart of the bill and the amendments that we are currently debating.

—I think the environmental cost of the industry has to be weighed up against this multimillion dollar handout to the mining corporations. I remind the committee that just last week in this chamber, Senator Hill, by failure to give an assurance to the contrary, indicated that money from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund—that billion dollar fund, much touted for the environment—could go towards cleaning up after miners who do the wrong thing in this country. I am very concerned about that.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an environmental detriment for mining. We ought not have the public paying out to clean up after miners, particularly when the miners are being given an excise rebate that is not available to the public in general. It is at the heart of the matter.

I would like to ask the minister, seeing that he has failed to be able to say how much this mine at Century Zinc—one of the world's most profitable—will be given to add to those profits through the diesel rebate scheme, whether he can give the figures for the McArthur River mine in the Northern Territory. Has he got the figures for the Olympic Dam mine, the uranium and other minerals mine in South Australia, which is just about to siphon vast amounts of water from the central artesian basin, with huge environmental impacts? Can he give us the figures for the mining rebate in toto for the Tasmanian mining corporations?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I explained, either at the end of the second reading debate or in the introduction to the committee stage, that the mining industry gets a rebate based on its use of equipment—mainly equipment—where it is diesel dependent. In the process it adds enormous wealth to this country—not just to the people within the region or the direct employees, but to the country as a whole. It has since the gold rush days, Senator, unless you selectively read your own history.

SPEECH.PARA: We are using this bill to tighten up the eligibility and remove loopholes. I would have thought, Senator, that if you had half a brain, you would recognise and support that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Temporary Chair. I would like that remark removed please.
—The half or none?
—Minister, I understand that people do feel strongly about these issues, but I do not think that personal insults help progress the debate.

—I withdraw. This is a bill which will tighten the eligibility. What we do recognise—this will be the subject of further consultations with the mining industry—is that, hopefully, the industry will grow. With it will come additional benefits to our country.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole aim of the program—and this was the whole basis of the discussion with the industry—was that growth was exponential mainly because of things like AAT and court decisions that were moving eligibility into areas not intended by the legislation. If my memory is correct, currently as it sits in the forward estimates we expect that the diesel fuel rebate payout for the coming year will be in the order of $817 million. I think I am right about that. That figure, because of this bill and because of the agreements reached with the mining industry, is substantially less than what it would have been without the closure of these loopholes. Either you support that or you do not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are having part of this debate today because of the kinds of statements the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) is making. He mentions companies that are diesel dependent. The government has made changes which make rail options more expensive. If anything, the government is creating a greater diesel dependency by companies and then handing them something back for that. If the government had some realistic desire to make companies less diesel dependent, it would take the options available which might benefit the environment, but it has not.

SPEECH.PARA: A gold rush mentality does exist within this government. It existed to a certain extent with the previous government as well but even more so with this one. The gold rush mentality was based on the fact that when people originally populated certain parts of Australia they brought their savings, they worked and there was at that stage a very high multiplier effect which was measurable because there was not anything in those areas before. We are talking about towns being built and areas that changed as a result of mining. Whether that multiplier effect actually benefited the country is another debate altogether. The gold rush mentality is being maintained, but it is a totally different ball game.

The minister mentioned $600 million in export income. The kinds of studies I am talking about question how much of that, say, $600 million, benefits the country that is hosting this event, how much are we being benefited in terms of things like taxation, how much stays in the country, how much is repatriated as profit repatriation and how much do we benefit if there is a very high import content. So throwing around figures like $600 million is almost meaningless. It is not our export income; it is the export income of a particular company.

BREAK.PARA: Unless you are prepared to look further into what those figures mean—that is, to whom, how and over what time export income is distributed—those figures are meaningless. They are the kinds of figures that always make the front page of the business pages but are rarely looked at more closely because of the kind of issue that Senator Brown spoke about—the business lunches, which end up being free promotions in the business pages or the front pages of newspapers and which are often uncritical about the figures behind the figures because those figures are generally not available. The companies are not going to make them available, and governments rarely have access to them.

Instead of throwing statements around like `this will benefit us by $600 million', we need to find out exactly how much will benefit us. We need to look at the cost and the actual incomings and outgoings for whom and over what time. Six hundred million dollars means nothing if very little of that stays to benefit Australia but in particular the local communities who end up with, say, 30 kilometres of great, whacking lens effect pits that they will have to live with for the rest of their lives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is time I entered the debate, if I may. There are, Minister, sound environmental, economic and fiscal reasons for supporting a major reduction in the diesel fuel rebate. The government has chosen only one of those. It has chosen the fiscal reason. The Australian Democrats had recommended as a first step that $400 million worth of reduction should be applied on a graduated basis to the mining industry's diesel fuel rebate.

SPEECH.PARA: Through this bill, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 (No.2), the government has delivered $160 million worth of cuts, which is about 40 per cent of the Democrats' target. The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) has clearly made the point to Senators Brown and Margetts that that cut at least accords with their objectives and for that reason he seeks their support for the bill, if for no other reason. It is for that reason, of course, that the Democrats do support the bill—because we do believe that there are sound reasons for reducing it.

However, Senators Margetts, Cook and Brown have focused much more on the economic and environmental arguments whereas the government's arguments, not particularly well elucidated today but previously elucidated, are primarily fiscal. Although I understand the government's frustration at the delays, it is quite proper for this debate to take place because it is about a fundamental policy issue, a fundamental policy direction and a fundamental disagreement about where economic and taxation policy should go in terms of trying to marry the environmental, economic, fiscal and, I guess we should add, social components that are affected by this very large subsidy.

The Australian Democrats have had three prime motivations—I outlined them fully in my speech in the second reading debate; I will not repeat all of what I said—for our belief that the diesel fuel rebate should be reduced. Firstly, we do believe that the mining industry has the capacity to substantially improve fuel efficiency by reducing its reliance on diesel—a move that would assist in reducing Australia's greenhouse emissions. It is our objective to reduce the use of diesel and to use other renewable or preferable energy sources. That has a sound environmental basis, and that is one the minister and this government well understand.

Secondly, we have accepted the fiscal argument that there are limits to the budget capacity of government and, in a climate of strong budget cuts and competing demands from society for expenditure in other areas that it considers more important, it is appropriate for both the government and the other parties in the parliamentary process to debate where those moneys are spent. Once again, it is for that reason that we support your cuts, because we think that $160 million is better spent elsewhere.

Thirdly, and it really comes to the nub of the economic argument, we believe that the diesel fuel rebate is an inefficient and inappropriate industry and export motivator. All sides recognise that it is a selective motivator. They recognise that it is discriminatory between types of mining and so on. That is a judgment you have to make on budgetary grounds, because if it was open‐ended the cost would be horrendous. We understand your motivation but we do not accept the choices you have made.

That is one of our great difficulties with this. The arguments of Senator Cook could equally apply to all those mining operations—and there are many—that do not benefit from the diesel fuel rebate scheme. It could apply to manufacturing, which does not benefit from the diesel fuel rebate scheme. Manufacturing has the same need to keep down input costs, the same need to keep down its sale price, the same need to have an industry motivator as any other industry. It certainly applies to the rail industry, which both this government and the previous government have operated a prejudicial policy towards, and it does apply to many exporters.

The Australian Democrats have an interventionist view on industry policy. We do have an interventionist view about the use of economic measures to motivate particular industries and particular sectors. We say to you that this particular motivator is an inefficient and inappropriate industry measure. We do consider it, Minister—and you understand our argument, as we understand yours—to be an industry assistance measure because it is discriminatory. If it was an across‐the‐board tax measure it would not be discriminatory. It is that fundamental discrimination which distinguishes it from a tax rebate device and makes it in fact a specific industry support mechanism. If you look behind the arguments of Senator Margetts and Senator Brown, that is also what they are saying, that this is a device which has been used to single out favourably certain industry sectors. The question is: is that appropriate, is that right, is it going into the right hands and is it having the right consequences? I think the questions that have been asked deserve to be answered.

From that remark I have made comes my problem with Senator Margetts's amendment. Senator Margetts seeks to knock out this DFR within two years. Whilst I and my party have very broad and very deep sympathy with that policy intention, this is too far and too fast. It would be very difficult for me, who has stood now in countless estimates hearings and committee hearings and industry hearings where I have consistently argued against government cuts on the basis that they have not been done in terms of the evaluation of their effect on investment, jobs, exports and growth, then to accept an amendment which also comes to us without an equivalent assessment of the effects of a very fast reduction of the DFR on investment, jobs, exports and growth. It is very difficult. I think Senator Margetts asked the right questions, but those studies actually need to be done.

The other side of the coin is this: no‐one on my side of the house is against the mining industry in any sense. We recognise both its benefits and its down sides. But we also recognise that the economic reality and the financial and accounting reality is this. Minister, I think your experience would cause you to agree; I can only outline it in terms of my reading. My reading is that, generally speaking, mining investment projects have a period of between eight and 15 years before you get a return. In other words, it is a long‐term investment of a very high capital nature and there is a significant lag before you get your return. If the diesel fuel rebate is such that it provides an important financial and cash flow mechanism that has been built into the assessments of those who have invested in the industry, it would not behove us as parliamentarians to suddenly say, `Hey, we are going to whip this out from you in two years' if it is built into, say, an eight‐year return mechanism.

That is a second reason that I regard Senator Margetts's amendments, unfortunately, as going too far and too fast. But I would like to put parliament on notice and for you to understand that we will continue to give strong support to reappraisal of the scheme. We believe that, first of all, it should be capped. We do believe that it should be turned away from an excise rebate to an assistance measure. We would prefer that to be dedicated to those mining operations which are more environmentally friendly than others, such as natural gas. We have the opinion that you do need a graduated and phased reduction of this process.

We know you are short of money, because you keep telling us the importance of fiscal responsibility, and we would urge the government to continue the reduction. In the arguments of Senator Margetts and Senator Brown, if you take away some of those things that make you react strongly but if you listen to the questions and the motivation, and if you listen to my own arguments, you will find some good policy reasons for refining and reducing and changing the nature of the scheme. Accordingly, Minister, although I regret that I cannot support Senator Margetts's amendment at this time, I would urge you and your government to respond to the intention and the thoughts that lie behind it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a three‐year phase‐out and not a two‐year phase‐out that we are proposing. I did put this proposal up as a private members bill, so it has been on the table. It is a pity that, with major changes that are occurring with the government, they tend to be concerned more about major changes to industry rather than major changes to the community, which is happening with a lot of their budget cuts, including things like housing.

SPEECH.PARA: However, you can be assured that, if this measure—and I can count—is not getting support in the Senate, I will be coming up again and again with it. So there will hopefully be other opportunities to put this model. I am pleased to hear that the Australian Democrats will support it in the longer run. But I would be very happy to propose a look at the actual impact of taxation and the benefits or otherwise of this proposal in depth at some later date. It is something that is not just specifically to this legislation, but I think it would be a very good thing if there were studies done to actually look at the comparative impacts of tax take on various industries and what the benefits or costs may be of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —There are just the two Greens in here supporting the phase‐out of this huge payout to the mining corporations. Our impulse to do that cannot be isolated to the impact on the mining industry. We are in a period of economic rationalism where government services are being cut across the board; yet the mining industry is not only being sheltered from that but also looking forward to this $800 million rebate becoming a billion dollars by the year 2000.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry the Australian Democrats are not supporting the Greens on this. Let me give you an example as to why I think the hard decision here ought to be taken to ameliorate much harder decisions that the government has made. If we look at tertiary education, we see that the cut there is $650 million to tertiary institutions across this country. The impact on students right across the country, particularly poorer students, is huge. The difficulties for tertiary institutions are enormous.

We in this country ought to be guaranteeing a tertiary education to everybody who aspires to it. Instead of that, it is becoming harder and harder for people to get a tertiary education as a prerequisite for a job. Labor, the Liberals and the Democrats are supporting $800 million going to the mining corporations. We cannot find $650 million for the universities, but we can find $800 million for the mining corporations. That, to me, is a shocking inversion of priorities. It is an indictment of the idea that we should be becoming the clever country. We have become much more interested in the shovel mentality than we have in the brains trust mentality that we should be moving to.

Where are the equivalent subsidies for the sunrise industries in this country? They are just not there, certainly not in this order. At the same time as we are looking at cementing this huge rebate to the mining industry—this gift—the government is cutting out the Energy Research and Development Corporation altogether, the small brains trust there is for alternative energy in a world which is looking to alternative energy options, renewable energy resources, as the huge economic and environmental impact of the global warming phenomenon comes down upon us. We have just seen the figures which show that this last year has been one of the four warmest years for the planet since records began in the 1860s.

It is a total perversion of priorities by the Democrats, the Liberals, the National Party and the Labor Party, which wants to give the miners even more. I feel very strongly about this matter. Clearly we have put our case. I support Senator Margetts's move on this strongly. It would cause some difficulties for the mining industry, but how do we compare that with the difficulties being caused to those people who are interested in this country having a fair, equitable and accessible education system for the brains trust which are central to this country's wellbeing as we move into the next millennium?
