These amendments to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) are a very constructive and positive initiative to establish a sun fund. In short, it means that those people who are currently receiving the diesel fuel rebate for the production of electricity can apply for a capital grant, in lieu of that rebate, to establish sun‐produced energy—that includes wind energy and photovol taic cells—and clean, green energy on their farms or in their businesses.

In effect, what would happen is that the applicant who wants to replace his or her diesel generator, which produces electricity for the home farm, for example, or the machinery shed, would apply to the fund for 10 years worth of diesel fuel rebate to finance the establishment of the new energy alternative—solar panels, solar hot water system, wind energy.

BREAK.PARA: There are terrific advantages to this. It is cost neutral to the government. It is optional to the farmer, or indeed the miner. It has the fantastic potential to stimulate the alternative energy industry in Australia, as the world moves into a huge expansion in this industry with new technology coming in almost month by month and as the world moves away from the age of fossil fuel exploitation to the age of a sun powered future. Australia has the image which will allow its industries not only to tap the domestic market, but feed into the burgeoning market for alternative energy options, particularly those that can be applied locally in the Asia‐Pacific region, as well as around the rest of the world, including Africa.

I have to reiterate that this is an antidote to the unfathomable decision by the government to cut funding for energy efficiency by 50 per cent in the recent budget—that is its own spending on that—as well to reduce all funding for the Energy Research and Development Corporation, which was the only government funded entity in Australia putting money into ensuring that we led the world in this exciting field which has such terrific economic and environmental spin-offs.

As far as this fund is concerned, we are not talking about small pickles. As I said in the second reading debate, we are talking about a potential 600 megawatt replacement of diesel fuel electricity production by sun powered alternatives. Six hundred megawatts is the equivalent of half an average thermal power station in the mainland states or half the total output of Tasmania's 39 Hydro Electric Commission dams. It is the equivalent of more than three Franklin dams.

That is a market that is potentially an enormous stimulus to the alternative energy industries in this country. Here we have a means of win, win, win for Australia. It is clear that this diesel fuel rebate is an established part of political thinking in this country. It is supported by the four bigger parties in this parliament. Here we have an alternative which I think all parties should very seriously consider and give affirmation to as well, because we are looking here at Australia being given a boost at no cost to the government and at an option for those people who are getting the diesel fuel rebate who want to take it.

Finally, in submitting to the committee that we adopt this amendment, I must point to the greenhouse gas and global warming phenomenon itself. This amendment, in the full flowering of its potential, could reduce by one per cent or so the huge contribution to national greenhouse gas production of the electricity industry. In other words, it makes a sizeable contribution towards our national obligation to join the rest of the world in reducing the production of greenhouse gases and therefore the threat of global warming.

Everything is positive about this option. So often the Greens get labelled as being negative, obstructionist and oppositional. Here is a great opportunity for the government in particular to show a positive response to a great idea that is a winner not only for the environment but for farmers, miners and business, particularly small business in this country.

I wholeheartedly recommend this amendment to the committee and I finally want to read out a letter which my office received yesterday from BP Solar. The manager of renewable power systems there, Richard Collins, had this to say about this sun fund:

Thank you for the media release regarding the sun fund. The concept as outlined in the release is certainly worthy of support from BP Solar's point of view. Not only will the funds assist in reducing carbon dioxide emissions, but they will also provide and excellent base business for Australian companies working in the renewable energy sectors with obvious benefits in employment throughout Australia.
These new energy systems have doubled the direct employment potential of the old fossil fuel energy production systems. The letter goes on:

For your interest, the accompanying sheets show our predictions of carbon dioxide savings on the assumption that half the $85 million goes to photovoltaics to displace diesel generation. This assumes increased production of 7.45 megawatts of solar cells.

So there we have very easy support for this motion from a representative of a major corporation who is in the business of energy alternatives. This is a major corporation, by the way, which has international connections and which is part of BP's recognition that the future is not fossil; the future is solar. So I commend this proposal to the committee, to the Senate and to this parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say that the Greens (WA) will support the amendments of Senator Brown and welcome them. I have been calling for a program to address the need for capital inputs into conversion to renewable power sources for years in relation to the diesel rebates, to greenhouse and to energy privatisation and in estimates committees.

SPEECH.PARA: The provision of diesel rebate for electricity generation has always been problematic for the Greens (WA) since we strongly believe that diesel is a poor source of energy for power generation in rural Australia. From our perspective, this includes both those with stand‐alone electricity generating systems and those townships with mini reticulated state power from large diesel generators.

The cost of carting diesel to these remote locations is added to the tragedy of burning petroleum, a non-renewable resource with a high intrinsic value as a high thermal substance liquid at normal temperature and pressure. It has further added to the stupidity or failure to develop the massive resources we in Australia have in terms of renewable energy. At the same time, we are loath to penalise rural people for living in these areas and do not believe they should suffer for the lack of imagination of government or for the lack of resources to overcome the high up‐front capital barriers to renewables.

We have also said that the subsidy of pollution and resource waste through a diesel rebate or through cross‐subsidised state power based on diesel was ludicrous. We would like to remove it, but would not do so without a program for assisting rural people to attain renewable alternatives. People would remember such things as the light fuel oil debates when the Greens were standing up and fighting for rural and remote regional communities in terms of fairness.

The program put forward by Senator Brown is actually quite modest. It does not refer to rural diesel town power except for mining towns. It does not provide money for the full amount of the RAP system. It ties the money available in the total fund to the amount currently given to electricity generation, and it ties what can be obtained to the previous levels of diesel rebate that were obtained.

There are some questions I would like to ask. There has not been mention of other sources of power, such as wave and tidal power. What was the basis of that? I ask that because, as with renewable energy technologies and often with technology generally, the commercial availability may follow as a result of allowing such things under a program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just respond to Senator Margetts. Yes, it is a very modest scheme, but I guess that is a big incentive for government to get behind it. It is not radical by any means. It is based on available technology. It has the simplicity of being cost neutral, and it is optional for those people getting the diesel fuel rebate. So it is a very enticing scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Margetts is right: it does not specifically pick up on options such as wave and tidal power, which are amongst the solar options for the future—and I guess there is a component of lunar energy involved in tidal power. But I would look to this idea being expanded upon in the future and being made available to communities such as non-mining communities, including Aboriginal communities in the bush, and communities in the bush where there are state funded diesel generation schemes at the moment.

It is very important that we look at those, but they will involve actual money coming out of a government allocation of specific money. The beauty of this scheme is that it is not going to involve the government in paying out more money than it pays out in the diesel fuel rebate option. So, yes, it is modest, but that makes it all the more attractive, I would think, to a government which is looking to get behind the energy options of the future.

I would recommend that positive and constructive process to Senator Brown.
—That could be done when we deal with the adoption of the report.

—I would see that proposal as a backup proposal, but I would not like to lose the initiative here. To accommodate Senator Murray and I hope the Labor Party's certain reticence about it and to make the government the proactive agent—because it has the ability to alter this—I seek leave to move an amendment to my first amendment.

BREAK.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: Omit "1 July 1997", substitute "1 January 1998".

The amendment seeks to change the commencement date from 1 July 1997 to 1 January 1998. This would give seven months for this proposal to be considered and, if the government does find fault with it, it can come back to the Senate with an amendment which would deal with that fault. I think that is the positive way of dealing with this and I put that to the committee.

I strongly advocate this course because the government would then be charged with the responsibility of looking at this terrific proposal and coming up with some amendments to it which will ensure that the promise is kept but that any disbenefits, which I am unaware of, are also dealt with. The government has the ability to do that; I do not.

I do not think the committee should lose this initiative. It is too good an initiative to be lost in a maze of attempts by me as a single Australian Green senator in here trying to get through the system and getting this back on board. I know I cannot do it. The government can. Let us put the onus onto the government by having this six‐month delay which Senator Murray has proposed and move on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to that. It seems to me that this thing is upside down. We are being asked to support something with a delayed time frame on it when none of us in this place are too sure about the content.
—I am.

—Well, you are but you made a remark that this would be cost neutral to the government. I pointed out that, from what I know of it, that is not so, that the only way anyone gets the diesel fuel rebate is if they pay fuel excise in the first place. It is just not true that it is revenue neutral. Someone could decide to switch to a hybrid sys tem—and that is the most likely thing because that is already occurring throughout Australia anyway; there is nothing new about that. The claim that it is revenue neutral, as far as I understand it at this stage, is just not true.

BREAK.PARA: I do not know what figure was required as a forward payment for people to move into photovoltaics. I do not know whether, if someone went to a hybrid system, they would also get the diesel fuel rebate or a partial diesel fuel rebate. Either way, it is going to be a cost to revenue. So what you are asking us to support is an amendment that we are not convinced is satisfactory. Also, the amendment places an onus on us to come back in six months time and say, `Listen, this is not right; it would be better if this were done'. In other words, if you were not suggesting some postponement, we would be opposing this amendment, as would the Labor Party and, I suspect, the Democrats.

That does not take away from the fact that we are always interested in any creative ideas that are going to assist on the renewable sustainable energy side. But it is worth pointing out that it seems to be an upside down position to support an amendment about which we are not convinced and simply to postpone the date. As I said, if there was no suggestion about a postponement, we would be opposing the amendment, as I think everyone in the chamber would, except for the Greens.

We are looking at a bill which seeks to tighten up eligibility to the diesel fuel rebate. It seem that, as a concept, it would be much better to go down the route suggested by Senator Campbell. We have Senate committees that look at these things.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal is revenue neutral. It allows for a maximum grant which is 10 times the annual entitlement of the diesel fuel rebate for electricity generation. The minister is saying that the government is not going to get the tax on the diesel for electricity production in the country which is used as a disincentive. I am saying that it is estimated that the cost of this would be $85 million per annum, and that there is a cap on the amount that can go into this scheme. If there were a flood of applicants for this scheme there would be a cap which makes it revenue neutral and when that amount of money has been disbursed then other applicants would have to wait for the next year of the scheme. That is exactly the matter that the government itself can look at and determine over the coming months.

SPEECH.PARA: I again put it to the committee that the scheme is not only workable but is an important boost to energy alternative businesses in Australia in a burgeoning world market. It is going to be a boost to small business in the bush. It gives an option for farmers, in particular, who are strapped for cash at the moment to move into energy renewables, which in the long term are going to be far cheaper. On estimates I have, a farm with a moderate sized home and machinery could be supplied with a two‐kilowatt system, attracting a grant of about $7,500. Over a 10-year period a farmer converting to photovoltaics would be $5,000 better off than staying with diesel. A site that was economic for wind power could be $18,000 better off.

It is such an attractive option. I would like to see, if there is not immediate support for this option now, that we at least put the onus on the government to come back to the Senate and point out where the problems are. I do not think they are there. I have given that assurance to the committee as I see it. I would like to see this supported. I am happy to make that amendment. I put it to the opposition that the onus should now be on the government, if it feels negative about this sun fund, to come back to us and say why, to come back and explain why we should not take this option up rather than to effectively shelve it outside this opportunity here and now to make it work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just clarify the position of the opposition. In principle we support the idea of this amendment. It has been delivered to us at the eleventh hour. We have not had a chance to study the implications. I have spoken on that before and set out the implications that I see that need study. There is no need for me to repeat that, but I mark the spot; they are still our concerns. The question is how to progress this in a useful and mean ingful way. I do not think we can carry it without knowing what the implications are in the hope that those implications might be pointed out at some later date and revisited in order to then correct it. I think that is a bad matter of process. I know that goes against your genuine and sincere wish to progress this in a positive way and not lose the initiative, Senator Brown, but if I can say this from my experience in this chamber: that is a bad way of proceeding and ultimately one that may not work to your advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: We would support this matter going to a Senate committee of inquiry, on the understanding that it would come back here. We would then have a chance to express our views in this chamber and progress it in a positive manner. I would support those processes. I do not think, though, it belongs in this act and for that reason I will not vote for it now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to hear that. It means that the positive thrust of this amendment is lost to the negative response from the government. That is what happens. That is the dynamics of this.
—Don't ambush us on those ideas.

—Senator Cook interjects, but the reality is that day after day we see legislation coming in here from the government which has all sorts of questions over it. Senator Cook has introduced legislation himself which has been questioned in this very committee, in this very chamber, because there were all sorts of hypothetical problems with it. But the vote still pertained; it went through and at some later time if government found there were unforeseen pitfalls with it then the legislation to cover those pitfalls came back here. But it is different, apparently, when the initiative comes from the Greens and is a positive one for business, for the bush and for the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: I hear the words about this being brought in at the eleventh hour. So often that is the case with amendments coming from all sides of this place. It does not mean they get rejected out of hand. I hear the argument that it needs looking into further. For goodness sake, for at least two decades there has been a lively debate in business as well as in the populace at large about our need to move to energy renewables. Here we have an opportunity which is going to be, in effect, shelved to further deliberations and some further hypothetical action which, as I have just said, I cannot undertake. So it is a blighted way of treating a very positive idea.

I could give chapter and verse about the parallels which this initiative has with many initiatives which have romped through this committee. I am very sorry to hear that the opposition is not going to support the amendment I put forward and that the government is effectively going to be able to shelve this for another day.

I contrast that with the fact that the government has a proposal to cut funding for the Energy Research and Development Corporation at the moment. It says something about us in Australia, does it not? It says something about the blinkered thinking in this parliament and in the Senate. On the one hand, we are putting off to some other day and some other committee deliberations, without any specified outcome as a result of those deliberations, a positive idea like this.

TALK.START.PARA: —To get it right, Bob. If you care about it, you care about getting it right.

—Senator Cook is talking about getting it right. On the other hand, we are going to have a proposal in here to do away with funding for the Energy Research and Development Corporation. I guarantee that the government is not going to come in here and give us a full run‐down on the ramifications of that one. I would imagine that it would not be difficult if the Greens and Democrats were here for that to be voted on without further debate. It is a very negative attitude from the big parties towards a very positive energy alternative—a business alternative and environmental alternative—for the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Confronted with a new idea, the reaction is, `Let's put it off' or `Let's think about that; it's dangerous for us to be seen as innovative. It's dangerous for us to be dealing with a matter that the mining companies have not responded to us on.' It is a failure of imagina tion. It is a failure of the ability of the stultified old parties to seize the moment on a very small positive initiative coming from the Greens.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Brown, and as amended by Senator Brown, be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, those against, no.
—Aye.
—I think the noes have it. There being only one call, under standing order 100, Senator Brown, you can have your name recorded as voting for it if you wish.
—Yes.
—by leave—Mr Temporary Chairman, I would wish my vote to be recorded on the voices of the ayes, please.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Your vote for the ayes is so recorded.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendment (Senator Brown's), as amended, negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 7, page 4 (lines 32 and 33), omit subsection (1C), substitute:
(1C) The application must not be made before diesel fuel concerned has been used for a purpose which attracts rebate under subsection (1).
(2) Schedule 1, item 7, page 5 (after line 7), after paragraph (1D)(a), insert:
(aa) certify that the diesel fuel concerned has been used for a purpose which attracts rebate under subsection (1).
(7) Schedule 2, item 7, page 28 (lines 32 and 33), omit subsection (1C), substitute:
(1C) The application must not be made before diesel fuel concerned has been used for a purpose which attracts rebate under subsection (1).
(8) Schedule 2, item 7, page 29 (after line 7), after paragraph (1D)(a), insert:
(aa) certify that the diesel fuel concerned has been used for a purpose which attracts rebate under subsection (1).

Minister, these amendments—I will be brief because either the Senate agrees or it does not—arise from my concern which arose from a question which was put to you in October 1996 at question time. That related to a problem of a major leakage and loss of diesel fuel at a mining site, which was subsequently claimed for the diesel fuel rebate. The minister's answer to the question—it has provoked these amendments—was:

I am advised that it is not possible to determine whether all or part of the diesel lost was, or was not, subject to a rebate claim without an extensive search of both Customs and GEMCO's records, even then, a conclusive outcome may not result.
. . . under the existing legislation, payment of rebate is based on intended use for eligible activities.

I said in the hearings and I have said in my reports and in my various speeches that it struck me as extremely odd that a claim should be made for intended, not actual, use, particularly when it runs to multimillions and may occur at a number of sites and in a number of instances during a normal financial year. This is particularly so since there may be an aspect of double-dipping here, because I understand that when fuel is lost the company concerned may claim against insurance for that. Whilst not dipping against government, they are getting a nice little handout from insurance and a nice little handout from the government as well.

Those amendments that I have put forward, which are put to you together in conjunction, propose simply that the diesel fuel rebate shall only be paid on diesel which is actually used and not just intended for use.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —That is something, as you would have appreciated in October last year, that was of some concern to us too. At that time I think the legislation said `if it was intended to be used'. I do not support your amendment because I think it makes it cumbersome across the board, not just for the mining industry but for the rural industry and the whole lot.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw your attention to our amendment 164(a). From a practical point of view, people buy fuel and it goes into very remote places, they claim the rebate and then they must justify that it was used for eligible purposes. Our amendment 164(a) says that if a person makes an application—I am summarising it—in respect of diesel fuel purchased, whether or not the rebate is paid, and it sells or otherwise disposes of it, uses the fuel—

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm struggling to find that particular amendment.

—It is in the bill. Basically, it says that if anyone makes an application for the diesel fuel rebate and sells or otherwise disposes of it or uses it in a manner other than indicated in the application or it loses the fuel, whether by accident, theft or any other known reason, they must, within 21 days after disposal or 21 days after loss, give particulars in writing of the sale and so on or the loss. Hence they will not attract the diesel fuel rebate. If they have got it, they will have to pay it back.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that covers it without the complications of saying that you do not claim for it until you use it, because there could be people in the farming industry and in the mining industry who might have accumulations of fuel over long periods of time.

The point I make is that the very thing you raised—that question, in fact, was a very good question in October—related to the mine up in the Northern Territory where the fuel was lost over a period of, I think, 10 years. I think you will find that yours makes it a little bit cumbersome but what is in our bill addresses the problem that you are talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will not be supporting these amendments. I understand what Senator Murray is driving at, and I appreciate the zeal with which he drives at it, but I think this does involve some massive consideration of change within the customs department in changing the whole system. I do not think that system genuinely is broke and I do not want to fix it so I am not going to support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is the Australian Democrats' amendments limit claims for the rebate to diesel that has been used as opposed to fuel purchased with the intent to use it for an eligible purpose. We have some reservations about this, given that it includes farmers and residential power users, hospitals, nursing homes, perhaps Silver Chain units and homes for the aged. It could be problematic in relation to subsection 164(3) of the Customs Act, which states that a collector can refuse to consider an application for rebate if the amount is for less than 2,000 litres.

SPEECH.PARA: Farmers and residential power users who buy in bulk and pay full price may not use the diesel for up to a year. It is also not so uncommon to borrow for major capital expenses such as a year's supply of fuel. We need to remember that the cost of transporting a number of drums of fuel or getting a tanker out to a remote site to fill tanks is not inconsiderable. We therefore are asking mainly farmers in remote residences to carry the debt for up to a year until they can apply for the rebate.

Hospitals and other medical establishments may be remote, but even urban institutions buy fuel for their emergency generators, which are necessary to maintain power should grid power fail for any reason. Urban hospitals in particular may not use the fuel for some time since use is mainly dependent on power failures or shortages.

As a result of some of these impacts, I have concerns about supporting the measures in this form. I would like to hear more about what the purpose of the amendments is—and I apologise for having missed some of that. What purpose were you particularly seeking to address? Is it a general notion to avoid someone getting away with something by filling large tanks for the upcoming growing season? Are you worried that the industries may collapse or on‐sell the rebated diesel, and are there any cases or examples of that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts has just come into the chamber. I do not have the numbers on the amendment anyway, so I refer her to my remarks in the Hansard which cover the points she made.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that item 10 of schedule 1 stand as printed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The running sheet has us moving amendments 1 to 3 and 13. The opposition will not be proceeding with amendments 1 to 3, but we wish to pursue amendment 13. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (13) Schedule 1, item 23, page 11 (lines 27 to 31), omit subsection (7B).

I think amendment No. 13 is self-explanatory, but perhaps I can just say that this amendment under the opposition list of amendments is to omit subsection (7B) after subsection 164(7). We wish to omit the provision that says that, if common salt is washed as part of a process of beneficiating that salt, then for the purpose of paragraph (7)(a) beneficiation of the salt ceases when the salt is deposited in a stockpile immediately after the washing process or if there is more than one washing process after the initial process.

The reason why we wish to omit this provision is that this matter was canvassed extensively at the hearing and this is the area where Dampier Salt would be declined rebate. Dampier Salt fought a case which went to the High Court on appeal by the customs officers. The High Court finally declined to deal with it. However, the Federal Court, the last court of appeal, had ruled that Dampier Salt was entitled to claim the rebate. Dampier Salt's entitlement was traded off in high‐level negotiations with the government.

In my home state of Western Australia, Dampier Salt is a substantial company. It is an export company. It engages in what the Federal Court had held to be a mining operation for which it was entitled to a rebate. It seems to me inappropriate and wrong for what the court upheld to be now put aside by this process.

Frankly, I think the situation which CRA, the holding company of Dampier Salt, faced was one in which the government said, `You have got to find these savings and find some trade‐offs or you will risk losing the lot,' and in those circumstances CRA sacrificed the Dampier Salt situation and that company in order to defend their interests in the wider mining area. I just do not think that is an appropriate imposition on Dampier Salt. The cost of Dampier Salt having to pay the full diesel fuel excise would be $800,000 a year. This is a marginal operation, and that will compute into competitiveness and jobs in that region. For those reasons we have so moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Cook that this was pretty well canvassed in the Economics Legislation Committee. But I just say that this was part of the agreement between the industry and the government. The purpose of it was to address the precedent set in the Dampier Salt case. It was the view of Customs that there could be flow‐on effects where people could then apply for diesel fuel rebate where they did not receive it in the past. This would have gone against the intent of the diesel fuel rebate and could well have been a cost to revenue. I think Customs estimated the figure to be in the order of $100 million.

SPEECH.PARA: So, firstly, it was an agreement reached with the industry. Secondly, it was there to do the very thing we had discussions with the industry about, and that was to stop the exponential growth occurring in the diesel fuel rebate in ways for which it was never intended. That was a major concession by the industry to chop off the exponential growth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments from the opposition relate to salt, as does opposition amendment No. 15. Fundamentally, if things are either included or excluded from the rebate on an arbitrary basis, which we argue, salt production is included. But, if we are going to include it, it seems somewhat superfluous and illogical to say that salt production attracts a rebate but then say that taking it through to the final value added phase of beneficiation is not included. Most beneficiation involves a preparation of minerals to a form which is marketable.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no substantial market for dirty salt, as there is little market for low grade ore. There is a substantial value adding in the process of washing salt and a substantial market for clean salt. The government, in an effort to justify cutting out the second washing of salt, has created an amendment that says that no regard is to be had to any market considerations. What does that mean? There is a market for bauxite and a market for alumina. In fact, bauxite is exported from Weipa while WA aluminium ores are almost all exported as alumina. This is a market consideration, since there is clearly a market for both. But the Weipa bauxites run to a tonne of alumina per two tonnes of bauxite and the WA alumina runs to a tonne of alumina to three tonnes of bauxite.

The reason it is processed to alumina is in large part because the ore is of low grade and it is cheaper to remove the two tonnes of red mud from the tonne of alumina before you ship it. In addition, Weipa exports bauxite because there are other refineries for conversion of bauxite to alumina much nearer than for the producers of bauxite in south‐west WA other than the ones they have built for themselves. There is also the ready availability of power and infrastructure for refining which is available in WA and not in Weipa, which is another market consideration.

The conversion or non‐conversion of bauxite to alumina is almost solely a market decision. Is it therefore the case that such a conversion is not a beneficiation? The point is that almost any beneficiation has regard to market considerations. A purer form of a substance is nearly always more valuable but various market considerations—transport distance, labour costs, available infrastructure, tax regimes which differ from nation to nation—are all commercial considerations which affect whether beneficiation is done here or elsewhere.

A purer form of substance may also have other uses. Clean sea salt is different from unwashed salt and has different uses. High purity silica has different properties and can be converted to special ceramic products like bearings and hip joints. High purity silica is not a final product, and I would like to think that the process of producing it is beneficiation. On the lack of logic of the government's approach, I would like to say that the Greens (WA) will be supporting the opposition's amendment in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what needs to be said has been said with respect to this amendment. I will declare my interest as a Western Aus tralian senator; this largely affects Western Australian interests. We have attended to this bill from two points of view: firstly, from the point of view of a general agreement as to the reduction in the diesel fuel rebate; and also with a view to fairness and sensibility, if you like, in terms of how individual industries are dealt with. It does seem strange that the salt industry is allowed it up to a stage and then it is ended at a further stage which is actually part of the original process and which has been agreed at law to be part of the process. For those reasons, therefore, Senator Cook, we support your amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a good look at this. As has been said, it was canvassed at length at the Economics Legislation Committee hearings, so I will not go over those points that have been thoroughly canvassed there. I do make the point that I am grateful to my colleagues on the Economics Committee for the work they put in on these matters. I was not able to attend. Well, I am not a member; I am a participating member. I do appreciate the work of the committees. It makes the task of persons out on their own like me a great deal easier than it would otherwise be. I do not suggest that my road is dreadfully easy but I guess it is far easier than many others.

SPEECH.PARA: Having looked at all of that evidence, I feel disposed to support this. I do, however, hope that my Western Australian colleagues are giving very serious consideration to voting in favour of Senator Cook's amendment, when it comes up, on the definition of materials relating to one of the other issues that was dealt with here, and that is calcinite.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Cook's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, page 8 (after line 9), after item 11, insert:
11A Subsection 164(7) (after subparagraph (f)(ii) of the definition of fishing operations )
Insert "where the vessel used in any such operations is registered in Australia".

This is an amendment to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), and it relates to the operation of fishing vessels. I have put this amendment deliberately, Minister, to flesh out some difficult questions which I think are worthy of debate and greater information. I recognise some of the difficulties that we are faced with with such an amendment, and I look forward to your response accordingly.

I want to talk about the eligibility of overseas owned fishing boats to the diesel fuel rebate scheme. Excise is not payable on fuel or any other item which is exported. Hence a foreign ship or aircraft which takes fuel on board in Australia and continues an international journey is deemed to be exporting fuel, so it is not required to pay excise. Had excise been paid for some reason, the purchaser would be entitled to a rebate on any excise paid.

This is an entirely separate arrangement from that applying under the diesel fuel rebate scheme. The amount refunded under that scheme is slightly different from the amount of excise collected. The excise, as I understand it, is currently 34.697c per litre, while the rebate is 34.582c per litre. Hence there is a slightly different result for those exempt from the excise compared with those eligible for the diesel fuel rebate scheme. In that respect, we must recognise that there is a clear difference in the intention of those two provisions.

Someone eligible for the diesel fuel rebate must first pay the excise and then apply to receive the refund. Ships continuing an international voyage can purchase excise free fuel held in depots in bond at ports.

The diesel fuel rebate is payable in respect of a boat which fishes in Australian waters. To me, that is equivalent to a company working on the land and in Australia. The legislation does not discriminate between Australian and foreign owned fishing boats. So long as the boat carries on a fishing activity, it is eligible to receive the rebate. A boat which carries out fishing in Australian waters would not be treated as exporting the fuel it purchases in Australia.
This matter was brought to my attention by an article written by Nick Cater on Friday, 31 January 1997. The article read:
Japanese fishermen operating in Australian waters are receiving Federal Government subsidies on diesel fuel.
Operators of up to 250 foreign‐registered fishing vessels a year are able to exploit a loophole in the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme giving 25c back on each litre of fuel.
The scheme was originally introduced to provide relief for struggling Australian farmers who use diesel for off‐road vehicles and machinery.
But fishing operators have discovered they too can claim excise rebates on fuel intended for "off road" purposes, regardless of their nationality.
An inquiry by the Australian National Audit Office last year highlighted widespread problems with the scheme including foreign fishing vessels claiming rebates.

Last year, 250 Japanese long‐line vessels were licensed to catch up to 3.2 million kilograms of tuna, marlin, shark and other fish in Australian waters. At least 84 vessels took up the option to operate out of Sydney, Hobart and Fremantle.

About $91 million was paid to fishing vessel operators under the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme last financial year. . . Proposed changes to the scheme introduced to Parliament last month will make it harder for some mining operators to claim rebates. But the changes will not affect fishing boat operators.
Customs Minister Geoff Prosser yesterday confirmed Japanese boats would be paid rebates if they were eligible.
"There is an international agreement that if international fishing vessels stop at an Australian port to refuel, they are not charged excise," his spokesman said.
"Similarly, Australian vessels refuelling overseas are not charged excise."

Our case is simple, Minister. I put to you that what is happening is that we have two identifiably different schemes where one is being confused with the other. We do not have Australian fishing vessels operating in Japanese waters in any numbers—there might be three or four private operators—and going to Japanese ports. We have literally hundreds of foreign vessels operating in our waters. It is exactly the same as a foreign company operating on our land.

All this amendment says is that those vessels who want to get the diesel fuel rebate must be registered in Australia. If they are foreign, they should not get it. It is the same as any foreign mining company registered in Australia: it would get the DFR here but not if it was not operating here under Australian law. That is the purpose of my amendment. I look forward to your response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —An article by Nick Cater, in Canberra, headed `Japanese getting our fuel rebate', quotes the customs office as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: There is an international agreement that if international fishing vessels stop at an Australian port to refuel, they are not charged excise. . .
Can you tell us the name of that international agreement and what our obligations are under it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I will find out the answer to that question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must begin by thanking Senator Patterson for stepping down the list and allowing me to speak first as I have a luncheon engagement. My real purpose in standing today is to thank Senator Ian Macdonald, Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), for his prompt action in response to my request to send additional cat traps to Macquarie Island.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very fortunate in having the opportunity to visit Macquarie Island for a period of five days last year. It was an incredible experience and one that will hold me in good stead in relation to the amount of information I was able to gather from the various scientists working on a wide range of projects.

One issue that was brought up time and time again was the problem of feral animals on the island—not just cats, but also rabbits and rats. Last year they had an extensive cat trapping program, thanks to Robert Gould—also known as `Ferret'—who has just come back on the last voyage, and who has spent a total of 15 months on the island trapping cats. His wage is partly paid for by the tourists who visit Macquarie Island as he also acts as a tourist guide. Last year he trapped more than 260 cats, but was very frustrated because the number of traps on the island did not enable him to adequately trap in all of the grid references he had set up.

As we tramped over the island for those five days one of things we were asked to do was to report back any sightings of cats or scats. I was one of the those who on a number of occasions unfortunately came across traces of cats. They were obviously doing very well. I am very pleased to say that Senator Macdonald okayed the $3,000 needed to get another 40 wire cage traps onto the island. They were purchased from Mascot Wire Works at a cost of some $69 each and were sent down to Tasmania to wait for the island voyage. They sat on the dock ready to go on 1 April; and they arrived at Macquarie Island on 20 April while Voyage 6 was there. It was fortunate that there were helicopters on the vessel, as was the case on my trip, and they were able to be deployed by helicopter.

One of the problems has been actually getting traps around the island. Some of the traps they had been using were very flimsy and I was told by those trapping that unfortunately some of the bigger cats manage to find their way out of them before they are checked. I am assured that the new traps that have been sent down are very strong and, if baited with some of the baits that attract the cats—particularly sardines—good results are hoped for.

As of yesterday, the results are already depressing, but also pleasing. The main trapping season is after the birds go and the birds start leaving during March. Indeed, most of them have gone by the end of this month. The traps are starting to be set up at the end of April. In other words, the traps deployed for this season have only been out a couple of weeks and already 45 cats have been trapped. The cat traps are left out there until about October because, once the birds start returning, there is another food source for the cats and it is very difficult to actually entice them back to the traps.

The Tasmanian government has put in an application to the federal government for a far more detailed program. It involves shooting. If we look at some of the experiences New Zealand has had in ridding its islands of cats—and they have succeeded now on one of them—we find it is extremely expensive to get those last couple of cats. It costs something like $35,000 a cat to get rid of the last few cats once and for all.

The traps are only a temporary measure, but, if they had not been sent, the rate of breeding up again through the winter and then the feeding season over the summer was going to make it extremely difficult to control them. We would need to put in even more resources at the end. I would argue that Senator Macdonald has seen money well spent, because the $3,000 will help to hold the numbers down until the full program, which hopefully the federal government will consider seriously, is put in place so that once and for all we can rid Macquarie Island of feral cats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak about the Conference for Older Australians. This is part of this government's vision for older Australians. By 2020 one in every four Australians will be aged over 65. One only has to use one's imagination to know what that will be like. In fact if I live that long, I will be part of that population. It is an issue which we have to address from all perspectives. In just over 25 years' time the median age—that is, half the population will be below this age and half will be above that age—will have risen to 40 years of age. Half the population will be below 40 and half above.

SPEECH.PARA: The government is conscious of the ageing of the Australian population and of the negative and damaging stereotypes that exist about older people. The conference, which had been set up by the Prime Minister in conjunction with the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan), has two major roles. One role is to coordinate the government's involvement in the International Year of Older Persons to take place in 1999. The United Nations has designated that 1999 will be the International Year of Older Persons. The second role is to devise strategies to promote a positive image of older people. The two main goals are the government's response and promoting a positive image. The conference will also provide advice on matters referred to it by the Minister for Family Services. It has those two main functions and demonstrates this government's commitment to older Australians.

The members of that committee—and we have not met yet, but hopefully we will do so in the next four to six weeks—are Ita Buttrose, Maureen Kingston, Major General Digger James, Sir Raymond Ferrall, Burnum Burnum, Marion Lau, Kay Hocking, Len Dickson and Terry Underwood. These people have been chosen because they represent various states and levels of expertise and interest in this area. They will also assist me as chairman of that conference, as appointed by the Prime Minister, to actually fulfil that role. It will give Australia a real goal or aim to reach a very positive outcome as a result of the International Year of Older People.

The conference will provide a nexus for local, state and Commonwealth government as well as national and community groups to engage in a positive and productive dialogue. It will also seek to challenge negative stereotypes about ageing and promote the interests of older Australians. It will perform an integral role in advising government on strategies for dealing with an ageing population.

We had the International Year of the Family a couple of years ago and, unfortunately, it was not the success that it ought to have been. It stalled for a number of reasons. In fact, I think we were worse off because it was not a successful year.

If you look at the International Year of Disabled Persons, and I think it was in the early 1980s, there was not only an impact in that year to raise the awareness of Australians of the abilities of people with disabilities, to raise the horizons and to raise their expectations of what they were able to do and to demonstrate to us what they could do, but also an impact to make Australians who do not have an obvious disability more aware of the needs of those with disabilities. We still see the effects of that year rippling through in terms of access to telephones, access to parking and access to buildings, and buildings codes have changed.

BREAK.PARA: We hope that the International Year of Older Persons will have the same impact, that it will have an impact in the year 1999 and that it will have a long-term rippling effect into the next century. It needs to do that because the baby boomers will be a very demanding population of older people. We have been very spoilt, are demanding and are well educated. Most of us have had jobs all our lives, but not all, unfortunately. So I have a personal vested interest because I will be in that age group, but also I believe we need to provide a way forward for younger people coming up by actually having policies in place that will deal with an ageing population.

As I was saying, the Year of the Family did not get the accolades that it should have got if it had been run more efficiently and there had been better outcomes. Margo Kingston in the Sydney Morning Herald on 31 December 1994 said:
The International Year of the Family was a damp squib, with PR events and bickering about whether gay families were families and whether single parent families were as ideal as two parent ones.
G. McNamara in the West Australian on 30 December said:
The Year was characterised by lost opportunities.

The Office of the International Year of the Family was tossed back to Family Services from the Prime Minister's department after it had exhausted its usefulness to Mr Keating during the 1993 election campaign. The chairman of the IYF advisory council, Jennifer Rowe, resigned. One might make some comments about that, but I will be generous and not do so. Had there been better leadership in that situation, she may not have resigned.

So it was a mismanaged year and there were wasted opportunities. There was money that could have been spent more appropriately and we should have had better outcomes. That is not going to happen with the International Year of Older Persons but, I have to say, we have got out of the starting blocks a little later than we ought to have. Towards the end of her time in office, Minister Carmen Lawrence was approached about being involved in the International Year of Older Persons and her response was that it was too soon to start planning for IYOP, so we did not start planning.

I have to give credit where credit is due. Di Moran from the public service in Western Australia did not give up. She pressed on and negotiated with people from the other states, at a state level, to actually make a bid for the United Nations International Year of Older Persons conference, and what a great thing that would have been if we had that in Australia. What a great fillip. What a great booster. But, we did not get it, despite their best attempts. Everybody who was involved in that ought to be given great credit. They competed, but one of the reasons we did not get it was there was no Commonwealth involvement. So who got it? Canada, and we missed out on having the United Nations conference here.

So we started slightly shackled because we did not get off to a good start like that. But, fortunately, there are other people in the community—rather than the former Labor government, which seemed to lose its way and the Australian public realised that and voted it out of office—who had vision. For example, Di Moran is now chairing the Healthy Ageing Taskforce, which is a task force that has been set up by the COAG process of all ministers in community services and health, to coordinate the states' activities in the area of seniors and, in particular, the state's responses to the International Year of Older Persons. She has enormous energy and was a great driving force behind that.

The Australian Council on the Ageing also saw the opportunity, and I believe they pleaded for us to be involved when Labor was in power to try to get that conference, but their pleas fell on deaf ears. The Australian Council on the Ageing under Denys Correll has been instrumental in assisting and setting up Coalition 99, which is chaired by Delys Sargeant. It is a community organisation to coordinate the response of the non-government sector in planning for the International Year of Older Persons.

All these people with vision were involved and they were not given the support they really needed from the Commonwealth. That has changed. The Prime Minister (Mr How ard) has responded—as there should have been a response from the Labor government, but there was not—and we are determined. I ask that all members of parliament on all sides of the house, both in the Senate and in the House of Representatives, join with us in making sure that this year not only has an enormous impact for older people but also has a long-term ripple effect into the next century.

The conference will focus on the positive, on issues associated with the positive aspects of healthy ageing. We want to explode the stereotype of ageing and older people as those sucking money out of the public purse. There are some older people who are frail and who definitely need our assistance, but there are many of them out there—and over 75 per cent of them are over 80—who do not live in residential care but are in their communities and are active and contributing to their community. Many of them are giving an enormous amount of their time in voluntary activities that goes unrecognised and unrewarded.

We are going to change that. This particular International Year of Older Persons in 1999 is going to give a new dawn to older people going into the next century. American research shows that problems accepted as normal in 65‐year‐olds in 1982 are being pushed out now and are not appearing in people until they are in their mid and late seventies. So we are seeing an expansion of the abilities of older people as health improves and we need to capitalise on that. We need to make sure that we recognise and cultivate the abilities of older people and make sure those abilities are used in our community.

We want to celebrate seniors in that year and we want to honour older Australians. They are the pioneers on the voyage of life. They are the ones who are going to set the examples for us as we grow older, and there are many of them from whom we can learn a lot about keeping active mentally and about keeping active physically. I ask senators on both sides of the chamber and my colleagues in the House of Representatives to assist by approaching this in a bipartisan way in order to make this a year to remember, to make it a year that will make a difference for older Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I propose to highlight the double disadvantage that women with disabilities suffer. They suffer a disadvantage not only because they are women but also because they have a disability. In fact, if these women were of ethnic or of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander descent, they would suffer a triple disadvantage.

SPEECH.PARA: `Double disadvantage' is not just my phrase. It is a phrase that has been used by many authors when writing about women with disabilities. The 1992 inquiry into equal opportunity and equal status for women in Australia, undertaken by the House of Representatives, produced what has become known as the Lavarch report. It had similar things to say. It stated that women with disabilities experience double disadvantage because of society's expectations of women's abilities as well as attitudes towards people with disabilities. I must add that I am not discussing a minority here. I am talking about a group that makes up nearly 10 per cent of the Australian population, or some 1.6 million people.

There is an advocacy group called Women with Disabilities Australia which is attempting to achieve a level of equity for this section of the Australian population. They have provided me with a great deal of information on the subject. Their membership brochure states that the Australian Bureau of Statistics revealed that women with disabilities are more often institutionalised, are less likely to work for money, earn less, are less likely to own a house and are less likely to receive requested personal care and household assistance than men with the same needs. This is in addition to all the normal discriminations they face because they are women.

`Hundreds of intellectually disabled teenage girls are being illegally sterilised by doctors' was the claim in a page 3 story in Brisbane's Courier‐Mail just last month. The story went on to outline research carried out by a Queensland Family Services Department officer and a Melbourne doctor which re vealed that, of 1,200 sterilisation operations performed in Australia between 1992 and 1995, only 20 had Family Court approval.

The officer conducting the research also added that these figures were probably a gross underestimate, as her research had not included public hospital patients. A 1992 High Court case has effectively made sterilisations with court approval illegal. This means that doctors are committing criminal assault on these girls. They are ignoring the law because of an apparent attitude that it is, after all, only women with disabilities that they are dealing with!

Another very worrying fact to come from ABS data is that women with disabilities are often forced to live in situations which make them vulnerable to violence. Their disabilities make them dependent on others for assistance and mean they are often subjected to various forms of violence, including physical, psychological and sexual. Such violence, which frequently is perpetrated by a carer, often is tolerated because of the high level of dependence. Society seems to ignore the existence of violence by attendant carers or institutional carers against women and many of these women either are in a helpless situation or do not know where to turn for help.

There have been numerous media reports of sexual assaults, rape and abuse of women and girls with disabilities who are in institutions, as well as those who are out in the wider community. This type of abuse only lowers further the self‐esteem and self‐worth of women who already suffer from both of these conditions. In other words, the downward spiral of self‐esteem is constantly being pushed even lower.

Even if these women could contact support services or the authorities, which in many cases would be difficult, they often lack the confidence to speak out and complain. Often these women are so isolated and cocooned that they are completely uninformed about the options they might have to escape from their predicament.

Groups like Women With Disabilities Australia believe that there needs to be more research on violence against women with disabilities. The fact that there is very little literature on the subject at all only helps to emphasise the ignorance that there is on this issue in the community at large. The other thing that is needed is a campaign to boost the image of women with disabilities. The emphasis should be on what these people do and can do, rather than what they cannot do.

`Invisible' would be a good word to describe women with a disability. Even groups who are fighting for recognition and equality for women seem to ignore the plight of women with disabilities, as do many disability groups. What hope, then, do these women have when it comes to having their needs met? I would say that they would have very little hope at all.

It is time that politicians, government departments and the general public started to recognise that there are many women with disabilities out in the community. It is also time that they started to learn how these women can contribute to the community. There needs to be a great deal more writing and research on the experiences of women with disabilities and women from non‐English speaking backgrounds, and it is essential that women of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander descent are included in those studies.

As I mentioned earlier, boosting the positive images of women with disabilities is a must. We need to find out what services are required by these women. What sort of support do they need? In terms of providing the best chances for these women in the future, we need to ensure that young girls are given every chance of a good education and are provided with support and positive encouragement to give them the best possible chance for their future.

The results of any research, combined with the expertise of women's organisations and disability groups, should be used to develop the empowerment of women with disabilities. Funding should be made available to appropriate groups to provide support to these women. Legislative changes may also need to be made, to allow for the improved status of women with disabilities and to allow them equitable access.
I could go on giving my views and the views of organisations here, but what about the women themselves? How do they feel, what do they need and how do they see their future?

In 1996 a project was undertaken in Victoria with a small grant of $12,000 from the Victorian Health Promotion Foundation. Wide consultation and the opportunity for women with disabilities to participate was a key principle of the project. Women with physical disabilities were contacted and invited to participate in regional workshops and free phone‐ins and to complete a questionnaire.

While this project is a wonderful start, one of its shortfalls was that it exclusively involved women who were members of network groups and regional service users. The hidden or invisible section of this community who would obviously require the most support was not involved. This effectively leaves a big gap in the information that this project obtained. Nevertheless, the information and data put together is still very revealing.

The wellbeing of these women is obviously low. The sorts of comments which were made included, `My wellbeing is affected by the degree of positive human relationships' and `Loneliness makes me unhappy.' The factors most often mentioned as influencing their wellbeing were loneliness and depression. This was closely followed by income and employment related issues and more than half the women said that the cost of aids and equipment or the lack of required services also affected their sense of wellbeing.

The comments made by these women about health services was also very revealing. They did not always reflect well on medical and health services staff. There were comments such as, `Once I was diagnosed with acquired brain injury, I was automatically treated as a second‐class citizen,' and `Need more support from GPs after disfiguring surgery or trauma, not just Valium.' Maybe it is best summed up by the statement of one woman who simply said, `I just do as I am told.'

In summarising the project report, loneliness, income and employment as well as cost of aids or lack of services were reported as frequently influencing wellbeing in women with disabilities. The enormous diversity of the types of disabilities was also highlighted. They ranged from cerebral palsy, spinal injury, multiple sclerosis and post‐polio syndrome to sensory and auto‐inflammatory conditions.

We should not assume that most of these women have suffered with their disabilities all of their lives. In fact, the opposite is true. Most of the women were disabled as adults. Therefore, they have obviously experienced the changing attitudes of other people towards them and they are quite capable of making comparisons of services, feelings of wellbeing and self‐worth and comparisons of a whole range of issues.

Fatigue was something experienced by most and was seen to interfere with women's interests or ability to participate in many ordinary activities or roles. Most women were worried about deterioration of their health and feared loss of independence and hospitalisation or institutionalisation. Fear and worry seemed to be feelings shared by many. It is up to the community and governments to address these fears and worries and allow these women to develop a positive self‐concept. It is up to the community and governments to ensure that women with disabilities do not remain forgotten and invisible. This is an issue that cannot be tolerated and cannot be forgotten.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —The topic that I wish to canvass in today's matter of public interest debate is the Model Criminal Code—in particular, the discussion paper on Model Criminal Code, chapter 5, relating to sexual offences against the person. There has developed within the community, in relation to this discussion paper, an unhelpful accusatorial style by the protagonists. There is no doubt that the individuals who worked on the Model Criminal Code and, in particular, chapter 5, gave of their best and tried to present what they considered to be an appropriate document for public discussion.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be remembered that this is a document for public discussion. It is a document developed for government, not by the government. Indeed, immediately inside the cover we are told:

BREAK.PARA: This is a discussion draft. It contains the views of the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee. It does not represent the views of the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General.
With the benefit of hindsight, it may well have been preferable for the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General to have at least given some preliminarly vetting to the document.

I accept that many in the public arena do not necessarily understand the legal niceties of the division between the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee of the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General and the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General itself, and I do not blame any government for the release of the document in its present form. With the benefit of hindsight, it may have been better for the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General to have given the document some degree of preliminary vetting.

The topic of sexual offences and changes to the law in this area usually attract a degree of community interest. The Model Criminal Code is no exception. Some of the recommendations of the committee are to be applauded, and this needs to be registered. It is easy to criticise—for some reason, harder to be gracious. The committee must have spent many hours working in this difficult area.

The Model Criminal Code, like any criminal code, must be built on a foundation or moral construct. It must determine which behaviours to criminalise and which not to criminalise. Fundamental moral judgments are required. As the discussion paper notes, at page 5:

What can realistically be achieved by the law has, from time to time, been questioned. However, this should not diminish the importance of what the law ought to strive to achieve. By outlining proscribed conduct the law can serve a vital educative and symbolic function in its condemnation of unacceptable behaviour. In this way, the criminal law can work to set a powerful benchmark for community standards.
This comment in the discussion paper is welcome but with respect to some of the recommendations I believe it has been ignored. For example, the document tells us, at page 10:
The Committee's view is that the Model Criminal Code should not have specific offences relating to homosexual conduct, either in private or in public.

This is an interesting proposed development of the law which came into force with the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Act 1994. Only 2½ years ago we were told that it was only homosexual practices in private that were to be decriminalised. Now we are being told that public activity will be okay as well. Those promoting the changes in 1994 stressed the importance of the limitation to private conduct. That is clearly a matter that will entertain further public discussion.
A matter which has received a lot of commentary relates to the proposals on age of consent. At page 99 of the commentary on the code, the committee says the following about the age of consent:

As indicated above, unless a defence operates to make consent an issue, consent is irrelevant to sexual offences against children. The age, therefore, at which a young person should be considered to have the capacity to consent to sexual relations is difficult and typically controversial. It effectively amounts to a determination about when young people should be allowed to exercise autonomy and freedom of choice in sexual relationships.

It is interesting to note that the committee was dead right when it said that this area would lead to controversy. The opening paragraph to this controversial area has undoubtedly allowed some to unwittingly misinterpret the Model Criminal Code.
Having said that, I do have a problem with the recommendation at page 105:
The Committee recommends that the age at which a child is deemed by law not to have the capacity to consent to sexual activity be set at 10 years.

I believe that there are many public policy reasons to substantially increase the age. I believe that, if the committee took to heart its own comments as to the law being a powerful benchmark for community standards, then the age of consent should be increased from that which is proposed. At age 10 we are talking about children in grade 4. To consider they might have the capacity to understand the sexual act is to require too much of them.

Let us not forget that the sexual act is not only a physical act. Emotions tend to run very high as well. A child should be protected from such activity. We are told by the committee that determining the age at which the children have the capacity to consent amounts effectively to a determination about when young people should be allowed to exercise autonomy and freedom of choice in sexual relationships.

Sexual relationships for children should not be seen in the context of simply going for a run or some other physical activity divorced from emotion. It does have consequences, usually emotional, including the risk of pregnancy and the consequences that flow from that. Whilst not all young people would be charged, the educative value of a higher age of consent should not be discounted. In layman's terms, could I suggest: let the kids at least get through primary school! At this juncture it is to be noted—and I want to stress this—that the age of consent which is spoken of relates to the children as between themselves between the ages of 10 to 16 years. The committee, in discussing the age of consent for homosexual activity, at page 101, makes the following observation:

It is apparent that the age of consent for homosexual activity is usually older than for heterosexual activity. This age differential stems, undoubtedly, from the legal discrimination historically shown against consensual homosexual conduct. For example, that young males needed to be protected from older `predatory' males or deterred from adopting homosexuality as their sexual preference.
Further on page 101, and over on page 102, we are told:

The Committee also takes the view that the age of consent should be the same regardless of whether the activity is heterosexual or homosexual. The inference that might be drawn from an older age of consent for homosexual conduct is that homosexuality is an undesirable activity from which males should be both protected, and deterred, until adulthood. It is questionable whether this is an appropriate aim of the criminal law.

I believe that homosexuality is an undesirable activity. It is, I submit, an appropriate aim of the criminal law to encourage young persons not to engage in such activity especially in that phase of their life where young people are developing.

I do not know how many people believe that it is a desirable outcome for young people to engage in homosexual activities. I note with interest that the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Act relates to privacy issues only for people over the age of 18 years. This would be an appropriate standard. To have an age of consent of 16 years, especially for young men, I believe, leaves them too vulnerable to predatory males. It is for this reason that the policy position of the Model Criminal Code in dealing with heterosexual and homosexual activities is misplaced. The quality of the two acts, I submit, are substantially different.

The recommendations with which I have most concerns are those relating to incest. At page 135 of the discussion paper, we are advised of some of the arguments for a specific crime of incest. The paper reads as follows:

One of these was eugenics. Eugenics is the `science' of encouraging the procreation of biologically and socially desirable populations and discouraging the procreation of inferior populations. A specific incest offence was effectively a way of guarding against inbreeding. Concern touched also upon genetics. Sexual contact between family members is said to increase the risk of a genetic defect in any child conceived. An incest offence is necessary to protect against such a risk.

The prohibition against sexual contact between family members is also heavily steeped in Judeo‐Christian tradition. In providing a specific offence of incest, the criminal law upholds the view that sexual contact within the family, whether between consenting adults or involving a non‐consenting child, is morally wrong and an offence against religion.

I am not sure that the committee is necessarily correct in saying that it is steeped only in Judaeo‐Christian principles. I think many of the other major religions of the world also have a similar taboo in relation to that sort of activity. Then, at page 137, we are told:
Given its unjustifiable historical origins, it is questionable whether the incest offence is necessary or desirable.
Further, we are told:

It is not the place of the criminal law to penalise citizens for moral or intellectual deficiencies. The criminal law should only punish acts contrary to sexual morality if they are harmful to society, for instance, where the victim is a child or not consenting.

May I respectfully suggest that incest is harmful to society—especially to the family unit, which I think is still viewed as the fundamental unit within our society. If it is harmful to families, it follows that it is harmful to society. Incest is a breach of the rules governing the relationship of the family unit. The family context is so fundamental that it must be seen as separate and different from other relationships in which abuse of power occurs. At page 137 of the discussion paper we are told:
Abolishing the crime of incest would, rather than leaving a child unprotected, emphasise what is actually being done to him or her. It would also do away with the stigma attached to the offence.
I believe that attracting stigma to the crime of incest is an appropriate outcome, especially for the perpetrators.

I have set out some of my concerns in relation to the discussion paper. I note that many other people have noted concerns as well. It is vital, however, that any criticism be fair and informed. I think there has been unnecessary community concern about some aspects of the proposals—yet very justifiable in other areas. It is for that reason that I suggest to my fellow Australians that they take advantage of the opportunity of writing to the committee, which the committee specifically invites at page iii of the discussion paper. I will read the last part of the section entitled `Preface':
The Committee not only welcomes submissions on any aspect of the proposed provisions, it actively solicits comments and criticisms.
So they are open to being criticised as well, and I think that is very good and healthy for the public discussion which will undoubtedly ensue. They go on to say:
Submissions should be sent to:
The MCCOC Secretariat
Criminal Law Division
Attorney‐General's Department
Robert Garran Offices
National Circuit
Barton ACT 2600
Submissions may also be made over the telephone, by calling the secretariat on (06) 250 5867.
I respectfully suggest to those who are desirous of change to the discussion paper that they will be more likely to achieve their goals by sound and reasoned arguments.

For my part, I want to thank the committee for its work to date. I wish it well in its further deliberations, and trust that our Attorneys‐General will undoubtedly deal with the code very carefully and decide what type of community we as Australians want. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to look further at the Kurwongbah by‐election, which took place in Queensland on the weekend. Whilst in the adjournment debate the other evening I referred specifically to the success of the candidate Linda Lavarch, today I want to take a slightly different tack to address a very important lesson coming out of that by‐election.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe, as was touted in the press following that by‐election, that what we saw emerge was the Hanson factor. If one looks at the Australian Financial Review, one will see an article that fairly well sums up what emerged in that particular by‐election. I will quote from an article on page 4 of Monday's Financial Review, which is headlined `One Nation poll ploy causes stir'. The opening paragraph says:

Senior Coalition figures are concerned about the level of voter support shown for an independent conservative candidate who used the slogan `One Nation Our Nation' on her how‐to‐vote cards in a Queensland by‐election at the weekend.
Further down it identifies that person as Mrs Moran who had—
