. . . unsuccessfully stood for pre‐selection as a Liberal in Kurwongbah.
The article then goes on to identify the concerns of the broad political spectrum. It states:
Senior Nationals are more concerned, with one conceding last night that the poll result "sends a message which is not particularly encouraging for either side of mainstream politics".

In the next paragraph there is a comment from the State Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, Mike Kaiser, who warned that although Mrs Moran was not formally a candidate for One Nation, the result was:
. . . a very rough simulation of what a Pauline Hanson candidate might do to the Liberals.

Immediately following on from that, concern was expressed by the major political parties about the result of that by‐election last Saturday. In the Courier‐Mail on Monday, under the headline `Blitz signals poll warning', John Lehmann commented:
While Ms Moran is not a member of Ms Hanson's One Nation Party, she ran a campaign featuring Hanson‐like rhetoric, setting herself up as a person fed up with party politics.
Her campaign literature distributed at polling booths on Saturday even went as far as using the slogan "One Nation—Our Nation".

Generally, if it walks like a duck, waddles like a duck and quacks like a duck, one would normally expect it to be a duck. But on this occasion that is not the case. We had all the trappings of a Hanson‐generated environment in that by‐election and that was readily picked up by the media and by the representatives of the various political parties.

This phenomenon that has blitzed us in the last 12 months or so could have been stopped, and that was brought home very clearly on Channel Nine's Sunday program. Part of that is reported, again in the Financial Review, of Monday, 26 May. I quote selectively from an article by Lenore Taylor. The first paragraph says:

Ms Pauline Hanson was a "disaster" for Australia which could have been completely avoided by an early and decisive response by the Prime Minister, Mr John Howard, the former Liberal leader, Dr John Hewson, said yesterday.

How ironic that Dr Hewson had to come out and make that very true statement which, I believe, could have avoided this emerging phenomenon that we now see entering into the byplay of by‐elections and ultimately into elections in this nation.
The article went on to say:
Dr Hewson said Ms Hanson's effect on Australian politics had been "the biggest disappointment" in his 20‐year involvement and could have been "killed" by Mr Howard.
"One sentence on day one would have killed it," Dr Hewson said on Channel Nine's Sunday program. "I don't think you ever would have heard of Pauline Hanson again."
I think that is very true. If leadership had been shown at the outset, we would not have seen the epitaphs to the Kurwongbah by‐election on Monday of this week.
Dr Hewson also went on to point out the effect that the Hanson agenda is having on our relations with Asia. The article reports:
Dr Hewson, who travels to Asia at least once a month in his business career, said Ms Hanson was raised in meetings `without exception'.

He said the Hanson debate was `doing a lot of damage in Asia and I think the reason is that they've always been suspicious about Australia . . . we've been moral schoolteachers to the region . . . without recognising that we, in fact, live in glasshouses ourselves'.

I do not think anyone could say it any better. The Hewson contribution to this debate quite clearly states that we are in the middle of a disaster. It could have been killed, and one sentence would have done it. What we have finally come to, of course, is that people of good character, goodwill and good intent are now fighting back, and this is a very pleasant thing to see indeed. They are fighting back for equality; racial tolerance; harmony; a multicultural society—which we undoubtedly are; mutual respect; and good old‐fashioned `love thy neighbour', because that is the ingredient that seems to be missing in our society today. There seems to be no respect by some people for the ethnic background of people in this country.

Of course, the fight back ultimately culminated after the weekend by‐election on Sunday with a major rally in Ipswich, in the heart of the Oxley electorate. That particular rally was well attended. There were some 3,500 in attendance and, of course, there were people from all walks of life, from all backgrounds and with varying degrees of interest in politics. But they all had one thing in common: they came to fight back against the Hanson agenda.

The Courier‐Mail of Monday carried an article by Mike Fishpool. Its headline alone says `Love and harmony wins over racism'. It is interesting to read some snippets from the article, in which he gives some of the flavour and feeling of what took place at that particular rally last Sunday. The opening paragraph reads:

BREAK.PARA: Jim and Thelma McCaskie are not the demonstrating kind, but they were determined to be at the community rally against racism at Ipswich yesterday.
Further on, the article says:
The Chinese community was prominent with a large banner reading, `We love Australia—equality, tolerance, mutual respect and harmony'.
Mike Fishpool also reported:
There were only a handful of dissenters, who could not dent the buoyant spirits of the event.

The rally was also addressed by former Liberal senator Neville Bonner and it is reported that he said he hoped all parties would direct their preferences away from the member for Oxley at the next election. She is the person who has caused this fight back by ordinary, average, everyday Australians.
The reporting on this particular event last Sunday was well and truly summed up by an address from Jewish community leader, Laurie Rosenblum. The Courier‐Mail report reads:
Jewish community leader and war veteran Laurie Rosenblum said Ms Hanson's `evil agenda' had been exposed in her book, Pauline Hanson, the Truth .
Mr Rosenblum said Australia had been enriched by multiculturalism.
`What is the point of an art gallery with only one painting? Or a music store with only one song? But this is Pauline Hanson's ideal,' he said.

So we have the situation that average Australians are prepared to stand up and to fight the intolerance of those who follow the Pauline Hanson line. I must commend those people. Whilst I was unable to get to that rally, I must commend those people who had the courage to attend it and to show that Australians do have a conscience, do have a social conscience and are prepared to stand up against the injustices that are currently being bandied around in our media.

Unfortunately, though, all of this could have been killed off had the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) taken effective action when it first raised its ugly head. The responsibility, I believe, continues to lie with the Prime Minister, along with every other citizen, to bury the Hanson debate, to bury the Hanson agenda and to bring back equality, racial tolerance, harmony, mutual respect and the good old‐fashioned `love thy neighbour'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of weeks ago I had occasion to go to Carnarvon and I spent some time with the Gascoyne Development Commission. I was very impressed with the information I was given by the commission about the potential of the Gascoyne region in Western Australia, so I thought I would take this opportunity to say something in the Senate about the Gascoyne and put the potential of the region on record in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the Gascoyne region is about 1,000 kilometres north of Perth on the mid‐west coast of Western Australia and is an area that offers tremendous economic and regional development opportunities. It is a region whose economic activity is now worth about $332 million a year and its close proximity to Asia means that the Gascoyne has the potential to become a major supplier of food exports to our Asian neighbours.

For example, aquaculture is an industry that has the potential to grow substantially and to generate many local jobs and exports to the Asian region. Yet except for cultured pearls, aquaculture is a relatively new operation in the Gascoyne area. Currently, the region has two pearl hatcheries that are operating successfully. While in Carnarvon I saw first‐hand how pearls are cultivated and cod are bred in a farm‐like setting. In my opinion there is great room for growth and expansion in this area of industry.

In addition, aquaculture producers can quite easily capture the Asian and European markets by servicing these areas with delicious seafood grown in the region's unpolluted waters. The potential for the Gascoyne region to generate a lucrative aquaculture market, both nationally and internationally, is unparalleled in Australia.

Another industry that has provided a firm and diverse base for the Gascoyne region and generates large capital is tourism. Tourism is one of the largest contributors to the regional economy and brings some $70 million a year to the general area. It is estimated that in the 1993‐94 year, which is the last year for which figures are available, some 303,000 people visited the Gascoyne region. That figure would have gone up substantially in the last four years.

Tourists are enticed to the area primarily because of its pleasant weather, its fishing, boating and natural attractions, such as the Ningaloo Reef and the gorges and beaches of the Exmouth area. I think Exmouth has more tourist potential than Broome and I predict that, in due course, Exmouth may well outstrip Broome as a holiday resort because Exmouth's great advantage is that all the attractions are close together.

During my recent visit to the region, as I said, I had the opportunity to meet with the Gascoyne Development Commission in Carnarvon. The commission informed me that they are hoping to set up an Aboriginal cultural and heritage centre which will of course be run by local Aborigines. The centre should not only be a drawcard to visitors but more importantly will provide jobs for local Aborigines.

Aborigines in fact comprise 13 per cent of the total population of the region and increased levels of Aboriginal enterprise development and employment are essential if Aborigines are to gain greater social and economic independence. Aboriginal unemployment levels in the Gascoyne are very high and, in my view, tourism ventures are an excellent way to provide Aboriginal groups with rewarding employment.

The new Exmouth marina and proposed Exmouth resort development will also be a great boost to tourism in the Gascoyne region. Tourism could grow if international aircraft started operating out of Learmonth RAAF base, which was used to service the US Harold Holt radio base at Exmouth for many years. Over the time that the Americans were running the Harold Holt base, once or twice a week the world's largest aircraft—the Galaxy and Starlifter—called in to supply the Americans in Exmouth. Currently, the Exmouth Shire Council and Gascoyne Development Commission are seeking to have Learmonth made a designated international airport.

BREAK.PARA: Such a designation would significantly improve export opportunities, and horticulture produce could be airfreighted to markets such as Jakarta, Singapore and Manila. Let me talk a little about the horticulture potential of the Gascoyne area. Horticulture is a mainstay of the region's economy and brings in some $30 million a year. It is important to note that, because of the Gascoyne's unique climate and high quality ground water reserves, it is a region that national and international buyers will look to for the purchase of off‐season vegetables and fruit. In that context the ability to airfreight vegetables and fruit to South‐East Asian cities becomes very important.
The Gascoyne produces more than half of Western Australia's bananas and, in addition, the region produces 15 per cent of the state's vegetables.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much better than Queensland.

—Much better than Queensland, bigger and more juicy. A variety of tropical and subtropical fruits are produced in the irrigation farms along the Gascoyne River. Table grape growing is an emerging industry in the Gascoyne and is expected to considerably increase in value as time goes on.

BREAK.PARA: As I have stated, the Gascoyne horticulture industry is an industry with considerable potential to generate both jobs and exports for Australia. In 1995‐96, Australia's food exports totalled $15 billion and approximately 40 per cent of these exports went to Asia. It seems quite evident to me that the Gascoyne region should tap into this market, and the government's announced supermarket to Asia strategy provides very ready means for the Carnarvon growers to do this.

The Supermarket to Asia Council, which has been established by the Prime Minister to provide strategic direction and priority setting for the agrifood industry, provides assistance with promoting food products in the Asian area. I believe the growers in the Gascoyne area would do well to take advantage of this initiative, and I have put them in touch with the Prime Minister's department and the Supermarket to Asia Council to enable them to do this.

Another primary industry in the Gascoyne region is fishing, which is valued at around $60 million per year. Demand for Australian fish in the south‐east Asian area is said to be increasing. Our fish stocks are increasing as the fish stocks in the Pacific and Indian oceans are diminishing. There are some 72 pastoral stations in the Gascoyne region and of course the pastoral industry was the traditional industry of that area. Pastoral production in 1993‐94, again from figures provided by the Gascoyne Development Commission, was valued at some $17.8 million.

At present, Gascoyne wool prices are down and, because of this, pastoralists have moved away from wool production to meat from sheep and cattle and, interestingly, to goat farming. In the past, goats in the Gascoyne have been considered a pest. However, today some of the pastoralists harvest feral goats for meat and live export as South‐East Asia and the Middle East markets have considerable demand for these animals.

Until recently, it was only salt that was mined in the Gascoyne region. However, today gypsum and limestone are being mined, and there are huge supplies of limestone to supply building requirements in Western Australia. Mining in the Gascoyne, in general, is valued at some $50 million per year. Mr Acting Deputy President, the Gascoyne region is approximately twice the size of your own state of Tasmania. It comprises 140 square kilometres of land area and represents about six per cent of Western Australia's total land area. It is, as I said, situated in the mid‐north of Western Australia.

The Gascoyne region is not equipped with good communications infrastructure. In fact, no mobile telephone services are available in Exmouth or Shark Bay, and there is no mobile coverage on the North West Coastal Highway. The region does not have an Internet provider, nor does it get SBS, Triple J or ABC Classic FM. Given that industry is generally attracted to regions that boast the best communications infrastructure, the poor communications infrastructure in the area is seen as a problem by the Gascoyne Development Commission.

It has been argued that because of Carnarvon and Exmouth's relatively small population, these towns do not warrant funding for improved communications services. However, I would like the Senate to note that the Gascoyne Development Commission has made the very valid point that the population of the towns, together with the roving tourist population, should be taken into account in assessing the entire regional population when determining whether additional funding for communications infrastructure should be allocated to this region. A strong case can be made for the communications infrastructure to be improved because the Gascoyne contributes greatly to the national economy, and that also validates the case, in my view, for the provision of SBS, Triple J and Classic FM to the people of the region.

As I have previously stated, the concerns of the North West are very much my concerns, and I am pleased to have had the opportunity to place on record in the Senate that there are tremendous economic and development opportunities in the Gascoyne region. In summary, the Gascoyne has the potential to be a major food supplier to our Asian neighbours, and it is a region which will continue to contribute very strongly to our national economy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.54 p.m. to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, do you agree with the Prime Minister, in speaking at the Aboriginal Reconciliation Convention, that:

QUESTION.PARA: Australians of this generation should not be required to accept guilt or blame for past actions and policies over which they had no control.

Do you also agree with the Prime Minister, in launching the Natural Heritage Trust, that our degraded, attacked and badly neglected environment is the fault of all of us and is a responsibility the whole community must carry? Can you explain why our past actions and policies on the environment are the fault of all of us, yet our past actions and policies towards the Aboriginal people are not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the ATSIC chairman, Mr Gatjil Djerrkura, who said in a press release this morning:

ANSWER.PARA: By expressing his personal sorrow for the hurt suffered by the indigenous families separated by the policies of past governments, the Prime Minister has made an important first step in acknowledging the seriousness of the issues.
He goes on—and I am answering the question, Senator Faulkner, in relation to guilt, because he brings that up too—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a question of responsibility, not guilt.
—The question was about both. Mr Djerrkura goes on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: While it is true that some non‐indigenous Australians have suffered as a result of mistaken welfare policies, no other part of the Australian community has faced the direct intrusion into family life by governments acting purely on the basis of race. No other part of the Australian community has suffered the stress and social damage that result from a policy of teaching children to forget their family links and denying their culture.

While we await the federal government's formal response to the report from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, I ask all Australians to think about how you would react to having your children forcibly removed. I ask all Australians to consider how you would feel if you knew that your children were forced to forget about their family, their community and everything that makes a person proud of who that person is.
I will not read the whole of the press release, because it is now on the public record. He refers then to the fact that:

There can be no doubt that the removal of children has had an enormous impact on our cultures. The loss of community and of identity has had the effect of worsening the many other disadvantages faced by our peoples.

I would ask all senators and, in fact, all Australians to read that report because it refers to guilt there and says, within the report, that guilt is not something that advances the future consideration and—
Senator Bolkus and Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obvious those who are critical of the report in its context have not read it. It is 700 pages. I will be producing a formal response to that this afternoon.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: BOLKUS

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't read it but you are going to do it this afternoon.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Abetz interjecting—
Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond this afternoon, and constructively—
—Order! There is far too much conversation across the chamber to hear the answer that the minister is giving.

—unlike the ill‐informed and ignorant responses that I get from the other side, to which I have become accustomed. There is never anything constructive that comes from the other side. On this occasion I would ask the opposition to be constructive and to read the report, as I would hope that everybody would, because it casts a different complexion on the leaked reports that came out in the media last week. It needs very considerable study. It is beyond the wit of the rabble on the other side to even read the thing. I would ask that they give it a constructive understanding and read the report rather than bring in these other issues—something Senator Faulkner did in the second part of his question in relation to the environment. To link that when we have a report that has been released, which the opposition have had a chance to read—dare I ask any of them on the other side whether they have read it. Have they read it?
—Yes.
—Do you notice, Madam President, that one person on the other side has read it? He has read it. He can read!

—I rise on a point of order. My point of order is that I have not received a copy and I think many other senators are in that position. I resent the statement made by the minister to imply that we should have read it.

—Order! I would also remind the minister that it is disorderly to be asking questions of the opposition at this time and I do not think conclusions should be drawn from the fact that only one member of the opposition was disorderly in responding.

—I rise on a point of order. My point of order is that it is inappropriate for the minister, who is responsible for the welfare of indigenous people in this country, to politicise his comments when he knows how important this report is. You only have to look at the response from his colleagues to get some indication of how they feel about this report.
—There is no point of order. You are debating the issue and there will be a proper time for that.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you obviously either misunderstood or misheard my question. The Prime Minister said, on 22 May, that the environment has been wasted, it has been degraded, it has been attacked, it has been spoiled, and it has been badly neglected, and that that has been the fault of all of us, and that it is a responsibility that the whole community must carry. What I am asking you to explain is why, in the view of the Prime Minister, our past actions and policies on the environment are the fault of all of us, yet our past policies and actions towards the Aboriginal people are not. Could you explain?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am proud to support the Prime Minister. We have the best Prime Minister that I can recall since the days of Malcolm Fraser. It is a pity that the opposition do not have a leader of the same calibre because if you read all the press today you will see that they are out there looking for a leader. They have got to find a leader who has the strength and courage of his convictions that our leader has. It is a bit of a shame that they do not have one, because then we would have a decent opposition instead of the rabble that exists there today. I have great pleasure in supporting the Prime Minister because I have got a leader in front of me that I am happy to follow.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. My question relates to the government's economic strategy, which has seen a massive reduction in interest rates since the Howard government came to office. Is it a fact that repayments on an average $100,000 mortgage will now result in savings to Australian families of $292 a month? How will the government's winning trifecta of low inflation, low interest rates and strong business investment assist Australian families and small business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday's announcement by the ANZ that it will reduce its home loan interest rate to 6.99 per cent is further good news for Australian families. The St George Bank yesterday also cut its standard variable rate to 7.05 per cent. This is a further vote of confidence in the government's economic strategy. When the coalition was elected, the standard variable loan rate was 10.5 per cent—just over a year ago. It is now 6.99 per cent—a 3.5 per cent reduction since we were elected. What does that mean in dollar terms? As the honourable senator said, on a $100,000 loan, that is $292 a month in interest rate payments that Australians are better off. Madam President, do you remember the comparison? Interest rates under Labor, 17 per cent: families paying $1,417 a month in the same circumstances. Under the coalition, 6.99 per cent, $707 a month—from $1,417 down to $707. That is the distinction between Labor and the coalition. Under Labor, record high interest rates; under the coalition, the lowest home interest rates since 1969.

ANSWER.PARA: It was the government's policy to reduce debt, which was opposed at every step by Labor but, nevertheless, we were determined to do it. We inherited a $10.3 billion deficit. Within the space of three years, we will turn that to a $1.6 billion surplus. What is the reward? The reward is low interest rates, low inflation, low debt and strong investment. Yesterday's figures show capital spending 18.6 per cent higher than in the same quarter last year.

Labor stands condemned. Labor, by comparison, had high deficits, high debt, high interest rates and high taxes. Speaking of taxes, very briefly, where does the Labor Party stand on the issue of tax reform? All over the place, it would seem. What did Mr Beazley say? He said it was a distraction. What did his shadow Treasurer say? At the same time that Mr Beazley said it was a distraction, former Senator Evans said, `There may be a case for tax reform. Of course, we would have to look at any such proposal.' He, of course, got a slap across the cheek, so the next day he came back and said, `Of course, tax reform is a second or third order issue in this country.' But nobody told Mr Tanner to shut up—Mr Tanner, another frontbench spokesman of the Labor Party. What did he say? He said, `Labor must examine alternative foundations for our tax system.' Mr Beazley is saying, `Ignore it, take no notice,' and Mr Tanner from the Left is saying, `It's time to examine tax reform.'

TALK.START.PARA: —What does Sherry say?
—No GST.
—What exactly did he say?
—Order! There are too many interjections.
—He referred to the ability to avoid or artificially minimise—
—Answer the question!
—Order! There are senators who are absolutely shouting and attempting to drown out question time. It is disorderly to do so.

—I will sum up with Mr Tanner's final comment. Just listen to this; this is the Left speaking. He said, `We must avoid becoming economically irrational, lapsing into mindless populism, recycling the policies of the 1950s and defining ourselves by what we don't like. We can't afford to return to the 1970s.' Senator Cook, this is your Mr Tanner—one of your frontbench members—warning you, warning the frontbench to catch up with the 1990s, to recognise what this coalition government is doing; that is, putting the important economic issues on the table and taking action. Take note, Senator. (Time expired)

—I direct my question to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, are you aware that the executive chairman of Normandy Mining Company, Mr Robert Champion De Crespigny, described the Prime Minister's speech to the Aboriginal Reconciliation Convention as `totally inappropriate'? Furthermore, are you aware that the deputy chairman of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, Dr Alex Boraine—who was the keynote speaker—said, `I don't think it was time for an abrasive, fairly excitable speech at certain stages which could whip up people who are feeling very deeply and who are very bruised'? Minister, do you agree with those views, that Mr Howard should have stayed right away from native title issues and ATSIC funding and that it was a day to reflect on the renewal of the nation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important question. I had lunch with Dr Alex Boraine yesterday at the reconciliation convention, and I discussed this matter with him. He asked me the background to it and expressed his view to me personally. I think those of us who were present on that day have to acknowledge that the reconciliation convention has been a great success. Senator Kernot was there and was applauded, correctly, at the time and would be aware of that. That applause was exceeded only by the applause for the Governor‐General yesterday, so I understand.
—Quite right. Have you read his speech?

—I was there, and the Governor‐General's speech was outstanding, and I had pleasure in telling him and Lady Deane what a great speech it was. The positives of the reconciliation convention should be acknowledged. It is still going on, and it is an outstanding success. Yesterday was the 30th anniversary of the passage of the referendum where over 90 per cent of the electors voted.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Kernot's dance card was referred to last night and was not filled, but I think it should be acknowledged that the dinner and the entertainment last night were absolutely outstanding. There were awards.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has any of this got to do with the question?

—The question, Senator Collins, was about the reconciliation process, and this convention is going on for three days. That is what it was about. I want to force honourable senators to understand the context, given that it is continuing and it is an outstanding success. Interestingly enough, the major award last night was given to the Ipswich City Council, which I think has a message in it too that should be noted.
—How full was their dance card?

—You will have to ask Senator Kernot that, Senator Collins, but it was referred to by Ray Martin, the compere last night. It was an outstandingly successful event commemorating the occasion. In the context of a convention to commemorate the event, I think it was inappropriate of a number of speakers in their opening comments to politicise something that was to be a commemoration of a referendum. Right from the beginning of that convention remarks were made in relation to that which politicised it. References were made to poisoning waterholes. If that was the context, I think it was incumbent upon the Prime Minister to reply vigorously. I saw that Dr Alex Boraine was also quoted as making certain remarks about the Prime Minister's anatomy. I think the Prime Minister showed that he has guts as well, and that was the reference I got out of it. I think that he is a man who has guts as well, and he had the guts to stand up and defend his 10‐point plan, which is supported by the government.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Fortunately, there are many of us on this side of the chamber who see that it takes more than guts to be a good leader. Did your office provide the Prime Minister's office with a constructive briefing on the significance of the reconciliation convention? Did you make suggestions about the nature of his speech and did you consult with ATSIC to see what their priorities were, so that they could be included in his speech?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to say that I converse with the Prime Minister on a regular basis and I am sure that there has never been a Prime Minister who has been across the issues as well as the present Prime Minister. But, as you would well know, Madam President, because he has guts and brains and heart and soul, he writes his own speeches. He is not like many on the other side—particularly other people who shall be unmentionable because they do not warrant mention. He writes his own speeches. He stands up for himself. He is a man of many parts—no pun intended. He is capable of writing his own speeches and forming his own opinions, and I am sure that he will continue to do so in the future.

—This question is to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I refer to today's report by the Information Policy Advisory Council into on‐line services in rural and regional Australia. Does the report recognise the importance of on‐line services in producing jobs and helping small business outside our capital cities? What is the government doing to ensure that rural and regional Australians have access to better and faster Internet and other communications services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very important question. The short answer is we are bringing them back into the game. They have felt like second‐class citizens for 13 years. Labor switched them off, and we are in the business of switching them back on. We are doing that in a variety of ways, not only through high‐speed access to the Internet but by bringing forward Telstra's FMO, which ensures enhanced services are available some three years ahead of the scheduled date; by giving them ISDN technology, which will be in place by the end of next year; and by encouraging facilities like telecottages and e‐mail—in other words, by allowing farmers and people in rural areas to get the benefits of the telecommunications revolution.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a tragedy, against that background, that Labor is not in the slightest bit interested in helping the bush. Do you remember how they fought tooth and nail against the Telstra privatisation bill? They did not concede for a moment that there were any benefits attached to a $250 million rural infrastructure program. To ram home the point and show that they have learnt nothing since that time, who, on the day after the budget, should put out a press release bagging that fund once again but Senator Schacht, clearly wanting to insult the bush!

This is the incredible thing. We all know what he has been doing in recent weeks, since it looked as though the numbers had turned decisively against him for preselection. He wandered off to Japan. He made a few statements on the car industry. He got up on the adjournment debate. He went on about industry policy. In other words, he is obsessed by trying to get back into the game and appealing as a last‐ditch effort to the people of South Australia.

So what does this press release do? It complains and it sets out a table that demonstrates what he would regard as the perfidy of this policy by having a per capita value attached to each of the states—in other words, how many people in rural areas get how much money per head out of this fund. What does his table show? What is he complaining about? He is complaining about the fact that South Australia does better than New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland or Western Australia. I can understand why he might want to spend a lot more time back in South Australia, because, if there is something he has to explain to his own people, it is why he would regard South Australia as deserving of a worse deal. The fact is that you have no commitment to the bush and you do not understand the benefits of giving access to telecommunications facilities.

He goes on to then complain that, in only one month, Telstra spends more money on capital expenditure than we have in this $250 million program. What are we meant to read into that—that you are going to commit yourself to spending a lot more than $250 million? Of course not. You are not prepared to spend one red cent on helping the bush. You are not interested in whether people get access to these facilities, whether farmers and people in regional areas can get onto the Internet, whether they can get the latest information on weather and other commodity reports.

BREAK.PARA: You are not interested in anything but playing politics. Senator Schacht said that and regards that as his great virtue—that he is not a policy man; he is only interested in politics. Well, this is very poor politics. You are losing the game everywhere else. Lindsay Tanner is exposing you; Kim Beazley is burying his head in the sand; and you have got Senator Schacht compounding the felony. I can understand how he survived in the recent massacre—and we were very grateful for it, I can assure you, on this side of the chamber—but you will have to do a lot better if you think the bush is going to be grateful for all those years of neglect.

The fact is that this IPAC report is yet another indication of the importance the government attaches to getting telecommunications services and new jobs out of the rural areas and will continue to lead the field. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is in two parts, is to Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Are you aware of a Western Australian politician's view that Aborigines are `the bottom colour of the civilised spectrum' and will you take this opportunity to disassociate yourself and your party from this obnoxious view?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Poor old Senator Cook hasn't the guts to stand up and say it is Senator Lightfoot.
—It is.
—Oh! Well why didn't he have the guts to say so, Senator Collins? Why didn't he have the other necessary parts of the anatomy that are required for that, Madam President?
—If you show him yours maybe he'll show you his.
—Really, that is a serious question that Senator Cook has just asked.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is too much noise in the chamber at the present time.

—Madam President, he is referring to Senator Lightfoot. I am certainly aware of comments of Senator Lightfoot, but we do live in a democracy. That might be not known by those on the other side. Senator Lightfoot has every right to express his personal views on a wide range of subjects. It is his prerogative to state his view, and I would think that every senator in this chamber has a right to express their personal views. As I have said, I have my own personal views on this particular issue.
—Pauline Hanson.

—Senator, I attacked Ms Hanson back on 22 March last year. If you look back you will find that is so. And those are my views. As I have said in the past—and I am happy to repeat them now—there are aspects of Aboriginal culture that the wider community could well learn from, and they include commitment to family and community and its very high and traditional Aboriginal culture. I also believe that, by exposing children in the wider community to Aboriginal culture, we are promoting a greater understanding and therefore a greater tolerance across society.

BREAK.PARA: I find myself in complete agreement with another Western Australian, Premier Richard Court, who said, `Aboriginal culture is an important and rich part of Australian society.' As I have said previously here in this chamber and outside, I consider myself privileged to have this portfolio, because it has given me a remarkable opportunity to visit so many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities during the past 14 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I take a point of order. My point of order is this: Senator Herron was asked specifically about a view expressed by a Western Australian Liberal, Senator Lightfoot, that Aborigines are the bottom colour of the civilised spectrum. He was asked whether he was aware of it. He was asked whether he would disassociate himself and his party from it. I ask you, Madam President, to direct Senator Herron to answer the question that has been asked of him.
—There is no point of order.

BREAK.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Madam President: Senator Faulkner has not been listening to what I have been saying. He just has not listened at all because I have made it perfectly clear what my position is. I think there is no point of order, Madam President. He is just filling in time.
—On a point of order, Madam President. I seek leave to make a—
—I ruled that there was no point of order, and Senator Herron then went on and completed his answer.
—Madam President, if it is in order, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—This is not the appropriate time to do so, Senator.
—Thank you, Madam President.

—Senator, I had ruled on the point of order and taken it that you were then completing your answer. If that is not the case, there is about a minute left to complete the answer, if you have anything further you want to say.
—I apologise to you, Madam President, because I thought I was standing on the point of order. I did not hear the—
—There was so much noise that people obviously did not hear what I said.

—Yes, I understand, Madam President. I was making myself perfectly clear. It is a pity really that everybody in this chamber has not had the opportunity that I have had to visit now 60 remote communities. As I said, we have a democracy. I have stated my position in relation to my high regard for Aboriginal culture, as Premier Richard Court has. It is a perfectly legitimate answer to a perfectly legitimate question. It is a pity Senator Faulkner did not learn from some of our Aboriginal leaders like Patrick Dodson or Gatjil Djerrkura. If he had, he would not perform in the way in which he does, Madam President.

BREAK.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is impossible for me—

BREAK.PARA: Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Collins, you have been persistently in breach of the standing orders.

—I have two supplementary questions. Senator Herron, you began by accusing me of a lack of guts. Will you demonstrate guts by disassociating yourself from the comment that Aborigines are the bottom colour of the civilised spectrum? Do these much publicised views of your Liberal Party colleague Senator Lightfoot accord with the views of the Liberal Party? If not, what action have you taken to ensure that they are repudiated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first question is yes and the answer to the second question is no.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, could you confirm to the Senate that over the last 20 years there have been at least seven formal inquiries by the states into land tenure, including pastoral leases, and could you confirm to the Senate that none of these inquiries recommended that pastoral leases be upgraded to freehold?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —As you know, Senator Minchin has been handling all the questions in relation to the Wik judgment. I am certainly not across the specifics. But I am happy to take that on notice and provide a formal answer to that question.

—Minister, are you involved in the Wik process discussions and would it not be reasonable to expect the minister for Aboriginal affairs to actually be considering the 10-point plan, but specifically point 4 of that 10-point plan? Would you be able then to generally describe the problem that point 4 of the 10-point plan seeks to address?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot asked were there seven state inquiries into pastoral leases. I just do not know the answer to that question. I am happy to get an answer to that question. As I say, I am involved in the process. I am in constant consultation with Senator Minchin, who has primary carriage of the matter. So I can get a formal response to you.

—My question also goes to the heart of Aboriginal affairs. It goes to the minister for Aboriginal affairs, Senator Herron. Minister, is it true that the government will be relying on the race power, section 51(xxxvi) of the constitution, to legislate your 10-point plan? Minister, does the government believe that this section can only be used for the benefit of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, or does the government believe that it also has the power under this section to legislate to their detriment?
—Order! I require Senator Alston and Senator Faulkner to stop speaking across the chamber.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a ploy that has been used by the opposition right from the beginning of the discussion and debate. It is really a debating matter. It is a statement that has been made in various arenas. I think he should look at the previous reply that has been given on this matter.
—Should he.

—Yes. It is a debating point that has been brought up and batted back and forth. I would refer Senator Bolkus both to the estimates when this was raised and to the questions without notice. He should look at that and have another go at it in his supplementary.

—I remind the minister that some two to three weeks ago I asked him a similar question. I would have thought in the meantime he would have got up to speed on it. Minister, it is quite obvious that you don't know, but didn't the Prime Minister acknowledge in parliament on Tuesday that the constitution was changed in 1967, that `the passage of the 1967 referendum was necessary for the benefit of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people', and that this `is a guide to the policies that should now be followed'? Minister, how can you possibly use the constitutional race power as the constitutional basis for your 10-point plan since, as the PM also told the parliament on Tuesday, his plans represents `a significant winding back' of indigenous common law rights?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
QUESTION.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the press reports of the Prime Minister's statement. I support them fully.

—My question goes to the minister for the arts. It is in reference to Artbank, which is a self-funding collection of some 7,500 Australian works, valued at an estimated $11 million, and which lends to a wide range of public and private instrumentalities. I also add for the minister's consideration that this is a major support for artists around Australia, not least in Tasmania. I ask the minister: is it true that Artbank is up for either sale or dismemberment? Is it going to be considered by cabinet? If so, will the minister put at least some limit on the anxiety of artists around the country by saying when that cabinet decision is going to be dealt with and what his submission to cabinet will be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a big ask. I don't think even Senator Brown would seriously expect me to answer in his terms. If he had bothered to read the budget papers, and indeed subsequent announcements, he would have been aware that there are ongoing discussions between myself and the Minister for Finance. It is no secret that the Department of Communications and the Arts commissioned a scoping study several months ago to examine the ongoing effectiveness of Artbank and to examine whether it remained appropriate for the Commonwealth to continue to be involved in its operations. As you may or may not be aware, it has assets to the value of about $11 million and it does not have any ongoing call on government funds. So it is therefore an asset of some value. What we are being asked to consider is whether that type of operation can be conducted in the private sector. Indeed, I have already had others indicating to me that they are contemplating setting up in opposition to Artbank. But no decisions have been taken. I am clearly aware of the ongoing success of Artbank.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise. Senator Brown is entitled to hear the answer to his question.
—Many in this chamber have probably drawn on the services of Artbank, which, after all, was established by a previous Liberal coalition government.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins, we don't need your commentary.

—It was established along with many other major national cultural institutions. I am sure the rest of the Senate knew it before now, but I will say it again for Senator Brown's benefit: there are ongoing discussions between ministers on the matter to consider the appropriateness of the Commonwealth's continued involvement. Unless and until a decision is taken, there will be nothing more to add.

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Can the minister say what contribution Artbank provides to the income of artists on an annual basis and whether that would be guaranteed through ongoing purchases in any sale to the private sector? Finally, because this is important to those people very concerned about this, because it does affect their incomes, will the minister at least put a limit on the amount of time that he expects government to be deliberating on this matter so that artists can know that there will be, by midyear, for example, a determination by the government? Or is this just an open‐ended process that is going to go on and on?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not going to go on and on. We will make a decision as soon as it is appropriate to do so. I cannot give you a figure about the amount of revenue that derives to individual artists. I do know that in many respects the concerns that have been put to me have revolved around the idea of somehow dumping the entire collec tion on the market and therefore significantly depressing prices.

ANSWER.PARA: Artbank has deliberately aimed to encourage emerging artists and to purchase their works from galleries rather than at auction houses so the full benefit, less commissions, goes to the artists themselves. It has played a valuable role. I would expect that there will continue to be a need to encourage that sort of activity.

Indeed, we have been trying to promote emerging artists across the field—rather than this elitist mob who thought the solution was to simply hand out Keatings of half a million dollars to your best friends. We think the people who deserve a helping hand are those who do not actually find themselves in the top tax bracket or who happen to live in Sydney. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, the Prime Minister, in his speech to the reconciliation convention, said that the government had given priority `to programs that directly target indigenous disadvantage in health, housing, education and employment'.
— Hear, hear!

—Yes, hear, hear! Are you aware, Minister, that the $37 million cut in the budget to Abstudy, mainly in the travel component, is going to devastate the programs for higher education for mature age Aboriginal students run by tertiary institutions across Australia? Are you aware, for example, that the cuts will result in the number of Aboriginal students able to attend the Diploma of Community Management course at Macquarie University being reduced from a planned 100 students in the year 2000 to none? Are you aware that the effect on the premier higher education institution for Aboriginal students in Australia, Batchelor College in the Northern Territory, has been described as `catastrophic', with a potential reduction in the student body at that institution from 1,800 to 200?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Collins for the question. I do not agree with the general statements that he made. I do agree with his comment that the government is prioritising in relation to health, housing, education and employment. We actually quarantined that in the budget. Not only that, we guaranteed the ATSIC budget for the next four years—major achievements in terms of health, housing, education and employment, which we believe are of significant priority for the government. I thank Senator Collins for bringing that to my attention again. It is enormously important because it will lead to better outcomes for Aboriginal people in all regards. I think it is important that that be acknowledged.
—You don't even know.
—I would also like it to be understood that there are 9,000 Aboriginal people now on Abstudy—
—I should have asked Senator Vanstone.
—And there are 34,000 doing TAFE courses, something that we should be very proud of as a community.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: COLLINS

TALK.START.PARA: —It's an Aboriginal college and you're the minister for Aboriginal affairs.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! All senators should cease interjecting.

—I was saying that there are 9,000 students on Abstudy and 34,000 doing TAFE courses, a very proud achievement for both sides of government. The median age of Aboriginal people in this country is 15 years of age. So there are enormous opportunities. I am very impressed as I go around the communities with the outstanding young people that I meet. I did go to Batchelor College, as Senator Collins knows—
—As I have.
—And as Senator Vanstone has, and I have presented awards there.

ANSWER.PARA: We have significantly increased funding for CDEP. It is the major employer of Aboriginal people living in remote communities. The government has made adjustments to education—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam President. With respect to the minister—I have waited a fair time—the question was very specific. I have asked the minister whether he was aware that the cuts made to the travel component of Abstudy, which directly affect the block release program that operates through the 200 only beds that colleges like Batchelor have got, giving it a student body of 1,800, are going to devastate that college. That was the specific question. The minister has not yet addressed it.
—I would ask you to keep focused on the question, Senator Herron.
—I was just getting on to that, Madam President. I said initially that I did not accept the premise that Senator Collins seems to have accepted.
—Tell us why.

—I am about to tell you. The government has made some adjustment to two existing programs, Senator Collins. The direct assistance element of the training for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander program, the TAP program, has been transferred to the new employment services market. And there will be some tighter targeting of several elements of Abstudy supplementary benefits to ensure a more effective use of funds. Abstudy benefits will still be more generous than those provided under Austudy.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Yes, Minister, I know you have been to Batchelor College. Is it true that, when concerns were raised with you directly on one of your much talked about 60 community visits about a possible erosion of Abstudy prior to the budget, you gave a categorical commitment to those Aboriginal people that you would be `a strong advocate for Abstudy during the budget process'? How do you reconcile this statement and this commitment you made to Aboriginal people with the boast you made to the Liberal Party conference last Sunday that you had cut $37 million from Abstudy in order to `minimise waste'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I have conferred with—
—One story for the bush and one for the towns.

—No, not at all. If you had listened, Senator Collins, to my previous response—and I will repeat it to you—you would know that we are more tightly targeting several elements of Abstudy supplementary benefits to ensure a more effective use of funds. There is no different story from one side or the other. It is on the record. I told the Liberal Party conference of these initiatives and I gave a list of them—in fact, we put it into the boxes in the press gallery because we are quite proud of those initiatives.
—The fact is you said you'd help!
—I did, Senator Collins. I was a strong advocate, as Senator Vanstone well knows, and I set up a interdepartmental committee—
—Why did you boast to your Liberal mates that you would cut the program, then?
—Only two sections have been cut back.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, reports indicate that meetings with the Chinese delegation led by Vice Premier Zhu Rongji were significant and encouraging in terms of the future relationship between both countries. Will you outline for the Senate the implications of these talks for Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for that question. I think it is interesting that here we have had a visit to Australia—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is too much noise in the chamber.

—Here we have had a visit to Australia by one of the most high-powered Chinese delegations ever and we have had heard nothing whatsoever about it from members of the Labor Party. They have no interest in it whatsoever.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise in the chamber for anyone to hear the answer.

—The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and I met with Vice Premier Zhu Rongji yesterday evening. Vice Premier Zhu was accompanied by Mr Liu, the Chinese Minister for Metallurgical Industry, and other Chinese officials. Vice Premier Zhu had earlier met with the Prime Minister and other Australian senior ministers, including the Treasurer and the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

ANSWER.PARA: In the lead-up to these discussions, the Vice Premier and his delegation had visited portfolio projects of interest in Western Australia in regard to iron ore and in South Australia in regard to both wool and wine.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise in the chamber. I am having difficult hearing Senator Parer.

—Two Australian companies, Ausi and Mineralogy, had also signed letters of intent with the representatives of China Iron and Steel and the Shanghai Metallurgical Holding Corporation regarding direct reduced iron ore. It has been as a result of gas developments in Western Australia that we have been able to see this downstream processing and the interest now in countries like China in relation to DRI.

ANSWER.PARA: On the resources side, I reassured the Vice Premier that Australia welcomed Chinese investment in our projects. Chinese investors also, I might point out, have a major stakeholding already in the Channar iron ore project and the Portland aluminium smelter. I welcome the recent conclusion of letters of intent, which I witnessed with Minister Anderson, of the two Australian DRI companies and said the government would be happy to facilitate further contact between Australian companies and Chinese investors.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the House of Representatives it's a big day. Howard's talking about long‐range vision.
—What about Tibet?

—I reminded the Vice Premier that an outcome of the Prime Minister's recent visit to China was an agreement for a separate delegation to visit Australia to examine the feasibility of investing in these projects. This has flowed from that. I assured him we would be happy to facilitate the visit, which I understand will now take place in June.
—Biggest customers in the world. Look, tell us his name again.

—It is interesting to hear the interjections from those opposite. They have no interest whatsoever in the fact that we are looking at trade, export income and downstream processing. The last thing they want to hear about is that we are about the creation of real jobs.

BREAK.PARA: In addition to the iron ore projects and resource projects, Minister Anderson welcomed the Vice Premier's visit in respect of wool development. I remind senators on the other side—who may not know that China imports about $800 million worth, or thereabouts, of wool from Australia—about the Vice Premier's comments on the excellent prospects for future growth in the wool trade between our two countries. That was the major thrust of those discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us his name again.
—You have no interest, Senator?
—Yes.

—You have no interest whatsoever. Those opposite think it is a joke. There remains a significant commitment between China and Australia for the wool trade, and this is extremely pleasing given that wool is our biggest trade and China is our largest and fastest growing market.

BREAK.PARA: Another aspect that was covered was in regard to tourism. Development of tourism between Australia and China is an important objective for the Australian government. Minister Moore reiterated to the Vice Premier Australia's desire to expand such links with China to obtain preferred destination status for incoming Chinese tourists. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, in broad terms how much taxpayers' money do you estimate the Commonwealth, state and territory governments will have to pay by way of compensation to pastoralists under the Prime Minister's 10-point plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Sherry for that question. As you know, Senator Sherry, the answer is that no-one is certain as to what compensation there will be, whether it be to pastoralists or indigenous interests. It is a question that needs to be resolved, and I think that will become more apparent as the legislation comes before the Senate. We will get some sort of estimate. That answer may be a little more broad than you asked for, but you did ask for a broad answer. It is as broad as you can consider it at the moment.

—Talking of estimates, isn't it true that governments are required to provide in the forward estimates for expenditure they can reasonably anticipate? Where in the forward estimates have you provided for anticipated compensation payments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is true, if you know what your forward estimates are concerned with in that regard. I think it is an impossible task to put a sum on it, as you know, Senator Sherry, given the context of the 10‐point plan.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, do you agree with the Treasurer's statement today that the ANZ Bank was now his favourite bank for passing on the full 0.5 per cent to home borrowers? If you do, do you endorse the ANZ's decision not to also pass on the 0.5 per cent rate cut to its small business borrowers, particularly in light of its $646 million half‐year profit announced today, up 24 per cent on last year, on the back of—wait for it—increased business lending?

QUESTION.PARA: Is this not just further evidence of the uncompetitive nature of the small business lending market which so concerned the Treasurer when releasing the Wallis report? When will the government acknowledge the massive market power of the banks over small business finance and intervene in the market to improve the cost of finance and to ensure fair business conditions on small business loans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not heard those comments by the Treasurer but I assume that this time you are quoting an individual in an accurate fashion, Senator Murray, as distinct from earlier this week. The Treasurer, of course, is quite entitled to mention who his favourite bank is. Let me go to the substance of your question. The issue is low interest rates, in particular to small business. This is the party which encourages low interest rates. Our strategy has been directed since coming to office to setting up the circumstances by which we can ease the pressure on interest rates. That has been the strategy, and I have to say that it has been a strategy not always fully endorsed by your own party, Senator Murray.

ANSWER.PARA: We believe that the measures that we have put in place have had a major effect on interest rates, and since we have come to office there have been major falls in interest rates. Equally, we are always keen to encourage greater competition in money markets. You would be aware of the Wallis inquiry, which we established to inquire into this particular issue and to see what other reforms the government could consider making to increase competition in money markets.

We endorse the view that it is important that the interest rates available to business be at the lowest possible rates. We endorse that position. We wish that we received strong support all the time from your own party in developing the strategy which will deliver low interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, we ask you to do more than endorse it; we want you to act on it.

BREAK.PARA: Yesterday's Yellow Pages Index of Small Business showed that 37 per cent of firms see barriers or impediments that limit their capital expenditure. Firms aspiring to significant growth—those which could generate more jobs—are more likely to see capital impediments. Given that Australian small business faces higher real interest rates than any of our major trading partners—and let us remember that real interest rates are far more important than nominal rates—isn't this government's failure to improve conditions of small business finance and allow them to obtain fair deals from the banks reducing the ability of small business to create jobs and grow?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say I do find it extraordinary, Senator, that you stand up and purport to speak on behalf of small business. We are asking you to assist us in a major initiative in relation to unfair dismissals in small business and, as far as I am aware, you are refusing to offer that support. I must say also that you seem to have failed to note that under this government interest rates have come down. We are the party of low interest rates. They are the party of high interest rates, and what we want, Senator Murray, is more help from the Democrats so that we can set up the strategy to continue this downward pressure on interest rates.

—My question without notice is to Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. How many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people will benefit from the centrepiece of your `for all of us' budget, the so‐called savings tax initiative?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —All of them.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, have you received any letters or other advice from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people thanking you for this initiative?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —There was great hilarity on the other side when I said, `All of them.' The reason that that initiative will benefit Aboriginal people is that it will benefit all Australians, including Aboriginal people, because there will be significant savings for this country and then money will be available as a result of that. We will get jobs out of it for Aboriginal people. Those opposite laughed; they thought it was a humorous answer. It was a correct answer.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the supplementary question, as to whether I have had letters, I assume that I have, and I will certainly check back for you and let you have a substantive answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?
—I do not carry them around in a sheaf in my pocket. I will let you know how many, if that is your request, and get back to you as soon as I can.

—My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Labor's recession that we had to have in the early 1990s was Australia's worst recession since the Great Depression in the 1930s. Will the minister outline the ways in which the Howard government is putting in place policies and reforms that will ensure sustained employment growth in the long term?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Tierney. This government has put in place the framework for consistent and strong economic growth. It is our fiscal responsibility that has in fact laid the groundwork for the interest rate reductions that we have already seen—four in a row. This means more investment and more jobs. Fiscal irresponsibility means fewer jobs, and that is what Labor did. Unlike the previous government, which jeopardised the interests of unemployed Australians by maintaining a policy of adding year by year to increasing levels of government debt, we will not do this. Labor did that for 13 years; this government is far more responsible. Unlike Labor, this government has not been passing blank cheques on an empty bank account that was going further and further into the red. We are repairing the mess after 13 years of very poor Labor government.

ANSWER.PARA: Net government debt was $17 billion when Mr Keating hacked his way into office. By the 1996 election, it had grown by almost $100 billion to reach $110 billion. To get a grip on the size of that, Madam President, you need to understand that total government outlays in 1996-97 were $130 billion, yet net government debt was $110 billion. The yearly interest rate on net government debt in 1996-97 was over $9 billion. That is almost the cost of two higher education sectors to the Commonwealth. For the interest of those who ask about reductions in funding in law enforcement, that interest bill is nine to 10 times the cost of all Commonwealth spending on public order and safety.

Some on the other side would suggest that the Labor gravy train could have continued indefinitely. Of course it could not have. Senator Carr, from the very left of the Left over there, would have no qualms about continuing to spend, running up debts that this generation's children would have to pay. Enormous government with enormous debt is the hallmark of Labor around Australia. Senator Carr and others like him on the other side seem to love debt. His association with the failed Kirner and Keating governments is great testimony to that.

This government, on the other hand, has a fundamentally different approach. The boom and bust days of Labor are over, because the boom always helps the top end of the town and the bust rips apart the battlers. Labor should have spared a thought for what they were doing to the battlers when they were drinking champagne with Laurie Connell, Alan Bond, et al. This government believes that steady growth allied with low interest rates and low rates of inflation is the only long-term way of increasing employment.

In the last bust we had, that recession, they destroyed 420,000 full-time jobs—330,000 were held by men and 220,000 were held by young Australians. The number of long-term unemployed increased from 114,000 to 349,000. Youth unemployment went from 14 per cent to 34 per cent. It has left a devastatingly deep stain of unemployment on the Australian economy. The bottom line is that Labor has never had a proper grip on economic issues. It is consistent and steady growth that will provide long-term opportunities for sustained employment growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister explain why the employment policies of this government will be more successful than the previous ALP government's failed so-called Working Nation program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Tierney. The failed Working Nation program was basically paying employment providers to have a go at getting someone a job. It did not matter whether you got them one or not. You could stick them in a training program and we would pay you that as an outcome. This government will not pay people to try to put unemployed people into jobs; we will pay them only when they actually put unemployed people into jobs. Unemployed people deserve no less than that.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lightfoot, Sen Phillip

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order 190, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The honourable senator may proceed.

—During question time, Senator Cook directed a question to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, in which he claimed, among other things, that I had said that Aboriginal people were the lowest colour on the civilisation spectrum. Most things that have been regurgitated are never as attractive as their pristine form. On this occasion this is no exception.

SPEECH.PARA: What I had said was during a discussion to advance Aboriginal housing, education and health. I thought it appropriate that we ought to know where some people at Aboriginal level were so that that expenditure could be put to better and more effective use. I, in effect, said that Aboriginal people in their native state were the lowest colour on the civilisation spectrum. The omission of the words `in their native state' was quite wrong and put a different slant entirely on what I had said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) in response to questions without notice asked by Senators Faulkner, Reynolds, Cook, Bolkus and Sherry this day, relating to Aboriginal reconciliation.

We have had the most extraordinary performance from the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs today in this chamber. We have a minister in this chamber who is not fit to hold office. We have a minister who has delivered no benefit to his constituency and clearly does not have a clue about the responsibilities that he has.

When asked today in question time whether he agreed with what the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said at the reconciliation convention and how that compared with the Prime Minister's statement, in launching the Natural Heritage Trust, that our degraded, attacked and badly neglected environment is the fault of all of us and is a responsibility that the community must carry, the minister could not answer. He could not justify the extraordinary inconsistency in Mr Howard's remarks.

He could not do anything, apart from give some pathetic defence of the Prime Minister. Apparently Senator Herron is the Prime Minister's last supporter in the Liberal Party. That was your effort—a pathetic defence of the Prime Minister's leadership.

When this minister for Aboriginal affairs was asked whether he would dissociate himself from Senator Lightfoot's view that Aborigines are the bottom colour of the civilised spectrum, he refused. Certainly, after question time we had the most extraordinary statement that I have heard made in the Senate chamber since I have been a senator. I have been a senator since only 1989, but I have heard no less worthy or contemptible remarks from any representative in this parliament in the time that I have been here than what I heard today. When asked a question in question time today by Senator Kernot about whether there had been seven inquiries into the mistakes—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I have a point of order. I ask Senator Collins to withdraw his remark that someone was a racist.
—Order! I did not hear Senator Faulkner say that someone was a racist, but if he did say that I would ask him to withdraw.

—I do not think that I said that someone was a racist; I could have, but I did not. When asked a question by Senator Kernot about inquiries by the states into land tenure, what did the minister for Aboriginal affairs say? He said, `Ask Senator Minchin.' Senator Minchin is a parliamentary secretary in this place. We cannot ask Senator Minchin questions without notice in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: What was said when that point was made during question time? Senator Alston, the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate, said, `Put your questions on notice.' It is not good enough that the minister for Aboriginal affairs is not capable of answering these questions that go to the heart of his responsibilities.

When Senator Bolkus asked this minister a question about whether the government would be relying on the race power, which is section 51(xxvi) of the constitution, to legislate the 10‐point plan, what did Senator Herron say to the Senate? The minister for Aboriginal affairs in this country said that the question was a debating point. He could not answer it. He has been asked before. He has failed to answer it now on two occasions before this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a liar.
—Senator Campbell, will you withdraw that please.
—When he stops lying, I will.
—Senator Campbell, you have made an unparliamentary comment. Would you please withdraw it.
—I will withdraw it if he stops telling lies about the minister.
—Unconditionally please, Senator Campbell.
—I withdraw.
—Thank you. Senator Faulkner, please resume.

—When asked a question about Abstudy by Senator Bob Collins, this minister was unable, or unwilling, to answer the question. When asked a question by Senator Sherry about the forward estimates, he was unable to answer the question, unable to inform the chamber. Perhaps Senator Herron's most extraordinary performance today was when Senator Carr asked, `How many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders will benefit from the centrepiece of your government's "for all of us" budget—the savings tax initiative?' Do you know what this minister said? He said, `All of them.' Not even Mr Costello would say that.

SPEECH.PARA: If you do not pay tax, if you are a social security beneficiary or a pensioner, and unless you have substantial savings, you do not get benefits from the savings tax initiative. Here is a minister in this government who does not know. He is incompetent. He has demonstrated it again today. He is absolutely unable to fulfil his responsibilities as a minister representing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in our community. He stands exposed today as the weakest minister in the Howard government.
