TALK.START.PARA: —It really becomes very sad, does it not, when the opposition seeks to play politics with a very important social issue that is confronting this country. I could set the record straight and make assertions about the Australian Labor Party's history when it comes to race. People on the other side of this chamber have got up to praise the work of one Arthur Calwell, saying what a fantastic fellow he was and what a fantastic contribution he made to race relations within this country.

BREAK.PARA: He is a man who is on record as having said: `Japanese women should not be allowed to pollute our shores.' Does the Australian Labor Party dissociate themselves from those comments? Arthur Calwell, a great Labor leader, on another occasion said:

If Australians are ever foolish enough to open their gates in a significant way to people other than Europeans, they will soon find themselves fighting desperately to stop the nation being flooded by hordes of non‐integratables.
Another comment—this is a real beauty for Senator Bob Collins and the like who try to beat their breast about these issues—goes like this:
No red‐blooded Australian wants to see a chocolate coloured Australia in the 1980s.

That is the race record of the Australian Labor Party. I do not condemn Arthur Calwell. He was a product of his time. If people want something more up-to-date, we will hear something from your former leader, Paul Keating, who said:
It is time we considered the enormous cost of bringing migrants to this country. . . After all, the best migrant is the infant Australian.
If you want me to keep quoting, I will.

Do you remember what Gough Whitlam and your Labor government did in relation to the South Vietnamese embassy staff who were stranded in South Vietnam at the end of the Vietnam War? You left them there to a certain fate. Do you know why you did it? Because that cabinet took the view that there should not be any more Vietnamese coming to this country because it might cause social problems. So do not come into this chamber high and mighty suggesting that you are purer than the driven snow in relation to matters of this nature.

It gives me no joy at all to provide all those quotes to this parliament. The Australian Labor Party had in its ranks a certain member for Kalgoorlie for a period of time. Let us get all this into perspective. The question is: do you want to play cheap, nasty politics or do you really want to find a solution to some of the huge problems that are confronting this nation?

I have to say that Senator John Herron, as Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, has set about his task in a professional manner. He is a person who is determined to cut through the nonsense of political correctness to actually achieve benefits for those Aborigines, whom, might I add, we usually do not see on TV. The chances are they were not even at the reconciliation conference. They are the Aborigines who live in the outback communities—the communities that I, as chairman of the joint standing committee on native title, have had the opportunity to visit and see. If what I have seen in my 12 months in that position is a result of 13 years of Labor devotion to those people, I have to say that I would hate to have seen them if the Labor Party had in fact neglected them.

Do not come into this chamber pretending that you are genuinely concerned, because you are not. You are trying to play cheap politics. What I am asking you to do is consider the fate of Robert Tickner. Join with us, and together we will try to deliver some real beneficial outcomes for the Aboriginal community in this country. If you were to do that, all of us would benefit—all Australians, black and white, Labor and Liberal. The chances are that is too much to ask. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the answers given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, during question time today, and in particular the personal explanation relating to an answer that was just provided by the new senator, Senator Lightfoot. I think I am correct in saying—although I have not followed all the proceedings of the chamber—that that was Senator Lightfoot's first contribution to the debate in this chamber as a senator from Western Australia. It was quite simply the most ignorant—
—I take a point of order, Madam Deputy President.
—Are you going to stop me from speaking?

—This may be an interesting debate, but the time for that debate is not now. The time now is your opportunity to debate answers given by ministers during question time. Madam Deputy President, I suggest that you inform Senator Collins that he should comply with the standing orders.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FAULKNER

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Madam Deputy President: Senator Cook asked Senator Herron a question and a supplementary question that went to the views of a Western Australian politician, who was identified as Senator Lightfoot, that Aborigines are the bottom colour of the civilised spectrum.

INTERJECT.PARA: I can say on this point of order that, following the answer Senator Herron gave, we had a personal explanation from Senator Lightfoot. Senator Collins, in his contribution, is properly addressing both Senator Herron's answer to the question and the response to that answer that was given after question time by Senator Lightfoot.

Senator Cook's question was the third question asked by the opposition during question time. I believe the comments made by Senator Collins are absolutely in order. If Senator Hill had a modicum of decency or guts, on behalf of his own parliamentary party he would get up right now and dissociate his party and his government from Lightfoot.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this a point of order? On the point of order, Madam Deputy President: it is quite within the standing orders for Senator Collins to debate during taking note of answers the answer given by Senator Herron on that question which related to comments made—
—Made by Senator Lightfoot.

—No, that was not the question. It was a WA Liberal politician, because Senator Cook was so gutless that he did not mention Senator Lightfoot and he was so gutless that he asked the question before Senator Lightfoot had made his first speech.
—Order! What is your point of order, Senator Campbell?

—On the point of order, what Senator Collins cannot do under standing order 190—which was the standing order Senator Lightfoot used—is debate the matters. It is quite clear under standing order 190 that he cannot debate a personal explanation. He can debate the answer given by Senator Herron.
—On the point of order, Madam Deputy President: I understand Senator Campbell's attempt not to have further debate on this matter at this point in reconciliation week with his new colleague—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Campbell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, yes, it is. Senator Campbell is wrong, as a matter of fact, and I just wish to point that out to the chamber and that is why I rose. Senator Lightfoot, by name, was in fact specifically part of the supplementary question. The question involved remarks on Senator Lightfoot's Liberal views on the position of Aboriginal people in Australia as at 28 May 1997. The answer related directly to that and so did the further explanation Senator Lightfoot gave. So the question and answer directly related to Senator Lightfoot's views about Aboriginal people in Australia. Therefore, what I am saying is absolutely in order.

—Order! It is in order for Senator Collins to debate the issue because, whilst Senator Lightfoot was not initially named, the question related to statements made by him. I am sure there is nothing in this that says that Senator Collins cannot debate the issues in the questions asked by—
—He should have asked for leave to debate the personal explanation.
—Order! He is not debating the personal explanation. He is debating the question.
—On a point of order: he took note of the answer and the personal explanation. I am saying he can go for the next five minutes on the answer, but he cannot talk about the personal explanation.
—What are you covering up?

—I suggest Senator Faulkner gets the Senate's approval to alter standing order 190, which says that such matters cannot be debated. You should move a motion now to get the standing orders changed, but you sought to move to take note of his answer and the personal explanation. Go for your life on the answer but, under the standing orders, you cannot, unless you want to flout the rules—
—He's wrong.
—Go check the Hansard , Senator Collins. You are the old Hansard checker. You go and check it yourself, or go and check the tapes.
—Shame on you, Robert, for trying to stop this.
—Order! Senator Collins is quite able to refer to the answer because the answer was about Senator Lightfoot's comments, and I am sure that Senator Collins is going to do that.
—In relation to Senator Lightfoot's views—
—On a point of order, Madam Deputy President, can I please have a ruling on standing order 190, which says you cannot debate a point of a personal explanation?
—Excuse me!
—It is a point of order.
—Three times?
—Order! Senator Campbell, I have given a ruling as to what Senator Collins should be addressing his remarks to and I will listen to what he has to say.
—It doesn't suit you because you don't like what Lightfoot said.
—I seek a ruling, Madam Deputy President, on a point of order. Do you allow or disallow Senator Collins to debate a point of a personal explanation under standing order 190? Yes or no?
—I have given an answer, Senator Campbell, that Senator Collins will be able to address those issues that were raised in the question and the answer.
—That's the ruling.
—That is the answer, and it is the second or third time I have given it.

—I am addressing myself to the question and answer given on the question of Senator Lightfoot's views on the position that Aboriginal people have in this nation today. I repeat again that in my 20 years in politics, in my 20 years as a member of parliament, I have never heard a more ignorant, ill‐informed or offensive statement made by a member of the Australian Liberal Party.

BREAK.PARA: I would point out that Senator Herron was a President of the Queensland Liberal Party for many years. The Queensland Liberal Party expelled, with a great deal of breast-beating and boasting, the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) from the membership of the party. As a lifetime member of the Labor Party, I know what an extreme step it is to take to expel a person from membership of a party, particularly for the Liberals. She was rightly expelled from the party for her statement.

Senator Lightfoot is a Liberal and now a sitting member of the Senate. Senator Lightfoot arrives here carrying a $460,000 pension from the Western Australian parliament with a seat in the Senate, and Pauline Hanson gets expelled! The minister for Aboriginal affairs says in defending him, `It's a broad church we've got in Australia. It's a democratic society and he's free to say anything he likes.' That is what the minister for Aboriginal affairs said.

Is it not extraordinary that, as it just happens—and I must say I was grateful to the Australian Financial Review for publishing this fascinating piece of Australian history yesterday—James Douglas, the 14th Earl of Morton and president of the Royal Society, was a greater liberal with more advanced thinking about the Aboriginal people of this country in 1768 than the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), his minister for Aboriginal affairs and, certainly, our new senator from Western Australia are in 1997? I will quote briefly from the extract of this fascinating advice given by the Earl of Morton to Captain James Cook on his way to Australia in the Endeavour. In relation to the native people of this country—the native people of this country, Senator Lightfoot—he said in part:

To have it still in view that shedding the blood of those people is a crime of the highest nature:‐ They are human creatures, the work of the same omnipotent Author, equally under his care with the most polished European; perhaps being less offensive, more entitled to his favour.

They are the natural, and in the strictest sense of the word, the legal possessors of the several Regions they inhabit. No European Nation has a right to occupy any part of their country, or settle among them without their voluntary consent. Conquest over such people can give no just title; because they could never be the Aggressors.

What a tragedy for Aboriginal Australia that that direction given to Captain James Cook was never given effect afterwards. But, I personally know seven 7,000 or 8,000 Australian Aboriginals, mostly living in Arnhem Land in the Top End, who are native Australians and who live traditional lifestyles.

When I first started to live among them 30 years ago, as an ignoramus then in respect of Aboriginal Australia, I was absolutely struck by the richness of their lifestyle, the complexity of their culture and their relationships, the beauty and complexity of their languages and the degree of family relationships that our society has long lost. I listened with fascination in my first contact with native Aboriginal Australians, thousands of whom are still living like that today, as Senator Herron full knows, as they pointed out parts of the landscape around them, identifying the people who owned it back four and five generations, all from memory.

Senator Lightfoot might be interested to know that Aboriginal people in native Australia living traditional lifestyles, as I said before, have a richness of culture second to none, a richness of culture which clearly the Western Australian senator, who has Aboriginal Australians living in this situation in his own state, is absolutely ignorant of.

I say this to Senator Robert Hill, and that is why I wanted to address it to Senator Hill. Senator Hill, you are supposed to be the leader of the Liberals in here. Why don't you investigate whether Senator Lightfoot should be expelled from membership of the Australian Liberal Party for saying something grossly more ignorant, ill‐informed and offensive than anything the honourable member for Oxley has ever said?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel compelled to rise and speak on this issue and perhaps put some matters in focus. Firstly, I would say that, if we continue with the name calling and the exchanges that have been going on, I think we will advance the debate no further. I could refer to the opposition spokesman for Aboriginal affairs, Daryl Melham, who stated on the 7.30 Report :

SPEECH.PARA: There is only one thing missing in this debate and that is the white sheets and burning crosses.
If we were to dwell on comments like that we would get nowhere.

Let us look at deeds rather than the words. Let us look at what has been done and let us look at what this Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) has done. I put it to Senator Bob Collins, through the chair, that Senator Herron has done a great deal since he has had this office. He has visited over 60 communities. He is the only minister to have visited ATSIC in Perth, Western Australia. He was asked a question about Abstudy, which is not even in his portfolio. What the opposition is trying to do here is to score a cheap political shot and play the man and not the ball.

Let us look at the budget provisions in relation to ATSIC, which I dare say Senator Faulkner has not even seen. I challenge Senator Collins on it. What part is wrong with the announcement that we made of a new four‐year, $120 million indigenous business incentive program? What is wrong with that? What is wrong with putting ATSIC funding on a forward estimates course so that ATSIC can now have some security in the way it plans its finances? What is wrong with that rather than the year‐by‐year, ad hoc approach that was the hallmark of the previous govern ment? What is wrong with bringing in a program which will bring jobs to indigenous Australia where we have an unemployment rate at 38 per cent—a shocking rate? That is what this minister is doing, and I say that to Senator Collins in particular. I notice you do not ask him about Aboriginal health because he knows more about that than all of you put together. But, of course, that is not in his portfolio so you do not ask him.

It was timely that we celebrated the 1967 referendum, which was brought in by a coalition government. Governments around this country, including the federal government, celebrated that fact and also took note of the stolen generation report. Today you have heard the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, admitting that it was a blemish on the history of this country, as did the Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

We can wear sackcloth and ashes and speak here at great length but it will not get the job done. That is what Senator Herron has been about since he has been in this portfolio—getting the job done. That was done by visiting in excess of 60 communities, seeing what the situation is like on the ground and seeing that we have a long way to go with health. It was all very well for former Senator Richardson to get his photo in the paper when visiting a community. But where was the result of his work in health with indigenous communities? After 13 years what did we see in relation to education, health and unemployment in the indigenous sector? We saw a disgraceful lack of attention—in 13 years. This government has only been here for 13 months and already we are reducing the rate of unemployment, we are increasing economic opportunities and we are announcing programs of the sort that I just mentioned.

You are only going to help indigenous Australia by empowering them and by giving them opportunities in health, education and employment. As the good book says: by their deeds you shall know them, not necessarily by their words. A lot of rhetoric has been spoken here today. You judge us by our deeds and the electorate will when we go to the next election. We are willing to rely on what we have done in office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —I take note of the answer, which is included in Senator Faulkner's basket, I think, that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) gave to my question.

SPEECH.PARA: I did think it was unbelievable that the minister could not make a general response to the issue of upgrade of leasehold to freehold, because, fundamental to any discussion about Wik—which I would think would be a core issue to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs—and native title is the issue of land tenure and, within that, obviously the issue of leases and especially pastoral leases. That is why, in my supplementary question, I asked you about point 4 of that 10‐point plan: what was the general problem that the government was seeking to answer by use of point 4?
I thought I might use a couple of minutes to actually give you some of the details. I know you are listening to Mr Melham in the other House—

TALK.START.PARA: —He's finished.

—Well, I want to make a couple of points here because point 4 of the 10‐point plan envisages the possibility of upgrading to freehold. It is fundamental and I would have thought that you would have been able to make some general comments on it—unless you did not know what point 4 was.
—I don't know that there have been seven state inquiries. That was what you said: would I agree?
—But you totally ignored my supplementary question too about point 4 of the 10‐point plan and I thought that you should have been able to give a general answer to that.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been seven state inquiries and they have all recommended the retention of the leasehold system. But what I think is important to this debate is the history, because the actual pastoral leasehold land system is unique to Australia. It is unique to Australia because it reflects a particular history of Australian land settlement. I do not think we should lose sight of the fact that lease tenures were developed as essentially an expedient response to the outward settlement that was happening: the uncontrollable settlement away from colonial Sydney, for example, during the 19th century. A lot of this was so uncontrollable that governments decided to issue licences to use land for pastoral purposes. That was clear but between the 1850s and the 1960s, between—

TALK.START.PARA: —That was not clear.

—I am just about to tell you, Minister, that between the 1850s and the 1960s we saw a lot of subdivisions of leases. The purpose of that was to promote closer settlement. But this brought its own problems, such as environmental disasters because of very small grazing areas, and the high use of rents. It had to take account of erratic climatic conditions and limited market infrastructure. So it is not surprising that all of these inquiries have said that the maintenance of leasehold is the best way to go.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, we have seen in your 10‐point plan the beginning of the argument about freehold. Graziers are now arguing that they have to have freehold title because it provides the security of tenure needed to facilitate development—and by that they often just mean improvements to the property. Those arguments ignore the evidence. We seem to have slipped over this little point of history: pastoralists have not had exclusive use of the land and Aboriginal people throughout all this time have been able to have access to the rangeland for traditional and cultural purposes.

That is why the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in my view has to work out in the 10‐point plan a system to accord property rights in alignment with the cultural resource and policy framework that recognises this history. I do not think what you have in point 4 at the moment does that. Moreover, I think it leads to the possibility that there will be speculative rent seeking. We have seen what has happened where there has been an area of up grading at Cape York. That enabled speculators to capture local land monopolies of up to 3,000 square kilometres. I do not think that point 4 of the 10‐point plan reflects the history and the cultural balance. Senator Herron, as minister for Aboriginal affairs, you should have been able to give me a general answer to that question. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak in this debate. Can I say that the comments that Senator Cook referred to, as reinforced by Senator Lightfoot today, are the most offensive, racist comments I have heard in this place in my 16 years of parliament. I know I do not have the full five minutes to speak but the point I want to make is that one needs to make a very cold and sober comparison between what Senator Lightfoot said before he arrived in this place, which he reinforced today, and what Pauline Hanson got kicked out of the Liberal Party for. Let me just remind the Senate of her sin when she was expelled in February 1996. In the comments which led to Ms Hanson's resignation she said that racism in Australia was created by the government looking after Aborigines too much and handing them a tremendous amount of payouts. She said Aborigines could walk into a job in the police force, receive lenient court sentences, had better chances to get better housing and business loans and were the main instigators of crime and violence.

SPEECH.PARA: They were the comments for which she was expelled from the Liberal Party. If those comments were so abhorrent then, then Senator Lightfoot's comments today demand his immediate expulsion from the Liberal Party—nothing less than that, because it is not just the Liberal Party that is tainted; it is the government of Australia and Australia itself that are tainted by the continuation in the government of this country of a person who espouses these sorts of ideas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Undiluted racism.

—It is undiluted racism and for that we will be judged not only within Australia but outside as well. Nothing could be more conducive to divisiveness in this country than that sort of racism. Nothing could be more conducive to this country's developing an odour internationally, particularly in our region, than comments like this. I say to Senator Herron and Senator Hill, who have failed in leadership today, that this matter has to go immediately to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and Senator Lightfoot has to be judged on the principles that we want Australians to live by, those decent principles of humanity and dignity of individuals. We are not a civilised country unless we can respect diversity and particularly the indigenous people of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The comments that we heard reinforced today show disrespect; they are abhorrent. That sort of comment and sentiment would have proudly fitted into Hitler's Germany. I am not exaggerating when I say that, because what we had here today was a reinforcement of the statement that indigenous Australians living in their natural environment are the lowest of the colour spectrum. That is abhorrent to all of us. It is now a question of leadership and it goes straight to the Prime Minister. Unless this person is judged in the same way as others have been in the past, we will find that all the rhetoric, particularly in this reconciliation week, means nothing. This is a sad day for Australia; it has in fact been a tragic week for Australia, because an opportunity for us to embrace and reconcile has, at every opportunity, been dropped by the government.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for the debate has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on 16 June 1997, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the High Court of Australia (Fees) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 106 and made under the Judiciary Act 1903 , be disallowed.
This is another government measure which raises the fees of the High Court to an enormously unreasonable level; and we will try to disallow it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes that:

PARA.TAB: (i) on 28 May 1997 representatives of the Australian Chicken Growers Council visited Canberra to highlight several outstanding concerns regarding the Federal Government's intention to lift import bans on cooked chicken from Thailand, the United States of America (US) and Denmark,
(ii) the council has five concerns regarding the process leading up to the Government's expected approval of imported foreign chicken, they being:

TAB.TAB: (a) there must be a full technical evaluation of the capabilities of commercial cooking ovens and monitoring and control equipment,

(b) suitably qualified Australian Quarantine Inspection Service (AQIS) staff and industry technologists, by invitation, must inspect all applicant processing facilities in the US and Denmark as was done recently in Thailand,
(c) source chickens for import to Australia as cooked chicken meat must come only from regions certified free of the diseases of greatest quarantine and economic significance,
(d) areas of disagreement between AQIS and the industry concerning matters of detail contained in the draft protocols must be further examined, and
(e) protocols must be framed in a manner that requires less subjective judgement by AQIS staff; and

DEBATE.TITLE: SEPARATION OF ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER CHILDREN FROM THEIR FAMILIES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion to take note of the document Bringing them home , which was tabled on 26 May 1997, and to extend the debating time from 30 minutes to up to one hour.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the debating time for the motion provided under standing order 169 be extended to up to one hour.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from their Families, entitled Bringing them Home .

As senators would be aware, the government tabled the report of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from their Families on Monday afternoon. Today I wish to outline the processes the government will undertake to address the recommendations contained in the report. I hope that by presenting this statement today the opposition and minor parties have had the opportunity to examine the report. I know that it has been very short time frame, as was evident during question time today.

The report is a very detailed and lengthy document of almost 700 pages canvassing a wide range of issues. I would like to say at the outset that the report catalogues what can only be described as a sad and tragic episode in Australia's history. I myself had commented earlier that it was horrific.

As I have said before, anyone wanting to understand the aspects of the indigenous experience and some of its contemporary characteristics would be well advised to read some of the individual case histories and evidence reproduced in the report.

Much discussion in recent days has focused on the question of an apology for the events recorded in the report. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the Governor-General and myself have expressed our feelings in this respect. It should be noted that the main focus of the report is on how governments should deal with the continuing effects of past policies in terms of the family reunion and related services and on current policy and practices.

BREAK.PARA: The government acknowledges the impact of these past policies and practices and is already working to address the significant disadvantage currently being experienced by all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.

The report's 54 recommendations can be broadly grouped into three categories: firstly, reparation or compensation for the individuals, their families, communities and descendants; secondly, reunion, health and other services for those affected by past policies and practices; and, thirdly, Commonwealth legislation to regulate current state and territory child welfare adoption and juvenile justice practices and to enable transfer of jurisdiction to indigenous organisations as a form of self-government.

The recommendations are wideranging. They cover the responsibilities of a number of governments and other organisations. The Commonwealth, state and territory governments and non-government organisations, including the churches, which are the subject of many recommendations, will need time to fully consider the report. I will be writing to my Commonwealth colleagues seeking their advice in relation to a range of recommendations that fall within the Commonwealth's area of responsibility. Also, as I outlined on Monday, I will be writing to my state counterparts asking that their governments carefully examine the report and the recommendations which are related to their responsibilities.

The report will be considered by the Commonwealth‐State Ministerial Council for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs when it next meets in August, at which point I would expect the states and territories to have examined the report and provide some indication of actions they propose to take.

The inquiry also suggests that national framework legislation be introduced—presumably, by the Commonwealth—to regulate current police, judicial and/or departmental functions in relation to child welfare, adoption and juvenile justice. This would represent a significant interference on the part of the Commonwealth in state and territory responsibilities. Such action would do nothing to alleviate the situation of people who suffered from the past policies and practices which led to the removal of indigenous children.

Notwithstanding these reservations, these proposals concerning Commonwealth legislation in relation to adoption, child welfare and juvenile justice will also need to be considered by the functionally responsible ministerial councils in due course and, ultimately, the Council of Australian Governments. In this context, the Commonwealth is very concerned about juvenile justice issues. We will be addressing these concerns through initiatives such as the young offenders pilot projects announced recently in the budget.

The inquiry also supports the eventual transfer of responsibility for child welfare, adoption and juvenile justice to indigenous peoples as an expression of self-determination. This would be a matter for the states and territories, as I said, to consider in the context of their current arrangements in this area.

At the Commonwealth level we will need to give careful consideration to those recommendations which suggest action on the part of the Commonwealth. As I have already made clear, the government is committed to developing a practical response based on a commonsense approach that addresses the present and the future.

I would again reiterate that the government, in its submission to the inquiry last year, made it clear that it could see no equitable or practical way of paying cash compensation. As stated in that submission, the government does not believe that the actions of the past can be judged according to contemporary values. While this should not detract from a recognition of any failures of governments in the past and their consequences, it does suggest that monetary compensation is neither appropriate nor acceptable.

In addition, the government stated that, even if compensation were considered warranted, the government could see no equitable or practical way of now paying special compensation to those persons affected. As I said when the report was tabled, this position remains unaltered.

Leaving aside the question of monetary compensation, the Attorney-General's Department has advised that the report is flawed in its analysis of many of the key legal issues. It should also not be forgotten that, in the midst of this tragedy, there are a large number of very dedicated people and organisations, including the churches, who genuinely believe that their actions were for the benefit of indigenous Australians. Today, of course, neither the government nor right‐thinking Australians would either contemplate or condone those actions.

Finally, I would acknowledge that this is a very emotional and important issue, not just for indigenous Australians but for all Australians. It is about heart and soul and family. I would hope that we, as members of the national parliament, can take a constructive and mature approach to this issue. That means a calm and sensible consideration of the report and its recommendations and a commitment to seek a practical and realistic response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a very disappointing and unsatisfactory response from the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), having sat on the report for some seven weeks, apparently not knowing what to do with it. Having undermined the report and the author before it was made public and having aroused the public clamour for a response to the report, what we have from the government and the minister today is a damp squib. It is a process response; it is not a substantive response. In my view it is, in a sense, a non-response. It is not the response Senator Herron promised us in question time today. It is utterly devoid of content, like the minister who delivered it.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the national inquiry into the separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children from their families, entitled Bringing them home, is a document of profound historical significance for this country. The response of the government to the report and its recommendations will mark a water shed for the government and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). Will they stand exposed as bereft of compassion, as lacking in insight and having no courage? Will their equivocation and weak leadership be exposed as a mask for the moral bankruptcy and intellectual impoverishment that has characterised the time that this government has been in office?

I say that this is a report of substance and merit. It brings a breadth of research and a depth of understanding that offers hope that we can effectively address a root cause of both continuing disadvantage amongst Aboriginal people and the frequent failure of government‐sponsored policies and programs to alleviate targeted problems.

This report goes to the heart of the truism that the problems of today are inextricably linked to the history of dispossession, discrimination and social dislocation that is the shared experience of Australia's indigenous people. This report chronicles stories across generations of the systematic suppression of a culture and of the systematic and deliberate destruction of Aboriginal family units. These policies stamped on the basic structures of Aboriginal society and they all but destroyed them.

The stories in the report tell of individual pain, loss and suffering. They document an approach by governments, churches and private agencies that assumed and hastened the ultimate disappearance of a people and their culture. The fact that that destruction was not complete is testimony to the courage and resilience of individual Aborigines and the strength of the indigenous society in this country.

The energy and goodwill that have characterised efforts by Commonwealth governments from 1972 onwards in their endeavours to advance the interests of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders to improve their health, to better house them, to better educate them and to empower them by giving them tools for self-determination have not been matched by uniform or widespread success.

The substance of this report and the insights and recommendations for action that it offers really offer hope for greatly enhanced effectiveness in policy and programs. We have to confront past mistakes. We must address the implications of dealing with people and communities who have been deeply scarred by their experience of the dominant society. We have to acknowledge that, unless we accept that the policy of tearing apart indigenous families is a root cause of the circumstances, mind‐sets and behaviours that impede individual and social betterment in indigenous communities, we cannot improve anything. The government has sought to absolve itself with some trite suggestions like it was done for their own good or many of them benefited from the experience. Government members should read the report, and so should many Australians. Judge for yourselves how well these things stand up.

A common platitude attributes the social advancement of a few notable Aboriginal people as proof of the overall benefit of past policies, and the report really nails that myth. It presents authoritative studies that show that the numbers of indigenous Australians with post‐school qualifications is slightly higher, at 4.8 per cent, amongst those who were not taken from their families than those who were, at 4.4 per cent. The number of those removed from their families who are unemployed or out of the work force is higher, at 69 per cent, than those who stayed with their families, at 66.5 per cent. Differences in health and personal incomes were similarly differentiated.

There is no benefit in objective outcomes to balance against the massive spiritual, personal and social damage directly attributable to the stealing of indigenous children. The Prime Minister has still not apologised to the indigenous people forcibly removed from their families or the families and communities that were blighted. Only John Howard citizen has apologised. There is not the same weight of national regret and the recognition which would go some way towards healing past wrongs—and they are the wrongs that cry out from this report.

The chairman of the inquiry, Sir Ronald Wilson, rightly says that saying sorry has nothing to do with guilt; it has to do with the recognition of past wrongs. Mr Howard, Senator Herron, Pauline Hanson and others are the ones who keep talking about guilt. There are two possible reasons for Mr Howard's inability to exercise his authority and stature in this matter as Prime Minister of Australia.

One possibility is that he is just unable to grasp the substance and texture of the Australian nation, that he is unable to see past the Hills hoists, the comfortable vacations at Christmas time at Hawks Nest and sanitised 1950s history tests about explorers and squatters. The Prime Minister cannot understand the tumultuous history that made this nation what it is and that, among the triumphs, hurts were inflicted on hundreds and thousands of our indigenous people. It is not a black armband view of history but the reality of our past which causes him great discomfort and perhaps a twinge of guilt.

The other possible explanation is that, in denying Aboriginal people the comfort of an apology, Mr Howard is playing cheap politics, appealing to an imagined narrow‐minded and bigoted constituency with a hope of a boost at the polls. If that is so, he sells this country short and he does not deserve to lead this nation. If Mr Howard fails to apologise as both the Western Australian and South Australian premiers and parliaments have done—and I hope that this parliament will do so—he will enter the history books as an apologist for all that is narrow and mean spirited in the darkest corners of our wider society.

There are racist forces abroad in our community. They are affecting our society. They are affecting our relationship with our neighbours. The Prime Minister appears unwilling to either recognise them for what they are or deal with them. Our past policies on the environment are the fault of people ignorant of the consequences of their actions. It could be argued that our past actions and policies towards indigenous people were also borne out of ignorance, even though the removal of children from their natural parents is the height of cruelty and this fact could not have been lost on the perpetrators. And we heard something about that in question time today.

BREAK.PARA: I think Mr Howard needs to ignore what he reads as mainstream opinion from the opinion polls. He has to ignore Pauline Hanson, and he has to become Prime Minister. He should apologise. On behalf of all Australians, he should be taking the initiative to have this parliament apologise. He should apologise now. In the absence of a government initiative, I am moving an amendment today that gives the Senate the opportunity to unreservedly apologise to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians for the separation policies. This is an opportunity to do that. I urge all senators to see the Australian Senate adopt the amendment which I will formally move to the motion before the chair and commend to the chamber. I move:
Omit all words after "Senate", substitute:

"Recalling the Australian people's overwhelming decision in the 1967 referendum to confer upon the Commonwealth Parliament responsibility for enhancement of the rights and well-being of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people;
reaffirming the abhorrence of racism shared by the Australian people and their Federal and State Governments;

reaffirming Australia's recognition of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide and the International Convention on the Prevention of All Forms of Racial Discrimination;
recalling the Parliament's commitment in October 1996 to the principles of racial tolerance; and
recognising the profound economic and social disadvantage suffered by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people:

(a) affirms that the tabling of Bringing them Home , the report of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from Their Families, presents the nation with an unprecedented historical opportunity to render justice and restitution to indigenous Australians, for the good of all Australians;

(b) acknowledges the immense trauma inflicted on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of Australia as a result of the separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children from their families under past government policies in place from before the time of Federation until the early 1970s;
(c) affirms that:

PARA.TAB: (i) these racially discriminatory policies and their continuing consequences are a matter of national shame, and
(ii) current and future Federal and State Governments are responsible for assisting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to rectify the ongoing effects of those policies;

BREAK.PARA: (d) affirms its commitment to a just and proper settlement of the grievances of people adversely affected by those policies; and
(e) on behalf of the nation:

PARA.TAB: (i) unreservedly apologises to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians for the separation policies,
(ii) calls on the Federal and State Governments to establish:

TAB.TAB: (A) in consultation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, appropriate processes to provide compensation and restitution, including assistance for the reunification of families and counselling services, and
(B) appropriate education programs to enhance community awareness of the history and continuing consequences of past practices and policies of racial discrimination, and

PARA.TAB: (iii) calls on the Federal Government to declare a national day in recognition and remembrance of the great suffering which flowed from the separation policies, and to affirm Australia's commitment to justice for indigenous Australians, today and for the future."

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —This report, Bringing them home , I think is one of the most significant reports to be tabled in this parliament. I say `most significant' for two reasons: because of the truth it reveals and because of the choices that it opens up to us as the parliament of this nation in 1997.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I want to go to the truths. It is true that there were government policies, practices and laws which resulted in the forcible separation of indigenous children from their families—practices in place almost from the very first days of colonisation; policies of protection, of segregation, of merging, of absorption, and, when that did not work, policies of assimilation.

It was in the name of assimilation in the 1950s and 1960s in this country that we saw this practice of forced separation at its peak. Indigenous children were removed from their families for a range of reasons. I do not think it is appropriate to say it is all for reasons of neglect, because we know what underpins assimilation: it is that ethnocentric view that they have to be like us.

Another truth which is revealed is that these policies and practices and laws inflicted almost unbearable pain and trauma on an entire generation of indigenous Australians and their families. In this report is the truth that the plight of many indigenous Australians today is a consequence of this history. I think it is that link of understanding between the policies and the consequences which is absent from the considerations of so many Australians today on the plight of contemporary Aborigines. A lot of contemporary Australians are likely to point their finger at symptoms—symptoms of high imprisonment rates, high numbers of juvenile offenders, the level of alcoholism in indigenous communities, unemployment levels and dysfunctional families. They point their fingers at the symptoms in ignorance of the causes. And I do not say it is a wilful ignorance; I do not think it is. But it is an ignorance that is caused by our failure to tell the real history and to own the real history of our country.

It is not a black armband view of history—it is one based on truth. Truth does not require us to wallow in guilt, and Aboriginal Australians are not asking us to wallow in guilt. But truth does require us to listen and to acknowledge. When I talk about the distinction between symptoms and causes and when I talk about the way in which the impact of these policies has contributed to the plight of Aboriginal Australians today, I think there are a number of sections from this report that are really worth quoting. I start on page 227, which reminds us:
Ways of relating and ways of nurturing are passed from generation to generation.
There is confidential evidence on page 226 from a woman who says:

I am a rotten mother. My own husband even put my kids in the Home and I fought to get them back. And then I was in a relationship after that, and he even put my kids in the Home. I think I've tried to do the best I could but that wasn't good enough. Why? Because I didn't have a role model for a start.

We could spend hours referring to the poignancy and the pertinent remarks made here, but in the time available we will not be able to do that. On page 229 there is a description from a psychotherapist at the Victorian Koori Kids Mental Health Network about James's family, which includes a description of his grandmother Helen:

Helen was removed from her family at the age of four and placed in a white institution. She was not allowed contact with her parents and left the institution at 17 to work as a cook in the city. She had no family to support her and no idea of where she came from. She became pregnant very young and was unable to care adequately for any of her children as she had severe socio‐economic problems and was unable to cope because she had no model from which to develop her own parenting skills. Her partner was alcoholic and violent and she became very depressed and began to drink. As her own ability to trust and form close relationships was damaged due to her traumatic removal from her parents at such a young age with no substitute attachment figures provided, she was unable to maintain intimate long‐term relationships, her marriage broke down and all her children were placed in care by `the welfare'.

This is the link between symptoms and causes. This is the link which Australians need to make, and I hope this report really helps them to do that. The structure of this report, the detail of the history it gives to us, is very useful information. I hope our schools make great use of it as a resource document.

I said this was a most significant report because along with the truth it also reveals to us the choices. How can we listen to these stories and turn away with a cold heart? How can we forget the way in which humanity can touch humanity? Are we not parents ourselves? Are we not somebody's children? How can we deny our humanity and say, `Well, it is all their fault'? That is one of the real strengths of this report—the opportunity to listen, to acknowledge, and I think the other choice: the choice to open our hearts and to care.

As Pat Dodson said at the Reconciliation Convention yesterday, how would we feel to go home to institutions where there were no loving arms of mothers or aunts or grandfathers or basically anybody who cared? How would it affect us to grow up with that absence of intimacy and affection, the things that make us able to cope with the demands of stress and the pressures of everyday life?

BREAK.PARA: As Mick Dodson said, don't we think Aboriginal people feel pain as we do? This report is a very moving record of that pain. Apart from the deaths in custody report, this report is going to be the most moving testimony of that pain that we will ever see in this nation. I certainly hope that it is.

Let us go back to the choices. I cannot do better than the words of others from yesterday, because we have no Aboriginal representatives in this parliament; they are not here to speak for themselves. I would rather use their words. Their words were:

The truth is now on the table. The defence of ignorance is no longer available. Individual Australians are not responsible for the past actions of others. But if (we) Australians (and the parliament of Australia in 1997) fail to respond to what we now know, that will be another thing.

And these are the choices we must make. We do have important choices to make on how we respond. Yes, we must apologise. It is absolutely crucial. It costs nothing; it means so much. We should not be pre-occupied with the material, with the possible cost of compensation, but with the words—the fact that we are prepared to say them and acknowledge the fact. That is what means most to Aboriginal people and that is why federal governments and state governments have to do it. We have to open the way for forgiveness. I apologised on Monday and I do so again unreservedly in this parliament today.

Secondly, the report focuses on reparation, not compensation. I think it is important to note that because reparation involves a multitude of options which may not cost much money. I personally think that we need to set aside financial compensation. I think we need to discuss as a parliament, in consultation obviously with indigenous Australians, what form that should take. But, more than anything, I wish the best response to this report will be that people read it, that people listen, that people hear the stories and that they open up their hearts so that they can forgive us—that true reconciliation is possible and we can start a new century together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very much afraid in this parliamentary process that what we are seeing from some members of the government is in fact their own truth. It is in fact a form of revisionism. In the West Australian newspaper on Tuesday, 27 May, the member for Swan, Mr Randall, said:

SPEECH.PARA: There was a lot of wrong information about Aboriginal children being taken from their parents.

In WA he knew of many children who had been put into missions at the request of their parents because they could not care for them. "They were not stolen, they were willingly taken and cared for and educated at the request of their parents who could not look after them because of poverty," he said.

Mr Randall chose not to stand in a minute of silence in the House of Representatives because he said it was a stunt. Like Senator Kernot, I think the answer to revisionists are the words of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people themselves. So I would like to quote from a person who suffered in Western Australia whose name was known as just Millicent. She said:

They told me that my family didn't care or want me and I had to forget them. They said it was very degrading to belong to an Aboriginal family and that I should be ashamed of myself, I was inferior to whitefellas. They tried to make us act like white kids but at the same time we had to give up our seat for a whitefella because an Aboriginal never sits down when a white person is present.

Then the religion began . . . We had religion rammed down our throats from hypocrites who didn't know the meaning of the word. We used to get whipped with a wet ironing cord and sometimes had to hold other children (naked) while they were whipped, and if we didn't hold them we got another whipping. To wake us up in the morning we were sprayed up the backside with an old fashioned pump fly spray. If we complained we got more. Hurt and humiliation was a part of our every day life and we had to learn to live with it . . . My life was miserable, and I felt I was a nobody and things couldn't get any worse. But I was wrong.

While I was in first year high school I was sent out to work on a farm as a domestic. I thought it would be great to get away from the home for a while. At first it was. I was made welcome and treated with kindness. The four shillings I was payed went to the home. I wasn't allowed to keep it, I didn't care. I was never payed for the work I did at Sister Kate's so you don't miss what you didn't get, pocket money etc.

The first time I was sent to the farm for only a few weeks and then back to school. In the next holidays I had to go back. This time it was a terrifying experience, the man of the house used to come into my room at night and force me to have sex. I tried to fight him off but he was too strong.

This woman did in fact get sent back to the home she was put in and was punished for speaking those horrors. She had her mouth washed out, had her ears boxed and was beaten again. She was sent back to the farm and was raped and bashed not only by the farmer but also by one of the farmer's workers. She also says:
I ate rat poison to try and kill myself but became very sick and vomited. This meant another belting.

The awful irony for this woman was that she in fact did fall pregnant and her baby was taken away from her, just as her mother's was. Do you know what the terrible sin was that forced her and her brother to be taken into care? It was that the Protector of Aborigines and the Child Welfare Department said that they `would have a better life and future brought up as whitefellas away from our parents in a good religious environment'. She says, `Because my parents were fair in complexion, the authorities decided us kids could pass as whitefellas.' That was the reason they were put into the home. And we are still getting the revisionism.

On Monday, 26 May 1997 the headline in the same paper was, `Get‐tough bid on solvent abusers'. As Senator Kernot indicated, in Western Australia the response to the understandable problems of long-term grief, often dysfunctional families and substance abuse is to lock them up even more. Mr Day, the police minister, said:
In the ideal world it would not be treated as a criminal offence . . . but if no other opportunity was available we might need to consider dealing with it through the criminal justice system.

He favoured detention in a drying‐out facility or health centre rather than the local police station. Bully for him. What if he had just taken the time to work out what was the cause of some kids going off the rails? What if he had decided to work with the Aboriginal community to work out what the problems are if this is a health and justice problem? It is not good enough. The report itself has indicated that other countries are dealing with this in a much better way. Page 280 of the report says:

In summary, there is an international legal obligation `to repair the damage caused, awarding the victims means of rehabilitation and, where applicable, compensation or economic indemnification' . . . This obligation passes from the violating government to its successors until satisfaction has been made (Lutz 1989 page 206).

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Whilst not wishing to discount anything that Senator Margetts is saying, it is my understanding that there is an arrangement by which Senator Margetts has five minutes allocated to speak. That has been used up. Of course, the time that she is now using is at the expense of other senators in this chamber who also want to speak to it.

—Senator O'Chee, it was an informal arrangement, as I understand it, but it was not formally announced. So it is not a matter that I can actually rule on. In so far as Senator Margetts's contribution is concerned, I do not see that I have any capacity to stop her, so I will allow her to continue.

—I will not hold up the house any longer. I am not eating into anybody else's time. I believe there is a total of 60 minutes. I do not want to take any more of the Senate's time, but I do indicate that I will be supporting the opposition's amendment to this motion.
—Senator Lightfoot, do you seek leave to make a statement?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lightfoot, Sen Phillip

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make an apology.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to a statement I made earlier today. I wish to unreservedly apologise to any Australians who may have been given offence by the remarks I made. I regard all Australians, irrespective of their race or ethnic background, as being completely equal and entitled to equality of treatment without discrimination of any kind. Any views to the contrary which I may have expressed in the past I no longer hold. I respect the Aboriginal people of Australia and strongly support practical measures to address their disadvantage. I wish to make it clear that I did not intentionally wish to give offence to anyone.

DEBATE.TITLE: SEPARATION OF ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER CHILDREN FROM THEIR FAMILIES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I want to say about the report Bringing them home —it can be said without fear of contradiction—is this: this is a report the government did not want to have. In fact, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is on the public record with his views about this inquiry. Let there be no mistake: this is a report that Australia would never have had if John Howard had been the Prime Minister of Australia in 1995, which is when the former Attorney‐General, Michael Lavarch, to his eternal credit moved to have this inquiry established.

SPEECH.PARA: All indigenous people in Australia and all good and decent non-indigenous people who cherish the importance of indigenous culture know that John Howard has questioned `the practical benefits' of the inquiry and its report. The report has been sitting on the ministerial desks of this government for more than seven weeks. In that time the government, in the guise of `senior government sources', has been busily trying to white‐ant the contents of this report with a grubby campaign in the Canberra press gallery to undermine those responsible for delivering it.

The mishandling of this important report is one of the more disgraceful episodes in this government's brief history. This report has been described by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner, Mick Dodson—one of the direct targets of this government's campaign of character assassination—as the sorriest of sorry stories. He is absolutely right.

This report traces the systematic attempt by governments in this country to conduct what was one of the most comprehensive peacetime programs of social and biological engineering in the developed world. It was an Australia‐wide endeavour to sever the descent lines of indigenous identity, language, culture and spiritual belief. It was, in fact, genocide. Genocide is the deliberate extermination of an identifiable people or nation. That is precisely what the governments of this country have set out to do.

The report traces the forcible removal of thousands of indigenous children from their families in the forlorn hope the original occupants of this country would eventually be bred out. As the report states:
By the early 1960s it was clear that despite the mandatory way in which the assimilation policy had been expressed, Indigenous people were not being assimilated.

Those Aboriginal people insisted on remaining Aboriginal people—many of them—and retaining their culture and identity. Thank God they did. Discrimination by non-indigenous people and the refusal of indigenous people to surrender their lifestyle and culture were standing in the way of this process. It is not possible, as the report says, to state with any precision how many children were forcibly removed, due to the absence of official records.

When I first went to the Northern Territory, those official records were still being kept in the MLC building. I have visited the office of the Register of Wards on many occasions. The Register of Wards was known colloquially in the Northern Territory as the stud book. It was kept for many years after I arrived. I had many discussions with the staff who kept it. It was for a long time the most accurate register of Aboriginal births and deaths that was kept in the Northern Territory. But the basis on which it was established can never be forgotten. Aboriginal children, because of their colour, were removed instantly from the legal care of their parents at birth and made wards of the state, irrespective of the circumstances of the families that were involved. The report goes on:

. . . we can conclude with confidence that between one in three and one in 10 Indigenous children were forcibly removed from their families and communities in the period from approximately 1910 until 1970.

I can tell you, from very personal experience indeed, just how recently those forced removals were going on. My wife's sister was reunited last year with her daughter, and that daughter is in her early 20s. This is not ancient history we are talking about here. I simply wanted to make that point.

Her daughter was cared for, to the ignorance of her mother, by a Darwin family. She grew up in Darwin and, I might add, received a great deal of love and care in the family that she was adopted into. But she realised once she was in her teens that she was in fact Aboriginal, and she set out herself on a process of trying to find out who her mother was. As I said, they were reunited just last year, and she is now living with the Tiwi people, of her own choice, on Bathurst Island. So this is not ancient history we are talking about.

In certain regions and in certain periods, the number of children who were, to their great distress and to the distress of their parents, forcibly removed was much greater than one in 10. In that time, not one indigenous family escaped the effects of forcible removal, and this was confirmed by representatives of the Queensland and Western Australian governments in evidence to the inquiry. Most families have been affected in one or more generations by the forcible removal of one or more of their children.

The report makes it clear that it was not until the election of the Whitlam government in 1972, on a policy platform of Aboriginal self-determination, that the means existed for indigenous groups to receive funding to challenge the very high rates of removal of indigenous children. The policies of self-determination are complete anathema still to some people in this country.

I want to touch very briefly on the Prime Minister's immediate reaction to public debate on this inquiry last year. I have already quoted what he said—that he saw very little benefit from actually conducting this inquiry. But he said more. As all honourable senators know, the Prime Minister immediately leapt into print attacking `the politically correct guilt industry' and `the Aboriginal industry', declaring that Australians should not adopt a black armband view of history. He then talked about the balance sheet of history and wondered aloud about the practical benefits of this inquiry. I think the substantive nature of this inquiry and the incredibly important evidence it contains—now enshrined in perpetuity for the first time—give the lie to that.

I want to talk about that black armband view of history—which is code, as we all know, for saying that it is okay to ignore it or pretend that what happened in the past did not happen. I am not into guilt at all. I do not believe for a minute that anyone should feel personally guilty—they can if they like—about what happened in the past. But I absolutely agree with Father Frank Brennan when he said, as clearly as he always does, that it is not a question of guilt at all—and, as a Catholic priest, he should know all about that—it is a question of at least honestly owning your own history, it is a question of looking it in the face and acknowledging the truth of it. I have to say I thought at the time that, even though I am not into guilt, I would much rather wear a black armband than a blindfold.

The one thing that can be said—and I will conclude on this—about those dreadfully ill-informed and misjudged policies of the past is that at least the people who perpetrated them had some excuse. The knowledge then of the complexity and richness of Aboriginal civilisation and culture was largely unknown. The whole basis of the policy of forcibly removing children from their parents was the ignorant premise that Aboriginal people living in a traditional lifestyle were the lowest colour in the spectrum of civilisation.

I find it particularly extraordinary that Senator Lightfoot made that statement in here only half an hour ago. I welcome his apology, but I was astonished to hear him say that he no longer holds the views he held in the past. I must say there must have been some very interesting conversations that took place outside this chamber for him to repudiate what was, in real terms, the most undiluted and pure piece of racism I have heard uttered by a member of parliament in all of the time I have been a member of parliament. There must have been some talking outside this place that persuaded him that the views he held half an hour ago he no longer holds, but I welcome his apology for it.

In the 1970s I had the greatest privilege and learning experience of my life when I lived and worked for four years with the Gunardpa people in Arnhem Land as the only non-Aboriginal in the community. Two years after I arrived in the community, I barely spoke English in my normal day's activities. The thing I learnt in those four years was that that culture had a system of family relationships and religious practices that was incredibly rich and in fact equated, without any question, with any other civilisation or culture I have ever being exposed to. Perhaps that is something Senator Lightfoot should take the opportunity to have a look at first‐hand at some stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a great privilege.
—Yes, it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I add unreservedly from the Australian Greens an apology to the Aboriginal people and, in particular, to those directly and indirectly affected as the stolen generations. There is no way we can express the awful tragedy at an individual and community level this policy wrought upon the indigenous peoples of this country. There is now an opportunity for us to reconsider and move into the future with an open heart and with the recognition that that past should never again be allowed. The way we can ensure that that past never be allowed again is by continually revisiting it as part of our history, as part of Australian history, that can never again be submerged.

SPEECH.PARA: The stolen generation's saga affects every corner of this country. It affects the Aboriginal people of Tasmania as it affects the Aboriginal people elsewhere around the country. We must move beyond the period of apology, if we get there—and that is an apology unreservedly required from the elected leader of this nation, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), on behalf of the nation, to reparations as yet to be determined. It is a task for us all to undertake toward a future in which we draw strength from the unity and diversity of this nation and from the enormous wealth of this nation's indigenous peoples and their culture, and their affinity for the vast lands of Australia.

It is imperative that we make that journey. On Monday, a great opportunity was blighted by the cavilling and conditional words of the Prime Minister. It was a moment of potential, positive, historic landmarking. It was a moment that was failed by the Prime Minister. It is an opportunity that rarely comes but, nevertheless, as he will know from the response he has had nationally and not just from the meeting in Melbourne, it is incumbent on him now to find the opportunity in the near future to do what he failed to do adequately on Monday. I will be amongst the many millions of other Australians who will support him, if he rises to that moment in the near future.

For now, I support the opposition amendments. It is imperative that we move to adopt the conclusions of this report. It is important that we move to heal as best we can so this country can move forward united and proud of the path we have put a light on into the next century.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not speak because I do believe that this motion to take note of the document Bringing them home should come before us right now. I intend to vote for the amendment, as proposed by the opposition. Obviously I intend to speak at some other time on this particular matter but, as the time is late now, I intend to allow the time to vote on this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak against the amendment to the motion. There is no doubt that the amendment is good in parts and the general sentiment would be accepted by the government, but it is inappropriate to move a motion that endorses some of the recommendations of the report, Bringing them home , before people have actually had a chance to read it. We had Senator Childs standing here in question time saying he has not seen it, and yet you are asking him to vote on something he has not seen. When I asked how many senators on the opposite side had actually seen the report, one put his hand up and I saw Senator Faulkner had an annotated report. It is hardly appropriate that an amendment be moved endorsing a report that the majority have not seen.

SPEECH.PARA: As I indicated in the response I gave in tabling the document, I have already pointed out that the government has begun to develop a response and the recommendations are wide ranging. We are not trying to obfuscate on it. They cover the responsibilities of a number of governments and other organisations. The Commonwealth, state and territory governments and non-government organisations, including the churches, which are the subject of many recommendations, will need time to fully consider the report.

As I did indicate also, the report will be considered by the Commonwealth‐state Ministerial Council for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs when it meets next in August, at which point I would expect the states and territories to examine the report and provide some indication of actions they propose to take. These proposals concerning Commonwealth legislation in relation to adoption, child welfare and juvenile justice will also need to be considered by the functionally responsible ministerial councils in due course and, ultimately, the council of governments.

That amendment, for example, `calls on the federal and state governments to establish, in consultation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, appropriate processes to provide compensation, et cetera, and appropriate education programs.' They are state responsibilities. It is with that general overview that the government will be oppos ing the amendment, as I say, not to pick bits out of it but as it is inappropriate to move it at this point in time as people on the opposition side, as has been indicated, have not had a chance to digest it fully.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Faulkner's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in my name, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Margetts moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 578.

I will not speak for long on the urgency of this motion. There is very little doubt that it is urgent for those people who are encountering landmines on a daily basis in their country and having their children and themselves in daily risk of their lives or at risk of being maimed. There is no doubt that there is urgent need for Australia to have regard to the actions that have been taken by such countries as the United Kingdom. In light of the national day of action on landmines on Monday there is no doubt that this is the right and proper time for us to be debating the motion in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by Senator Margetts and her contention that this is an internationally important matter, a matter that the Senate ought to be debating. We all know the enormous toll around the world as a result of the landmine industry. It is considered so important by the new Blair government in Britain that it is one of the first matters that they have attended to. This is an extraordinarily important humanitarian impulse. I support Senator Margetts and I believe that we ought to move to debate the matter.
