PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Margetts) agreed to:
That general business notice of motion No. 578 may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business today till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) the decision by the new Labour Government in Britain to enforce a total ban on landmines by the year 2005,
(ii) that 26 May 1997 is the National Day of Action in Australia run by the Australian section of the `International Campaign to ban Landmines', and

(iii) the International Campaign is calling for the Australian Government to enforce its promised total ban on landmines by destroying Australia's own stockpile of weapons and working seriously towards a global unconditional ban; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) calls on the Government to:

PARA.TAB: (i) destroy its stockpile of anti-personnel landmines,
(ii) take a leading role globally to ensure landmines are banned, and
(iii) pursue a ban through the pro-ban country forum known as the Ottawa process.

SPEECH.PARA: I will outline the reason I have moved this motion. The British government announced a total ban on landmines by the year 2005—not just a partial ban but one that includes a ban on detectable and self‐destructible mines as well. The British move, unfortunately, still has an out clause until the year 2005 where landmines could be used in a combat situation, when deemed essential to winning a conflict. The British move is part of the British Labour Party's election pledge to review British arms trade policies in terms of their consequences for human rights. The decision on landmines has been their first real announcement. What will be interesting and crucial to watch is whether they cancel the contract between British Aerospace and the Indonesian government for 16 Hawk jets and armoured tankers. That we will wait for.

Australia had a very successful national day of action on Monday, 26 May 1997 with the public stepping on landmine stickers that they can peel off their shoes. The stickers read, `Your leg has just been blown off by a landmine.' They proceed to state the facts about the number of people killed or maimed by landmines each year. They state the manufacturers, the countries affected and what states can do to reverse the scourge.

One hundred million landmines are currently deployed in over 60 countries and the US estimates that they kill or maim over 25,000 people, mainly civilians, every year. The national day of action was organised by the International Campaign to Ban Landmines. Australian coordinator, Sister Patricia Pak Poy, has said that Australia coming out in favour of a total ban on antipersonnel landmines, with a suspension on operational use, has not been enough. The international campaign wants Australian to act more consistently, first by destroying our own stockpile of the weapons and, secondly, by working seriously towards a global, unconditional ban.

BREAK.PARA: In October 1996 the Australian government sent a delegation to a pro‐ban conference in Ottawa where it pledged to work towards having a ban treaty in place as soon as possible. Canada has suggested it be by the end of 1997 and at least 50 countries have pledged to have a ban treaty in place by next January. However, since the Ottawa conference Australia has backed away and is now joining the United States, which prefers a slower approach through the Conference on Disarmament, CD, at the UN.

The landmines movement is split between those who favour the slow approach through the CD and those pro‐ban countries which want action and are prepared to take voluntary measures to implement a ban as soon as possible. Having 50 nations on board is no mean feat and a number of key CD states, such as the US, the UK and France, have stated their support for CD negotiations, arguing that that would be a slower approach but would include most of the world's important mine producers and users, especially China, India, Pakistan and Russia; as well as staunch opposers of the ban such as Israel, South Korea and Turkey.

However, bringing landmines into the Conference on Disarmament, a forum for nuclear and conventional arms negotiation, brings with it its own problems. If the landmines issue becomes part of the Conference on Disarmament agenda, it will be used in trade‐offs between nuclear and conventional topics. Countries in the non‐aligned movement believe antipersonnel mines would be used to overshadow negotiations on nuclear issues, a development that the non‐aligned movement and countries that are seriously working for nuclear disarmament are desperate to avoid.

Again, this leaves the Ottawa process as one where Australia, as a pro‐ban nation, could express its real support for a total ban on landmines. Lip service from Australia is not enough. Although Australia suspended operational use in April 1996, Australia continues to maintain a stockpile of antipersonnel landmines, despite declaring its support for a ban. Australia must now take further action to destroy the rest of its landmines stockpile.
I am calling for support for two things today. I am asking that the Senate notes:
. . . the decision by the new Labour Government in Britain to enforce a total ban on landmines by the year 2005 . . .
That is not difficult to do. I am also asking that the Senate notes:
. . . that 26 May 1997 is the National Day of Action in Australia run by the Australian section of the `International Campaign to ban Landmines'. . .
That is not a problem. Of course, 26 May is the day notice was given. I am further asking the Senate to note that:

. . . the International Campaign is calling for the Australian Government to enforce its promised total ban on landmines by destroying Australia's own stockpile of weapons and working seriously towards a global unconditional ban . . .
The action part of this motion is that the Senate:
. . . calls on the Government to:

PARA.TAB: (i) destroy its stockpile of anti-personnel landmines,
(ii) take a leading role globally to ensure landmines are banned, and
(iii) pursue a ban through the pro-ban country forum known as the Ottawa process.

BREAK.PARA: There is a very large level of support for this action in Australia, and I urge the Senate to support my motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor opposition is pleased to support this motion. Labor has repeatedly called upon the Howard government to agree to the unilateral destruction of Australia's large stockpile of antipersonnel landmines, with exemptions only for the absolute minimum of stocks to allow the Australian Defence Force to continue effective mine clearance training. Senator Margetts's motion does not refer to this minimal exception, but we are sure senators recognise it as a necessity if the ADF is to continue its very valuable role in support of ongoing mine clearance work around the world.

SPEECH.PARA: Destruction of Australia's landmine stockpile is a measure which has also received bipartisan support from the majority of mem bers of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties. It is, consequentially, a matter of great regret that the government is unable to agree to the unilateral destruction of the stockpile. Public destruction of the stockpile would contribute significantly to the development of an international consensus that landmines are not a legitimate weapon of war—a vital foundation for the negotiation of a global ban.

Conversely, as the coordinator of the Australian network of the international campaign to ban landmines—Sister Patricia Pak Poy—said on Monday, `It is unconscionable for Australia to maintain its stockpile of landmines while declaring its support for a global ban.' As Sister Pak Poy has said, we simply cannot pay lip‐service to a ban and continue to maintain a stockpile of these weapons for possible operational use. We must start destroying them. Labor will continue to take every opportunity to press the Howard government to do the right thing on this vital humanitarian issue. The opposition will continue to urge the government to take a positive approach to the so‐called Ottawa process. This Canadian initiative for the conclusion of a ban between like‐minded pro‐ban countries by the end of this year has great potential to give a major boost to the efforts to achieve a global ban through negotiations in the Conference on Disarmament. It deserves Australia's wholehearted support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will also be supporting this motion on landmines. We supported this stand throughout the last government and this government. If senators look at the report of the treaties committee when we looked into our treaties involving landmines, one of the recommendations we made—there was some dissent but very little—was that we should look at destroying our stockpile. I believe we should destroy our stockpile, except for those few mines we would need for training people in destroying landmines.

SPEECH.PARA: That is something we have been pushing for all along, and it is something that the treaties committee has also said that it would like to see. That is something that is in this motion. The treaties committee called on the government to do the same thing. Destroying our stockpile of antipersonnel landmines—except, as I say, for those few training ones—is a very good move and one that we should take immediately. I believe that is what the British government has already said that they are about to do, which is excellent.

We should be taking a leading role globally, to ensure that landmines are banned, and we have always believed that. We should be pursuing a ban through the pro‐ban country forum known as the Ottawa process. Canada has taken a leading role on this and has done a lot of work on this, and we should be supporting Canada in this. I do not understand why we are not. It is not as if we have antipersonnel landmines as any integral part of what we might need to defend this country. We could not do it. It is just a silly argument. We do not have enough to defend ourselves with them. There is no reason for us to have them.

All that antipersonnel landmines do is keep fighting after the war is over. They are the only little soldiers who do not understand that the war is finished. The vast majority of people who are injured, killed and destroyed for life—whether they are dead or not—are the people who go out into the fields. They are children, women, farmers and people who are non‐combatant. The vast majority of people who are affected by antipersonnel landmines in the world today are non‐combatants.

There is absolutely no reason why we should maintain our large stockpile of antipersonnel landmines. There is no reason why we should not take a leading role in getting rid of these vicious, useless, abhorrent weapons, and there is no reason why we should not be supporting Canada in the Ottawa process in the pro‐ban country forum. They are doing a very good job on this. Landmines are one of the most iniquitous weapons still available in the world today. Everybody thought they had disappeared, but they have come back with a gigantic, spectacular, appalling vengeance and are carrying out that vengeance to an incredibly large extent on innocent people all over the world even as we speak. Of course they should go, of course we should take a leading role in their going and of course we will support this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as one of the few parliamentarians in Canberra who unfortunately have personally experienced the horrors of war. I know about landmines. I have seen the effects they have on machinery, equipment and vehicles; I have seen the effect they have on people; I have seen the effect they have had on animals; and I have experienced them personally. This is an issue which is right. Its time is right. The arguments are clearly understood. Landmines are not like bullets. As soon as the bullet is fired, its work is done. Landmines go on year after year, sometimes decade after decade, and they move from the combatant and non‐combatant field to the purely non‐combatant field.

SPEECH.PARA: I add my personal plea that the Senate accord with this motion. I would remind senators that what we are talking about here, in my view, should be cross‐party agreement on an issue which matters fundamentally to humanity. It is my view that what we require from the government in this issue yet again is some political will, some political leadership and some political courage. This is a government which is very outspoken on economic matters. It is time you started to be outspoken on human rights and fundamental issues of peace in our world.

I therefore add my voice to those who call for a total ban on landmines and the immediate destruction by the government of its stockpile of antipersonnel landmines. The government should take a leading role globally to ensure that landmines are banned and it should support the Ottawa process.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not support the motion. The government does support a global ban on the production, stockpiling, use and transfer of antipersonnel landmines and the unilateral suspension on the operational use of antipersonnel landmines by the Australian defence forces. The government supports the Conference on Disarmament as the negotiating principal forum for a global ban.

BREAK.PARA: The government is currently leading a major push to start negotiations in this forum. The Conference on Disarmament has proved that it can produce treaties which are comprehensive in scope and which can achieve the adherence of all relevant states—for example, the Chemical Weapons Convention and the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. The government is also participating in the series of Ottawa process meetings this year and hopes this process will prove complementary to work in the Conference on Disarmament.

The government is also focusing on tackling the humanitarian disaster caused by landmines. The calls for destruction of Australian stockpiles are, in this context, somewhat misplaced, because the Australian Defence Force stocks are used for training and research purposes only, notably for the training which has been essential to enable our army engineers to participate in mine clearance programs—for example, in Cambodia. Senator Carr and Senator Bourne both made reference to this.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't need thousands and thousands.

—I got that interjection, Senator Murray, but I refer you to the motion which talks about destroying the stockpile of antipersonnel landmines. It makes no provisions whatsoever for landmines which will be required for the training purposes which are so essential. The suspension in the operational use of antipersonnel landmines by the ADF is indefinite and would be reviewed only in the case of substantial deterioration in our strategic circumstances in which Australia's security was under threat and the denial of an anti‐personnel landmines capability of the ADF would result in additional Australian casualties and damage to vital infrastructure.

BREAK.PARA: The government continues to give priority to those measures which will make the great est practical difference to the victims of the misuse of landmines. The total Australian contribution to the de‐mining process announced since March 1996 is $18 million, and it makes Australia a world leader in the de‐mining process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank senators for their contributions in this very important debate. I would like to say something to Senator Parer about stockpiling. There are people who are still concerned about training. Some people think the implications are that we could still use landmines for training in the placing of landmines. It is not as clear as it could be that the training is only for de‐mining purposes. There is still a concern within the community that training might be for a future need to show our military how to put them out. But a few hundred landmines to be used in terms of de‐mining training does not, in my opinion, constitute a stockpile. A stockpile, from my understanding, is what we have at the moment—which is a very large number of landmines—and I do not think there is ever an excuse to hold onto those just in case we might need them. That is clearly what this motion is saying and clearly what the speakers have said today.

SPEECH.PARA: The issues are human issues. If anything other than the strongest approach is considered to be acceptable, members of the government should speak in as much detail as they can to those people who are currently experiencing the horror of living the uncertainty in a country where they cannot farm their own land, live in their houses or understand whether they are going to survive the day.

It is extremely urgent, it is extremely important. If the government can move just this step further in relation to its own policies it would find that it had a great deal of support within the Australian community and, indeed, the international community. What was considered to be a hopelessly utopian approach just a couple of years ago by the former minister is now gaining huge international support. So here is the chance for this government to act with strength and with a real level of honour in relation to what we would like to see in the world in the future. It should not ever be seen as a matter of military strategy. It is those people who know most about military strategy who know about the lunacy of continuing to use land mines. But it is not just a matter of military strategy; it is a matter of taking strong and right action and taking it now. I urge the Senate's support for this motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TITLE.XREF: AUSTRALIA NEW ZEALAND FOOD AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Parer) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Act 1991.
Motion (by Senator Parer) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

This bill makes a number of technical and minor policy amendments to the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Act 1991. These amendments proposed in this bill support this Government's regulatory reform agenda as they help the Authority take control of its business and prioritise its agenda.

The Australia New Zealand Food Authority is a Commonwealth statutory authority which develops uniform food standards for Australia and New Zealand and undertakes related functions. It operates under a unique Commonwealth, New Zealand, State and Territory partnership arrangement based upon a 1991 cooperative agreement in Australia and a 1995 treaty with New Zealand. These arrangements see standards, developed through the Authority's statutory processes, uniformly adopted by reference and without amendment into State, Territory and New Zealand laws.

The amendments seek to facilitate the cooperative arrangement between the governments and at the same time, retain the community consultation, accountability, openness, transparency and timeliness which characterise the Authority's operations. They give the Authority greater flexibility in its operations, simply and clarify its procedures, and confer powers appropriate to a modem statutory authority.

These amendments have a long history. They have been proposed in a number of internal and external reviews of the Authority's processes over a number of years. While they are essentially administrative house-keeping, they are important in giving effect to this government's commitment to its regulatory reform agenda.

The reforms in this bill, while relatively minor, will smooth the way for the Authority as it undertakes its important regulatory reform program over the next few years. The amendments are about simplicity and clarity. They are about flexibility and modem management. They streamline, and replace prescription with guidance. They support better government. These are matters which this government will continue to hold dear.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the Spring sittings, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend general business notice of motion No. 584 standing in my name for today before asking that it be taken as a formal motion.
—Is leave granted?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: HARRADINE

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then, Sir, pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of standing orders be suspended as would—

TALK.START.PARA: —One moment, Senator Brown. Could I clarify something with Senator Harradine? You objected to the amendment of the motion, or to the motion being formal?
—Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator Brown sought leave to amend his motion.
—Yes.
—I denied leave.
—That's correct. I just wanted confirmation of that. Thank you.
—The reason that I denied leave was that, in my view, if I may seek leave to—
—You really do not have to explain. The denial of leave is your right, Senator.
—I would like to explain to the chamber.
—If you wish to make an explanation, I will have to ask you to seek leave also.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to explain why I did it.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion that is on the Notice Paper Senator Brown seeks to amend, as I understand it, in a fairly substantial manner. My office was notified of this a couple of hours or so ago. But I have been engaged in other things. I have not had a chance to look at it. I think honourable senators who are placing notices of motion before the chamber should give other senators the chance of having a look at matters that come before the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: This whole practice of giving notice one day and trying to get the matter formal the next day or the day after that or the day after that is becoming a farce. I believe that these notices of motion and the motions that are going through this parliament like a sausage machine are devaluing the decisions of the Senate. People are just getting up here and giving notices of motion. I think there were 10 or so notices of motion given today.

I suppose I could spend all my time looking at these notices of motion and judging whether or not the motions should be adopted or whether they should not be adopted, but I have more to do with my time than that because there is legislation coming before this parliament. The major function of this parliament is to consider legislation. It is getting a bit rough when it comes down to individual senators such as me very often deciding whether these motions are adopted or whether they are not. I am getting to the stage now where I think I will not vote on any of them; I will just walk out of the chamber until such time as people have the decency to realise that, if they continue piling up the Notice Paper with notices of motion, they can have it on their own.

I am not denying that many of these things are very important issues. The last one was of considerable importance and it had been of considerable interest to me for a considerable period of time. But, fair crack of the whip! I and my very hard‐working staff are overloaded at this time. We get people coming along with these notices of motion on all sorts of things, asking that they be called formal. Therefore, one does not have the chance to consider the opposing argument to the particular proposition. These matters are not, therefore, dealt with on their merits, because the government and the opposition have got their policies on it. They have huge resources to say whether or not these motions fit within their policies. I do not.

I remind you again that many times these matters, unfortunately, have to come down to my vote. It may well be that one needs to just absent oneself if one is not in a position to have been fully informed about the issues concerned.

This is just over the fence. Just before Senator Brown sought to ask that his motion be made formal, he came into this chamber and sought leave to amend the motion. As I said, I have not had a chance to even look at the amended motion. I think that is just over the fence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Objection having been raised, pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Brown moving a motion relating to the conduct of business of the Senate, namely, a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 584.
I do that because Senator Harradine might say that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Brown, the objection was to your amendment, not to the calling of your motion formal. You are proceeding on the basis that the formal part of your motion has been challenged.
—I ask that the motion as it stands be taken as formal.
—Is there any objection to this motion being taken as formal?
—There is an objection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Brown moving a motion relating to the conduct of business in the Senate, namely, a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 584.

To me this is an extremely important motion. We have a leader of the Ogoni people from Nigeria, Komene Famaa, in this city and in this parliament today. We have 19 of his fellow Ogoni people languishing in a gaol in Nigeria facing summary execution. Ken Saro-Wiwa, an outspoken leader of the Ogoni people, and seven of his fellow community leaders were summarily executed, even while the CHOGM meeting took place in New Zealand two years ago.

This motion is an appeal to the Senate to give some impetus to Australia's need to stand with the Ogoni people against the Abacha regime military dictatorship in Nigeria which has these 19 Ogoni leaders existing in despicable conditions in gaol with the threat of summary execution over their heads simply because they have stood up for democracy, social justice and the environment of their homeland.

Senator Harradine says that we should have the decency not to bring forward such motions. What an extraordinary contribution to the national discourse. What a call to deny issues as we elected representatives see them being brought into this Senate for proper debate. Senator Harradine has the temerity to say that he wants to get on with the government schedule—that is, to consider legislation.

I have news for Senator Harradine. He is not going to set my agenda. He is not going to eliminate from the agenda of this Senate the matters which the people whom I represent in this Australian and Tasmanian constituency feel are important. He might have his schedule dictated by the Howard government, but the Greens are not going to because there is much more to the national interest and to the Tasmanian interest—and, indeed, as in this case, to the international interest—than would be set by the very constrictive, arch-conservative view of the Howard government.

It may be that Senator Harradine is stressed by the workload. I empathise with him there. But if he had spoken to me, he would have known that I am happy to make a joint approach to the government that we do get the adequate staffing to enable him to deal with the same workload that I am dealing with.

In the meantime, I make an appeal to the Senate to consider the urgency of this matter. We have another Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting coming up in Britain a little way down the line. It is important that Australia makes a very clear stand on this in the coming months as an indication to the Commonwealth of nations that there is an international obligation to take it up to the Abacha regime—this cruel dictatorship in Nigeria, responsible to no-one. Unfortunately, it is a place used to doing business with the Shell oil corporation. It has caused so much of the opposition from the Ogoni people because it is their homeland that Shell has been operating in.

Seeing there has been no action by the Abacha regime to do the right thing for the Ogoni people, hopefully we will see a stand at the Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting to expel that regime from the Commonwealth and to move our Australian consulate to one of the west African countries which have a more decent view, to use Senator Harradine's adjective, of the way human affairs should be conducted.

So it is an urgent matter. I ask the Senate to endorse it and to give Mr Famaa, as he continues his tour of this country, moral support that he can send back home to the Ogoni people, in particular to those 19 patriots of the Ogoni people who are languishing in General Abacha's cruel, inhumane prison conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will not be supporting the suspension of standing orders. While Senator Brown is canvassing obviously very significant issues, there is a question of priority in terms of the availability of time that we have to deal with the business before the Senate.

BREAK.PARA: The opposition has business here today as well, and we are anxious to proceed to it, and that is issues relating to the Australian automotive industry. I think it is important that Senator Brown tries to sort these things out outside, where possible. Under normal circumstances I could understand why he may wish to proceed in the way he has, but tonight I am afraid there is simply not sufficient time to do the work that he is seeking of us and I think there are higher priorities at this particular hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe this is urgent. I believe that the urgency of the car industry obviously is important, but I would like to say it was the Labor government who pushed through the Uruguay Round of GATT and the implications of tariff reductions and they did not think it was urgent then. So I am very pleased to see they now see industry policy as urgent and that issues involving human beings and their jobs are urgent in relation to tariffs, but I could not get them to see that as urgent in terms of those issues when they were pushing through the Uruguay Round of GATT despite the warnings of many people in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: But the urgency today relates to especially paragraph 5(b), which calls on the Senate President to write to the British Secretary of State and Community Affairs expressing the Senate's grave concern about the treatment of the Ogoni people. Just maybe that will save the lives of those 19 Ogoni people facing execution. That is something that we as a Senate can do.

I urge those people who are here to think about it themselves. If the Senate is unable to consider that this is urgent enough for us to call on the Senate President to do this, perhaps there is some other means by which the Senate can sign a letter to do this. Maybe we could take this opportunity, if the Labor Party do actually believe this is important, to circulate a letter amongst members of the Senate to sign—maybe even some members of the government who believe it is important will sign it as well—and just maybe we will be able to save these people's lives. If that is not urgent, I cannot think of many other things that are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that what Senator Brown is doing I can only charitably call grandstanding. I simply raised the point that I had not even looked at the amended motion. I had not even had a chance to look at it. He comes in here and accuses me of not being interested in the human rights of the Ogoni people, and I object to that. I happen to be on the human rights subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.
—Very able.

—Thank you, Senator Bourne. As Senator Bourne would know, we spend hour after hour on these issues of human rights. In fact, today the committee saw the representative of the Ogoni people. I was not able to be there because a matter being dealt with this morning came down to my vote, unfortunately. But let me say this to Senator Brown: the real work for the human rights of people, including the Ogoni people, is done in the human rights subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Obviously I could not give away that particular commitment. I do not intend to because I believe it is very important to have that commitment to human rights.

SPEECH.PARA: I reject entirely what Senator Brown has said with regard to staff. It is all very well for him. He and Senator Margetts may cover a lot, but I am on my own covering the all the portfolios and all of the matters that come before this chamber. It is just impossible to be across all of these motions that come up without time being given for people to look at them. We are asked to declare them formal when we cannot hear the debate for and against.

On this occasion I am simply saying that I have not been able to even look at the amendment. What is wrong with having this matter come before us tomorrow, when we will have had a chance to look at it? The decision that we make today will not make any difference, frankly, unfortunately, to the Nigerian government or Shell.

BREAK.PARA: My worry, again—and I will repeat it—is that too many motions being put through this chamber formally on the nod really does devalue the strength of those decisions. It is very important that these matters are dealt with by the various committees including, as I said, the committee that has been established jointly by the Senate and the House of Representatives to deal with these matters; namely, the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and its human rights subcommittee.

I do not think it is going to make any difference if we give ourselves 24 hours to look at the matter. Therefore, I am voting against Senator Brown's motion to have this matter dealt with before any other matter in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, the honourable senator has just said that he would be amenable to this matter being dealt with tomorrow. So would I, if it is going to—
—Is this a point of order, Senator Brown?
—This is. I ask your indulgence, seeing there is a consensus on that, in assisting me, if that is what the Senate will do, to have the matter brought before the Senate tomorrow.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —You will have to resubmit the motion to comply with the standing orders, because it was raised today and it was declared not formal. This motion for the suspension of the standing orders is operative only for today. I am advised that you will have to move the suspension of standing orders again tomorrow to comply with standing orders.

Is the proposal supported?
More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clock accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency;

The need to secure the future of the Australian automotive industry and create an environment which supports a doubling of motor vehicle exports to 100,000 units per year, a trebling of components exports to $3 billion and up to 10,000 new jobs, by establishing a post 2000 assistance regime which:
(a) freezes tariffs on motor vehicles, original equipment and replacement components at 15% to at least 2005 (while maintaining our commitments under APEC),
(b) establishes a transparent measure by which the progress of our trading partners in reducing their tariff and non-tariff barriers can be judged.

(c) reviews the industry's position in 2003 to determine the assistance needed beyond 2005. (In formulating its recommendations, the review to have regard to the progress of our trading partners in reducing barriers to trade and the impact of any policy changes on regional Australia.)
(d) continues the Export Facilitation Scheme, modified as necessary to be consistent with our WTO obligations.
(e) continues the duty-free allowance to support domestic market value-added.
(f) provides measures which ensure a more supportive industrial research and development environment.

The car industry in Australia is the cornerstone of Australia's entire manufacturing sector. Our manufacturing industries are built around the fact that this country has a viable car manufacturing industry and in one way or another in the traditional sense most of our manufacturing sector relates in some form to that industry.

Australia makes good cars and Australians drive cars made in Australia, in the majority. Our cars these days are of high quality, often of Australian design and increasingly competitive in price. This is a good industry for this nation. It employs directly and indirectly 295,000 people both in the car manufacturing companies themselves—the big four, as they are known—and in the 200 component part manufacturers that supply equipment to the car manufacturers themselves.

It is an industry that has the potential to create another 10,000 jobs in this nation by the year 2005. It is an export industry for Australia, too. Exports have increased for this industry from almost zero 15 years ago to something close to $1 billion these days. It is an industry that attracts investment. Under the last several years of the Labor administration of this country, Toyota invested $800 million in new plant at Altona. General Motors Holden's has invested over $260 million. Mitsubishi put in an investment of $600 million and Ford announced a commitment of a $1 billion investment in this nation.

This motion is about giving this vital and central industry to Australia certainty about its future—certainty so that it can be kept growing, certainty so that it can be kept exporting and certainty so that it can be kept in Australia. This motion gives this chamber a simple choice: we can vote for or against the Australian automotive industry, the companies involved and the jobs they represent.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you read the motion that was contained in my letter. Outside of the chamber and earlier today senators approached me. I want to change some of the provisions that are in that letter to make it more effective and more representative. I thank the Australian Democrats in particular for expressing their views to me in this way, expressly Senator Murray. Under paragraph (a) of my letter I would like to eliminate the paragraph and replace it with the following paragraph:
(a) ensures that tariffs on motor vehicles, original equipment and replacement components should not fall below 15% at least until 2005 (while maintaining our commitments under APEC).
I want to remove the sentence in paragraph (d) and replace it with the following sentence:
(d) ensures that the Export Facilitation Scheme is not removed without putting in place a program of equivalent value, consistent with our World Trade Organization obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook, are you seeking leave to amend your motion?
—I am seeking leave to amend my motion in those terms.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to take the 10 minutes allotted to me this evening, because I do believe that it is vital that the chamber come to a decision on this urgency motion tonight. The issues about the Australian car industry are well known. It is important, though, that the Senate speak to this urgency motion today.

BREAK.PARA: We in the Labor Party have consulted widely in this industry, something we have continued doing in opposition as we did in government, and we have announced a plan for the future development of the Australian automotive industry. It is a plan which involves a freeze on tariffs at at least 15 per cent until the year 2005. It is a plan which involves a review of the industry's position to determine the assistance needed beyond 2005, taking into full account, of course, the impact on regional Australia and the progress of our trading partners in their reducing their barriers to trade. It is a plan which involves the continuation of the export facilitation scheme, or a similar such effective scheme, of the duty‐free allowance and of more support for research and development.

We have put down this plan, made it public and attracted widespread community support—support from workers in the industry and support from the industry itself. Indeed, industry has responded to the points we have raised by saying that, if such a plan were adopted in Australia, it would double the amount of motor vehicle exports to 100,000 units within the time span of our plan; it would triple the component part exports of the automotive industry to lift it to the value of at least $3 billion; and 10,000 new jobs would be created.

We have called for a bipartisan approach to this industry so that the future of this industry will not be determined every three years, parliament to parliament; so that there is a long distance perspective; and so that the industry can plan its restructure effectively so it remains world competitive and a viable exporter. The response to our approach has been overwhelming from industry, as I have said, from state governments and from the community. But I believe, and so does the ALP, that the federal government needs to be forced to act on this issue. The Howard government flip‐flops around on it. Most recently, the Treasurer, Mr Costello, over cigars and port at the Commonwealth Club, asked the question, `Why don't we just let Mitsubishi go?' That is a terrible position of neglect of this industry. I commend this motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Gibson, I understand informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times for each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I ask the clerks to set the clock accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the government to oppose the motion proposed by Senator Cook. It is amazing, really, that a former minister, a minister in a previous government and who knows proper process, should bring forward this urgency motion today about the car industry and the future of tariffs in the car industry when he knows the matter is going through proper process—when he and the Labor opposition know that the Industry Commission is due to report this week or thereabouts and that the matter has not yet been considered by cabinet nor by the party and is going to go through proper process.

SPEECH.PARA: This is nothing but a political stunt. This is not a debate for or against the car industry. All of us here are in support of the car industry in Australia. In fact, quite a few of us on the back bench have been around visiting the plants in recent times and are very appreciative of the work that they have done in lifting their game, improving their efficiency and exporting out of Australia. They are continuing to do that. We cannot debate that here tonight. Tonight we are really talking about process. This is nothing but a stunt brought forward by Senator Cook. It is really a waste of time.
I would like to remind the Senate of the reference that was given by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) to the Industry Commission late last year. The reference is this:

. . . the Government's desire to encourage the development of a sustainable, prosperous and internationally competitive automotive manufacturing industry in Australia; to improve the overall economic performance of the Australian automotive industry; to provide good quality, competitively priced vehicles to the Australian consumer; and its commitment to abide by Australia's international obligations and commitments.
He further suggested:

. . . the Commission consider how the Australian automotive industry will evolve within a world trading environment through the next decade, and that the Commission consider APEC developments on market liberalisation, and the timing and extent of cost reductions from other microeconomic reforms.
The government has not made any policy decision on this matter and will not do so—and cannot do so—until the Industry Commission delivers its final report, which is expected later this week.

The government is determined to provide a stable policy environment in which the automotive companies can undertake major investment decisions with confidence. The Productivity Commission is but one source of advice on this matter, and the government is consulting widely, particularly through the Automotive Manufacturing Council, as part of its policy development process.

In establishing arrangements for the automotive industry after the year 2000, the government will consider a range of factors affecting the structure of the industry, including the strong growth in import penetration over recent years, the actions of competitor countries and, most importantly, the progress of the Australian industry itself towards developing a global niche.

I note that Labor leaders favour a pause in tariffs and a review prior to resuming their reductions while also insisting that we maintain our commitments to APEC—which, after all, we are locked into by former Prime Minister Keating. I would like to ask senators opposite to outline how these contradictory objectives can be achieved. They might care to indicate how certainty can be maintained for the purposes of planning investments in the industry. They might also specify the modifications they think necessary to ensure that the export facilitation scheme remains consistent with our WTO obligations.

BREAK.PARA: Within the opposition there is quite a range of views. I will quote from some statements made by Mr Lindsay Tanner. He said:

However, we must avoid becoming economically irrational, lapsing into mindless populism, recycling the policies of the 1950s and defining ourselves by what we don't like. If we adopt such a stance we will be virtually indistinguishable from Pauline Hanson on economic issues. We should not delude ourselves that there is no link between her virulent racism and economic nostalgia. The two are very closely related, and difficult to separate.
He further warns:
`There is a danger, however, that Labor will allow tariffs to resume the unduly dominant role they played in industry policy in the past.
`We cannot . . . return to the 1970s.
Again there is a serious risk that Labor will become a prisoner of the populist nostalgia such as that peddled by Pauline Hanson. It confirms the deep divisions within the Labor Party.
Last Saturday night on the Science Show, John Button, a previous Labor minister for industry, was quizzed about policy. He said:

I mean, people talk about what the Government should do about industry policy. I don't think the Government should do very much about industry policy. What it should do a lot about . . . in a country this size, is strategic policy, you know, thinking about strategies for wealth generation, community development and so on, in the next decade—not now.
I repeat, `strategies for wealth generation, community development and so on in the next decade'.

What have we as a government done? First of all, before we can say anything about our achievements in getting wealth generation and the development of the Australian economy under way, we need to remind the Senate and listeners where we have come from. What happened with the previous Keating government? Taxes were up 30 per cent in the last four years of the Keating government. Debt was up $70 billion in the last four years of the Keating government. There was $9 billion worth of assets realised. The whole lot was spent. Because all this was hiding behind the facade of cash accounting, the community were not made aware of this huge build-up in debt.

So when we came to government last year we inherited a deficit—a loss, in other words—from the previous government of $10.3 billion. We have set in train via the budget process—through the second budget and forward estimates for next year—a situation where we expect to be in surplus by $1.6 billion at the end of the financial year after this one.

There has been a huge turnaround in Commonwealth government activity. Instead of big spending, creating debt and cutting down on savings, we have turned that all around and are indicating that we are going to be in surplus. Hence the government will be a saver.

What has happened as a consequence of that? We have had a huge change in the interest rate regime in Australia. Not only has the short-term rate come down enormously, but so has the long‐term rate. The 10‐year bond rate has come down; the whole lot has come down. On top of that again, the risk premium on 10‐year bonds relative to the USA was 2½ per cent 2½ years ago in the middle of the Keating regime. It is down about one per cent now, so we are regarded by the world as a much less risky place.

We are on about encouraging sustained economic growth in order to get investment. We need the investment to sustain the economic growth—that is where the jobs come from. Recent results have shown that there has been a big growth in investment in the last 12 months. We are on about sustaining that.

The government is committed. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has made a commitment to look urgently at the matter of assistance for and cooperation with the car industry. We are great supporters of the car industry, as all Australians are, and we disagree with Senator Cook's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gibson, when I was young, there were always concerns about finding communists under your bed. The conservatives always said, `Look out for the communists. They've got different ideas from ours.' Now they say, `Look out for the populists and the interventionists.' I respect your views more than that cheap and easy way to get rid of those who disagree with you.

SPEECH.PARA: I also accept that you are not a naive person. The reason the Senate wishes to put pressure on the government at this stage—and quite properly Labor has introduced this motion—is that we have the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries in a large group in the parliament applying as much pressure as it can on the parliamentarians.

The second thing is that we know that the Productivity Commission report is out and is to be considered by cabinet. It is our view that the report should not remain secret. Quite frankly, we think it might be useful if the cabinet did not make their decision until the report was out and debated. I am aware that six of the last seven Productivity Commission reports have been dealt with in just that way—they have been put out in the open.

I also say to you, Senator Gibson, that you have been forced to defend the government's position when those on the coalition side themselves are very split on this issue, as you know. There have been public statements from large numbers of coalition members supporting essentially what Labor is proposing. I am very used to expressing a minority opinion. I have just heard you express one, too, but this time you should join together with us.
Speaking to the motion: I appreciate your amending your motion, Senator Cook, to accord with our interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wishes.

—We do not deal with each other as you two deal with each other, Senator McGauran. The Australian Democrats are strongly opposed to the speed and depth of the cuts in tariffs, quotas and bounties which have been to date enthusiastically advocated and implemented with the support of both of Australia's large parties and the minor National Party. These cuts have gone well beyond what Australia is obliged to do under the World Trade Organisation, and they have been undertaken without similar measures by our trading partners, who continue to protect their industries by keeping out Australian manufactured products.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the useful things this government has done through its Minister for Trade, Mr Fischer, is pay far more attention to bilateral arrangements as opposed to multilateral arrangements. Bilateral arrangements do mean paying attention to what individual trading partners are up to.

Australian manufacturers and workers have deliberately been placed at a disadvantage to overseas employers operating with strong tariff and non-tariff assistance. Both of Australia's major parties finally agree that tariffs should only be reduced in future on a quid pro quo basis. Yet unilateral tariff reductions are still legislated until the year 2000 for the two major industries affected by tariffs, industries which directly employ tens of thousands of Australians.

The rate of tariff assistance for the car industry is set to fall from the present 22½ per cent to 15 per cent by the year 2000. These reductions are set to take place irrespective of what our trading partners do and irrespective of their impact on employment and investment in Australia. Our view is simple. If it is not acceptable to have unilateral reductions after the year 2000, why on earth is it acceptable to have them now?

The parliament is now preparing to decide tariff rates beyond the year 2000 for the car industry. The major parties have indicated that tariff reductions on a nothing for nothing basis are not good enough after the year 2000. We welcome this announcement—the Democrats are pleased with that—but we believe we can and we should go further.

Our position, and it has been so for many a year, is that tariff cuts should cease immediately. Australia must no longer proceed with tariff reductions further than what is required under multilateral and bilateral agreements unless our trading partners do likewise and also address their use of non-tariff barriers. So‐called unilateral disarmament must cease immediately, not just after the year 2000 as the ALP is advocating and as the coalition has suggested.

BREAK.PARA: The fact is that the programmed tariff cuts from December 1996 to the year 2000 will cost $2 billion in lost revenue, so the government will forgo $2 billion which it would otherwise have earned. We believe that, if tariffs were frozen, the resultant saving should be ploughed into industrial development programs targeted at generating jobs and export opportunities. So we are not suggesting that the money should not be put to a good economic purpose.

I point out, however, that we do not believe tariff reductions are inherently either a good thing or a bad thing. It is the unilateral reduction, without equivalent cuts by our major trading competitors, which permanently damages Australia's interests.

The government has been engaged in trade liberalisation negotiations and should continue with that. However, further trade reductions must only occur if reciprocal trade liberalisations are pursued by our major trading partners.

It is well understood that we have done far more than our fair share of tariff reductions compared to our global competitors and often, regrettably, at enormous social cost. Unlike the Labor Party, the Democrats do not believe we need to wait until the year 2000 before we adopt a more strategic and tenacious approach to trade policy. We are unashamedly interventionists. This should be adopted now while we still have tariff rates which put us in a good bargaining position, and this is imperative now because the car industry directly employs 22,000 people.

Unfortunately, the Liberal, Labor and National parties are to this date fundamentally opposed to reviewing these decisions. They are open to negotiate tariffs after the year 2000. By then, however, it may already be too late. Car manufacturers, for example, are already struggling to sustain market share, both domestic and export, under current tariffs of 22½ per cent. Imports have risen strongly as tariffs have declined.

Imports accounted for only 24 per cent of vehicle sales in 1990, which was only seven years ago. Now they account for 46 per cent of sales and industry leaders expect they will reach 70 per cent by the year 2000 when tariffs will have fallen to 15 per cent. So they will have jumped from 24 per cent to 70 per cent in 10 years—a threefold increase in imports directly as a result of this policy.

Meanwhile, our Asia-Pacific trading partners, while committed to lower tariffs in theory, show little sign of actually reducing them. Indonesia recently launched a national car project enjoying large government subsidies and tax concessions. Thailand and Malaysia maintain protective barriers of more than 200 per cent, Indonesia levies a flat 100 per cent, Singapore charges 45 per cent and South Korea, which has a tariff on car imports of only eight per cent, keeps imports low through non-tariff barriers such as complex audit requirements and sales tax on imports.

The level playing field is clearly a myth. Other countries ensure their industries are not at a disadvantage from imports. It is about time Australia did the same. In Australia the path of reform has been predictable and has been disastrous for jobs, national debt and Australian ownership. It needs to be reviewed.

Year after year, the Industry Commission, now the Productivity Commission, has held public inquiries into different industries, or aspects of industry policy, followed by draft and final reports. What they have effectively been doing is charting the decline of many of our best industries. They have selectively interpreted the evidence provided and advocated reforms which have paid little heed to what our trading partners are doing. The danger is that the same fate will fall upon the car industry. Australian governments have been victims of naive, ideological, academic, theoretical and overtrusting advice. We need to inject a healthy dose of self‐interest and hard bargaining into our trade negotiations.

Our industries and jobs have been exposed, and we have received little in return. Tariff cuts have led to job losses as firms have scaled down operations, closed altogether or moved overseas. Just recently, Mitsubishi closed its truck operation. Some gains have been registered, and we recognise these, but these have typically been in other sectors of the economy and have not compensated the losers sufficiently—and the losers are the Australian jobs.

This sort of approach to trade liberalisation will lead to disaster. We should only agree to open our markets if our trading partners do likewise and match us. Failure to do so will simply result in the further decimation of Australian industries and the further erosion of thousands more jobs, or the loss of those jobs to add to those already sacrificed. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few remarks on this motion moved by Senator Cook, and I do so in the context of what is occurring in the remainder of the world. World trade patterns are well established and well understood. Indeed, if one examines the trends, there has been little variation in world trade patterns over the last 100 years.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are relatively simple. World trade is growing in both volume terms and value terms. In respect of commodities, which Australia is an expert at producing and exporting, there is growth in both volumes of commodities traded and volumes of commodities sold. However, there is significant decline in the value terms, and this decline is significant, longstanding and ongoing. There is no suggestion in the figures of any reversal to this unfortunate trend of lower and lower real prices for commodities. In respect of Australia, this means by definition that we need to sell a lot more wool, coal, grains, ore and the like simply to receive last year's dollars.

In respect of manufactures and services, the growth is in both volume and value received for these products on world markets. Importantly, there is significant growth in the value received for those manufactures and services, and this will continue to grow almost in exponential terms as more and more countries develop and their consumer societies have a more disposable income.

So a country that switches or changes its export base from commodities to manufactures and services is doing the right thing to improve its standard of living and to improve its relative position compared to other nations. To our immediate north, as most senators know, a number of countries—Singapore, Malaysia, South Korea and Taiwan—have dramatically improved their living standards over the last 30 years.

Common features of all those countries 30 years ago, or at the predevelopment stage, were poor literacy standards, often less than 50 per cent, non-existent infrastructure, low quality public health, low educational standards, economic domination by foreign interests and a low to non-existent domestic capital basis. All of those countries shifted their populations from relative poverty to relative prosperity, and they are still raising aggregate living standards.

Those huge shifts in living standards are achieved through an emphasis on a number of factors—that is, sound macro‐economic policies resulting in low interest rates, often negative; low inflation; free movement of capital; a sound currency, which is often undervalued; an emphasis on the allocation of scarce resources to education, health, infrastructure and agriculture; and, finally, and most importantly, a central coordinating role to guide firms through the development and implementation of industry policies in key areas of the economy. Those industries changed over time, but the key element of all the industry policies in most of those countries was movement up the value chain based upon an export orientation; hence they nurtured, protected and grew key industries.

The key industry that contributed to the growth of national wealth of most developing and most developed countries is, and will continue for the foreseeable future to be, the auto industry. In that context, the motion before us today is quite modest. It makes no reference to state ownership, state control or state development. It seeks really only three things: firstly, to maintain tariffs at almost the lowest level in the world; secondly, to implement transparent measures to ensure our domestic industry is compared accurately with competitors; and, thirdly, a continuation of domestic schemes that are consistent with World Trade Organisation obligations.

It seeks the maintenance of a viable, world‐class, export oriented, domestic‐based auto manufacturing industry. It seeks this because this country has no other option if it wishes to maintain current aggregate high standards of living for the entire population. It seeks this because our current trading volumes are not sufficient to generate the necessary amounts of foreign currency to fund our huge import bill. That import bill, in the two key industries of automobiles and IT, will blow out by around $30 billion per annum over the next 20 years. If we do not produce enough domestic vehicles and we continue to import at current levels, our import bill—our current account—will blow out from something in the order of $7 billion to $30 billion in the automobile industry in the next 30 years. The same scenario applies in the IT industry except the projected deficit there is much worse.

We cannot grow sufficient product or dig enough holes to fund that deficit. Iron ore, gold, silver, gas, coal, LNG and LPG are all basic commodities. Australia, as a supplier, is a price taker. The purchaser decides both the volume and the price and, if either are not adequate from this country, he has many other sources to go to.

The only way to avoid declining relative living standards is through the implementation of industry policies in a range of key industries. Those industry policies should have a number of features. They should be export orientated; value added with capacity to move up the value chain; benchmarked towards international best practice in competitive terms; and they should build up our comparative advantage of a literate, numerate mobile population. They need to be heavily reliant on technology and renewing technology.

The Australian car industry, because of the major structural changes that have been introduced over the last 15 years and that continue to be introduced in a range of plants around Australia, is noted for all of these features. There are now high value producing units, becoming more and more export orientated. All of the key firms benchmark their labour and production practices to international best practice. They regularly introduce new and modern technology.

BREAK.PARA: The motion seeks to encourage the further development of that industry. It is appropriate to say that, in a key industry which has such significance for the future, it is appropriate to seek and to argue for bipartisan—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to oppose the motion that has been moved by Senator Cook. I listened with interest to Senator Bishop's comments to see whether he was ever going to talk about the car industry, which seems to be the way that the motion was framed in general. But, in fact, Senator Bishop talked in general about industry policies. I want to talk specifically about some of the things that are noted in this motion that has been moved by Senator Cook.

SPEECH.PARA: The government is on the record as saying that it is committed to the development of strong and viable manufacturing industries. The car industry is no exception. That is why the Productivity Commission's terms of reference were framed in that way. The terms of reference requested the commission to:
Have regard to the government's desire to encourage the development of a sustainable, prosperous and internationally competitive automotive manufacturing industry in Australia.
The terms of reference also requested the commission to have regard to the economic, social, environmental and regional development objectives of the government.

I can just imagine the hue and cry from the former government if we had brought forward an urgency motion like this, just prior to the release of a report that they had commissioned and one that they had not responded to. I can just imagine Senator Cook, in his day as a minister, if we had come up with this sort of a stunt to try to debate an issue just prior to the commission releasing its report and the government commenting on it.

The government is now waiting for the final report of the Productivity Commission and we will be following standard practice—standard since June 1993—in relation to reports, where the government considers the report and also determines the timing of the release of that report. That is a practice that you started in 1993 and continued to follow, Senator Cook. I am quite sure that had we been in your position and you in ours—which you will not be for some time—you would have screamed blue murder if we had put up a motion like this.

It is also interesting to note how your position has changed on the issue of tariffs. I could not quite believe it but you probably need reminding of one or two things that some of your former ministers said—Martin Ferguson, for instance, the shadow minister for industrial relations. In 1991, the day after the then government's 1991 industry statement, which included tariff cuts, TCF unions—which many of you are familiar with—alleged that further tariff reductions or reforms would lead to job losses. But what was Martin Ferguson's response? He endorsed the tariff reduction policy saying, `It's all about investment in the long‐term future.'
Former Senator Gareth Evans, now the shadow Treasurer, made a ministerial statement on 12 March 1991. What did he say? He said:
The most powerful spur to greater competitiveness is further tariff reduction . . .

However much our competitors might bend or break the principles of fair trade, our own self‐interest is served by a steadfast refusal to return to the days of protectionism . . . Worse still, tariffs are a regressive burden—that is, the poorest Australians are hurt more than the richest.

That is the policy of the Labor Party and even more the policy of Senator Murray and the Democrats. Senator Murray is going to ensure that the poorest Australians are hurt more than the richest—the words from then Senator Gareth Evans in 1991, when his government deliberately and determinedly set about pulling down the tariff barriers.

Let us now look at Labor's record on tariff reductions, particularly in relation to the car industry. In 1984, shortly after Labor came to office, car production in Australia stood at around 370,000 units. When they left office in 1996, production was just 314,000 units. In the interim, Nissan had closed down production and Australia had largely lost the capacity to produce small cars like the Ford Laser. I think there was only one remaining small car, the Toyota Corolla, being made in Australia.

This under Labor Party policy and Labor government policy. This is the policy that they put in place and they now have the hide to say that we have a large increase in the number of imported vehicles in Australia. Let me tell you that there is one reason why they are imported. It is because the Button plan, when it was put into place, did not read the signs all that well and had underestimated the growth in the small car market. It said that if you could not produce 30,000 vehicles of any one model, then you could no longer make that model in Australia.

So the demand for small cars has meant that there is no alternative but to have imported vehicles in that range. There is no alternative directly because of the plans that were put in place by the Button car plan and endorsed by the then Labor government. I am quite sure that Senator Murray may not have endorsed that program even at that time because if he had his way we might still have tariffs at 45 per cent. But then again, if we did, Senator Murray, remember that would be hurting the poorest Australians much more than those who are well off. In 1984 import penetration was 20 per cent. As a result of your policies, it was 50 per cent in 1996. That is because of your policies. Under Labor, employment in the industry declined from around 70,000 to around 45,000. Do not blame us for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Technology.

—You cannot have the argument that reducing tariffs causes the loss of employment if you are then going to blame technology for it because either technology causes job losses or tariff reductions do; you cannot have both.
—They both may have an input.

—They may have some input but you cannot insist that just one does. It went down from 70,000 to 45,000. Your government promised the automotive industry cost savings that would be won by micro‐economic reform and which would offset the effects of declining tariffs, but they never materialised. That is why we now have the car industry crying out that they have kept their part of the bargain in reducing tariffs but you did not keep your end of the bargain, as a government, by bringing in micro‐economic reform which would make it possible for them to be competitive.

SPEECH.PARA: The Productivity Commission's draft report on the automotive industry noted that progress had been especially slow in labour market reform, government regulations and in the economic infrastructure supporting the industry, especially the waterfront, shipping and rail transport. This government has set in train a comprehensive process to review the post‐2000 arrangements for the car industry. The Productivity Commission has its terms of reference and it has produced a draft report which has been commented on at length in the interim. It has received further submissions, it is continuing with that reference and is about to release its report.

To bring on this urgency motion today, when the Productivity Commission report is about to be brought down and when the government is about to respond to that Productivity Commission, is one of the greatest stunts I have seen for a long time. You can have comment all day and you can talk all you like, but we are using exactly the same process that you as a government used whenever you commissioned a report and responded to it in your own time. Senator Cook, can I say that it is no wonder that we oppose this motion. You can see from your own record that we are only continuing in the same manner that you did when you were in government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the government's objection to Senator Cook's urgency motion. I do so, coming from the state of Victoria where we know only too well the importance of the car industry, in particular in relation to employment as we have major plants in Geelong, Altona and Broadmeadows, for example. I think it was a pretty poor attempt by the former Minister for Trade, Senator Cook, to bring on this motion in an attempt to pre‐empt next week's Productivity Commission inquiry into the automotive industry, and the government's subsequent response. Be assured, it will be a quick response. It will not be dragged out. It will be a matter of days before the government responds to the Productivity Commission inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: When listening to the former Minister for Trade, Senator Cook, you would think he was never the minister who negotiated Australia's entrance into the World Trade Organisation. All of a sudden he is born again and he has completely done a back‐flip and is using terms like `tariff freeze'. This is an unbelievable situation. Albeit that the Democrats made him pull those words out on their demand, but he still used them throughout his speech. He has now caught onto this populist term `tariff freeze' which Lindsay Tanner warned against. This is the nostalgia that Lindsay Tanner warned against and Senator Cook has dived in deep. It is a sad fate for the once minister; he did a fair to average job. I am, Senator Cook, probably the only one on this side of the benches who would give you that much credit. But, given that you did a fair to average job in your travels overseas, be it that you did not work until after nine o'clock—you always liked the long breakfast—

TALK.START.PARA: — Ha, ha.

—That is true. He put out a dictum, so we are told, that he did not want any appointments before nine o'clock when he travelled. If I have misrepresented him, I apologise and I would expect him to get up and make a personal explanation if that is the case. But after nine o'clock he really did get revved up and did a fair enough job. It is a pretty sad state of affairs that he has now been reduced to presenting the nostalgic view of trade. He was once a zealot and now he is into nostalgia. The first thing about Senator Cook's motion is that, of the six points in the urgency motion that he puts before us, there is not a genuine one amongst them.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take you through them in the short time I have. The first point is in regard to the government freezing tariffs on motor vehicles. As I have already stated, it is ironic that we are here defending the previous government's policy. We are presently working under the tariff regime that you put into place, a tariff regime which you never deviated from during your 13 years in government, from the time the Button plan was put down.

As for the second and third points, which you can combine, they are calling for a watch over our trading partners to see that they are reducing their tariff and non‐tariff barriers as agreed. That is fair enough, but it is out of date. It is no longer relevant. It does not warrant being put down in a motion, because the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has already put down this government's policy on that sort of matter. He put it down last year—around about November. I quote from an article in the Financial Review:

In a strong indication of support for continued assistance for the car and textile industries, Mr Howard said it was "legitimate" to argue that Australian companies had problems competing against highly protected Asian firms.
The article went on to quote Mr Howard:
"I believe in lower tariffs, but I think the lower tariffs in Australia should be matched by equally fair treatment from other countries."

So we agree. We are already doing it and the policy is already down. We do not need a special motion in the Senate to waste our time. It has already been an utterly frivolous and wasted day. It is not completely the opposition's fault. Senator Brown from the Greens—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you sit down then?
—No, I am going to finish. I only wish I had more time to dismantle Senator Cook's pathetic six‐point plan. Anyway, that takes care of points (b) and (c) together.

SPEECH.PARA: Points (d) and (e) relate to the continuation of the export facilitation scheme and the duty‐free allowance scheme. I point out to Senator Cook that these two schemes have survived two very tough budgets from this government. Industry should have the necessary confidence that these schemes have survived two very tough budgets.

The inconsistency in Senator Cook's thinking should be noted. It should be noted that the schemes were introduced to reinforce the process of tariff reduction. You cannot have it both ways. If you are talking about a freeze on tariffs, it is fair enough to say that these schemes must then come under review because they were put in place to facilitate a reduction in tariffs.

Equally, there are other ways and other schemes, such as a reduction in the wholesale sales tax. That has been one of the ideas floated and it may well trump your pathetic second car plan—the Cook plan. You may well be trumped after the Productivity Commission report next week, Senator Cook. What are you going to do then? The whole point is that this government supports the integrity of the two schemes mentioned in points (d) and (e).

What is really galling in this motion is point 6. That is a call for a supportive industrial research and development environment. What is so galling about this is that, under Labor's so‐called `clever country' policies, Australian business R&D expenditure slipped from a very high ranking within the OECD down to 18 out of 24. Time does not permit me to mention that the R&D syndication rorts, which you never picked up on, were right under your noses. It took this tough‐minded government to make a very simple decision to abolish that scheme, after you had had eight goes to tighten it up. (Time expired)

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Murphy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the amended motion moved by Senator Cook be agreed to. I will clarify the amendment as there was some misunderstanding with regard to the words. The first part of the amendment should read as follows:
