INTERJECT.PARA: (a) ensures that tariffs on motor vehicles, original equipment and replacement components should not fall below 15% at least until 2005
The word `to' has been taken out after `15%' and the word `until' is to be inserted before 2005.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have that in writing before me, so could you read it again? Is it a significant amendment or not?
—No, Senator Harradine, it is not.
—Can you read it for me again?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly will. The first part reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: (a) ensures that tariffs on motor vehicles, original equipment and replacement components should not fall below 15%—
at that point the word `to' is to be taken out, and then after `at least' the word `until' is to be added—
at least until 2005
(while maintaining our commitments under APEC).
It is a grammatical change. The question is that the motion, as amended by leave, be agreed to.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6.50 p.m., I call on the consideration of government documents.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This is a very important report and it would have been great if we could have had it before it was tabled, so that we could make a more intelligent response. As always with these reports, because we do not have it before us much before the tabling of it, we labour under a disadvantage. I wanted to comment on a number of things that are in the report—particularly the discussion about drought—and to underline some of the Democrats' concerns about the report and the direction the government is taking in drought funding.

One of the things happening next week is another meeting of ARMCANZ. I hope that next week ARMCANZ will reconsider the proposal to drop drought exceptional circumstances from the planned new national drought policy. This is absolutely critical. Once again, farmers wonder what on earth this government is doing, having been elected on a sort of slogan of being the friend of farmers.

BREAK.PARA: The problem with dropping drought exceptional circumstances—unless the new policy, when we get it, has something in it that has not been signalled—is that we are dropping a trigger that people can use when there is a drought to get the government to respond to their situation. The Senate will remember that the previous Labor government dropped the definition of drought under the heading of `natural disaster'—I believe that was a retrograde step—and put in place the drought exceptional circumstances program to enable farmers and state and regional governments to trigger aid when there is a drought.

The problem is that if we do not regard drought as a natural disaster but as an exceptional circumstance and then drop that, we are saying, `Well, there is no drought really. It is just something that happens. And when it happens, we can address the problem.' It do not think that is good enough; it is letting down our farmers. I hope that, in its national drought policy, the government will address this and have put in place something to replace drought exceptional circumstances. Otherwise, farmers and state and local governments, whenever a drought occurs, are going to have to come cap in hand to Canberra and beg for assistance.

Drought in Australia is not something which is exceptional. It is something which is part of the cycle of our climate, and that is why I believe the government needs to take account of this. I note that several drought stricken shires around Australia are due to lose their drought relief next month. I am concerned that, although those shires may have had some rain, they are still a long way from recovery and many have not had any crop at all yet.

Tonight, in speaking to this report, I call on the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Anderson, to extend drought exceptional circumstances funding from 10 June—the date it is due to run out—until the government's planned new integrated rural policy is implemented, because there is going to be a gap there which could be quite serious. I see the parliamentary secretary, Senator Brownhill, shaking his head. I take that as a reassurance, which I think will be a great relief to those farmers who are affected. I hope that Senator Brownhill actually puts something on the record as well; I think that would help. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to take note of the report that has been tabled, the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand: Record and Resolutions . This report not only sets out the record and resolutions of the ninth meeting of the Agriculture and Resource Management Council but it also raises issues of considerable interest to the Australian Democrats. The agrifood business is particularly important to Australia, and this document brings together a number of matters on which I have already expressed my views. I will take this opportunity to set out some of those concerns again and link them with the resolutions of this particular meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: Environmental issues are central to our future and we must recognise the need, as the Australian Democrats certainly do, for sustainable development. The government has a role in leading Australian agribusiness into the next century. How we position ourselves now will, of course, have important consequences for the future. The report card is five, 10 or at least 20 years down the track, when it will be too late to make the changes to catch up.

This can be addressed and hopefully averted by smart agricultural practices but this does require a commitment from the government to fund research and development addressing these concerns. I think that funding of research is the key to wealth generation and lifestyle in the future. It is an investment and not a cost and the returns are long term. Agribusiness has been one of the beneficiaries of Australian research and development in the past, and it has a major role to play in our future as well.

This document is particularly relevant because it recognises the link between environmental, economic and social issues and sustainable development and highlights the problems for which research and development may provide answers—problems such as water treatment and waste water management.

BREAK.PARA: The other concern addressed by this document, which I would like to comment on, is the development of uniform food safety and hygiene standards. I noticed that this particular meeting resolved to develop the concept of a national safe food system, which I find particularly encouraging. This will have a local effect or perhaps a local benefit in Australia, helping to ensure consumers that the food that they eat and the food that they buy is safe to eat. It will also have benefits for the export of Australian food, which is dependent upon Australian food being safe to eat, and the recent bans on Australia beef in Indonesia and in Korea are strong reminders of this fact, and an illustration of the consequences of food contamination on Australia export trade.

The government must not compromise consumer safety by penny pinching and we have seen a number of positions lost through rationalisation in the very agencies that deal with health and safety matters. This is affecting the ability of these agencies to cooperate with state and territory authorities for inspection, development and enforcement of standards, review of the food standards code and the development of the food hygiene standards. These are important issues and the consequences of funding cuts in these areas and at this level, I believe, are considerable.

I would also say that, at this time, a move to self‐regulation and away from all the present standards may not achieve the high safety standards that consumers expect and have every right to expect, nor will it necessarily protect our trade. These are important issues and I hope that the government will take these matters into consideration when developing its policy and legislation. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the consideration of government documents has expired. I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a half hour or so ago we had an urgency motion moved in this place on car tariffs which drew attention to issues that the speaker said would save the jobs of an important section of the Australian industry. Tonight I would like to talk about an equally important Australian industry and one that has the potential to create far more jobs in this country than perhaps any other industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The market for food in Asia is growing at some $16 billion every year. We export around five times more food than we import. Put together, these two simple facts provide Australia with an enormous opportunity and a significant challenge. Australia must—and I am optimistic that it will—capitalise on the huge market for food products in Asia, just a couple of hours away by aircraft, literally on our doorsteps. This recognition of the great opportunity for our food exports into Asia is the impetus behind the governments's `Supermarket to Asia' strategy, which is the cornerstone of our efforts to achieve a competitive Australian agrifood industry.

Let us not forget that around 200,000 Australians are employed in the largest manufacturing industry in this country, that is, the food processing industry. Retail sales and exports in this sector of the economy are valued at $64 billion. Food exports in 1995-96 were worth $15 billion—an enormous amount of money. Approximately 40 per cent of these exports went to Asia. Very clearly, we have already got our food on the tables of these very near neighbours.

Food products such as meat, dairy foods, seafood, horticulture and grains as well as value added and fully processed products will all benefit from the Supermarket to Asia strategy. I am very pleased to say that my own state of South Australia stands to gain a considerable boost from this plan. Total food and beverage exports from South Australia in 1995-96 were $978 million. Our exports in 1995-96 were $282 million and in the same year exports of dairy products were $48 million—not bad for a state of one million people. Fruit and vegetable exports from South Australia were $101 million, and processed seafood products were $103 million.

It is a striking example of South Australia serving the best to the tables of the world, a point I recall making during my first speech in this place. All of these exports contribute significantly to the South Australian economy and through that economy to all of Australia. In particular, the states' rural and regional areas are involved in primary production and, in some cases, in significant value added industries.

The opportunities provided in these industries are enormous and very clearly are growing. The government wants to see these areas continue to grow and develop even further. As a result, we have allocated $11.8 million in funding over three years towards implementing this very important strategy. The sum of $1.4 million per annum for three years has been provided to establish and run the Prime Minister's Supermarket to Asia Council and for initial funding and to commission studies in high priority areas. The sum of $2 million per year will be used for three years to fund a technical market access program to be run by AQIS. This funding includes money for placing two AQIS technical access experts in Japan and in Korea to enhance trade opportunities in those countries. This will also help Australia to vigorously promote access to these markets and to remove the impediments and barriers to exports that currently exist with those countries.

As well, the budget has provided an additional $210,000 to develop the Quality Food Australia proposal. This brings total funding for the Quality Food Australia proposal to $600,000. In 1997-98 the government is also providing another $1 million for a program to be known as `The Delicatessen'. This is designed to assist Australian food producers to better appreciate the specific requirements of our Asian customers. It will enable our producers to capture export opportunities for the high value niche market industries.

The Supermarket to Asia strategy will bring investment and jobs to rural and regional Australia and through the value added and processing industries to the cities of this country. It provides valuable opportunities and support for small and medium enterprises trying to break into these large and growing markets. Overall, the strategy will contribute to an increased variety of high value export products. These are great opportunities that we must seize and make the most of. The Supermarket to Asia program means jobs, more jobs, more exports, and increased profile for Australia's clean and green agricultural industries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak about a couple of issues in my own state that are very important from the point of view of Tasmania's economic future. I guess I do not have to repeat here that Tasmania's economy is probably the worst in Australia, our unemployment is at the highest level in the country and we do not really seem to have too much of a future to look forward to, given the actions of the current government.

SPEECH.PARA: Senators will be aware that the opposition pursued the government over one matter—that relating to the shipbuilding bounty—and finally convinced the government of the error of its ways and, as a result, effectively saved a very important industry, one of the largest private employers in Australia. I congratulate the government at the end of the day. They were able to come to grips with the importance of their decision and just how important that bounty was in maintaining at least somewhat of a level playing field for shipbuilders in this country.

The issue I really want to deal with is the question of the Bass Strait car equalisation subsidy, the fact that our economy is so dependent on tourism and the fact that we have one ship that operates. Senators will remember that, prior to the last election, the Labor government proposed to purchase an additional fast ferry for Tasmania at a cost of around $45 million. That boat would have been built in Tasmania, I would have hoped, and would have now been operating on the service across Bass Strait.

We know that Tasmania purchased a ferry, which was then known as the Peter Pan and renamed the Spirit of Tasmania. At the time we had to upgrade the existing ferry, the Abel Tasman. Because it was unable to cope and was ageing, a decision had to be taken to find a replacement for it. That decision was taken. Fast ferry technology at that time was still very much in its infancy and there was no clear indication of whether or not fast ferries had the capability of dealing with long crossings or whether the economies of scale were right for that. Nevertheless, that was proven fairly quickly. As I said, the replacement vessel was bought at great expense to the state. It has operated over that time, running at a loss, I think, with the exception of maybe one year. It is a significant burden on the taxpayers and, of course, on the state government of Tasmania. Decisions that have been taken and that will be taken in the future will be very important.

There is one slight glimmer of hope in one area of Tasmania's economy. That is in tourism, because we do need to get more people across the water. The opposition, now government, proposed prior to the last election to provide Tasmania with this car equalisation subsidy. It said, in effect, that it would give Tasmania $49½ million over three years. I can remember Senator Newman saying, `That's a lot of money that we are going to give the state.' The reality is that the state will get somewhat less than half of that. The real problem is that, even with the subsidy, the ship that we have on the service does not have the capacity to carry enough people to be of any real benefit because it has a maximum capacity. We need at least a second ship.

I know that next year there will be an estimated shortfall in supply and demand of a minimum of 10,000 people who would like to go to Tasmania, but the ferry service will not be able to carry them because it will be full. The subsidy has had some impact. It has assisted people going across to Tasmania in terms of the cost of their vehicle. We have to acknowledge that. But the reality is, is it a solution to the real problem? No, it is not.

The builder and manufacturer at Incat, Mr Bob Clifford, has proposed to the state government that a second ferry either be leased by the state government, because they simply do not have the funds to purchase it, or get in place some consortium arrangement where we would get a second ferry on the service. What has the poor old state government said? It says, `Oh, no, we can't do that.' The poor old minister for tourism always seems to be lost. Old Ray Groom—the lights are on but no-one is home. He cannot make a decision. He will not take any initiative. The state is suffering as a result of that.

I would suggest—indeed, I would urge—the government at a federal level to talk to the state government and get them involved in the process. It is terribly important to Tasmania's hospitality and retail industries that we get more people into the state. If we can get 10,000 or 20,000 more, it will be of significant importance. It would underpin a lot of employment in the hospitality, service and retail industries.

The papers and the AHA—indeed, I have here a number of newspaper clippings—have all been urging the second ferry to be brought into play. Over and above that, the state government just seems to be lost for direction. It has a problem with regards to the existing ferry in terms of the debt burden that it carries.

We do need to look at real solutions. If the federal government is committed to looking at real solutions for Tasmania and if, as it said it was prior the last election, it is committed to assisting the state, you ought to start taking some steps. I would think that at least the Tasmanian Liberal members—or Liberal member—and the Liberal senators, two of whom are ministers in this government, ought to be taking up some argument on behalf of the state they are supposed to represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were right the first time—there are two members.
—Well, Senator Macdonald—
—Order! Senator Murphy, address your remarks through the chair.
—Through you, Madam Deputy President, I can only think of one.
—Miles and Warwick Smith.

—That is right. Senator Macdonald is so right. I should not forget Warwick because he is in my duty electorate. I have got to say that, when he is there, you hardly notice. He is a minister. He ran an ad in his pre-election campaign which said, `Where's Warwick?' The question is still: where's Warwick? Where is Warwick with regard to assisting the Tasmanian economy and assisting us with our problems in getting people across the Bass Strait to our state to help boost our economy? Nowhere.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps he is in Sydney looking at the Olympic venue and seeing how that is coming along. I do not know why you do not move him up to Sydney and see whether you can arrange for preselection up there for him. He would be better suited to that, I think, if he cannot come back to his own electorate, if he cannot do the job that he said that he would do.

With regard to the promise he made to the people in Tasmania about their getting some benefit from the year 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney, he said, `I'll write to all of the people at all of the potential training venues and I will be there in Atlanta working my butt off to get some benefit for Tasmania.' I have to say to honourable senators: if they asked any training facility in Tasmania that meets the standard—and there are not many—they would find that none of them have received a letter from Warwick Smith.

That brings into question this matter of ministers having to deal with the public honestly. I have said that before. Quite frankly, the government ought to bring Mr Smith into line, but of course we will not hear anything from Warwick Smith about the Bass Strait problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Smith, thank you.

—From Mr Warwick Smith, the `Where's Warwick' member for Bass. We will not hear anything from him with regard to the economic problems confronting the state. We will not hear him put up any real, strong arguments about getting greater assistance to solve the problem of getting more people across the Bass Strait on the ferry services.
—Yes, you will. He's doing the work.
—No, he will not be doing anything, and nor will Senator Newman or any other members from Tasmania. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from their Families

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak tonight on the Bringing them home report of the national inquiry into the separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children from their families. I suppose everyone is going to say something of the impact of this report on them, but I thought tonight I would tell just some of the impact of this report on me. I opened the front cover of this report and I read:

SPEECH.PARA: This report is a tribute to the strength and struggles of many thousands of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people affected by forcible removal. We acknowledge the hardships they endured and the sacrifices they made. We remember and lament all the children who will never come home.

Another paragraph does follow, but I wanted to add another line that says: `We remember all the mothers with a great gap, an aching heart and empty arms that could never embrace their children—those children who never came home.' If ever there were a report to break the hearts of people, it is this one; if ever there were a report that lists the broken hearts of thousands of women, of thousands of families, it is this one.

I believe that this is an absolute watershed report—an extraordinary, significant, amazing 700-page report. I certainly want to congratulate and acknowledge the producers of this report, from President Ronald Wilson to all of the members of the committee, who listened to the testimony that is listed in such detail and in such generosity in the pages of this report.

This 700-page report is full of pain. The words that occur again and again are sad, sad, sad. The report to the extent that I have been able to read it seems to me to be almost entirely lacking rancour. It is lacking anger. It is just full of sadness.

BREAK.PARA: I will read from page 8 the story of confidential submission 818, Victoria, in which the person making this submission describes how much she appreciates and likes her adopted family:

I love the Sullivan family very much. Mrs Sullivan taught me how to love and what was right and what was wrong. I'm glad she taught me values because I know now what was wrong. It was wrong the way my natural mother was treated. Mrs Sullivan told my mother she should lock herself away. The Sullivan family told people my mother was crazy and the court gave us to the Sullivan family. My mother was not crazy she was only nineteen.
Perhaps we could get Eric Bogle to write a song about Aboriginal women who were `only 19'. The quote continues:

She was the right one and shouldn't have killed herself but she knew no better as there was no one to help her keep her children. I can remember the day she died—that has haunted me for the rest of my life. I remember the police coming to Mrs Sullivans's place where we were and told her that mum Faith died I'm sure I heard that. I turned and said to Mrs Sullivan `Mummy Faith can't take us away anymore.' The day she died we died.
On page 90 of this report there is a reproduction of a photo headed `Homes Are Sought For These Children'. Underneath it it says:

A group of tiny half‐caste and quadroon children at the Darwin half‐caste home. The Minister for the Interior (Mr Perkins) recently appealed to charitable organisations in Melbourne and Sydney to find homes for the children and rescue them from becoming outcasts.
Underneath it says in handwriting:
I like the little girl in centre of group, but if taken by anyone else, any of the others would do, as long as they are strong.
The quote underneath states:
We was brought like a market. We was all lined up in white dresses, and they'd come round and pick you out like you was for sale.
Confidential submission . . . New South Wales: woman fostered at 10 years in the 1970s; one of a family of 13 siblings all removed; raped by foster father and forced to have an abortion.
The next submission states:
I clearly remember being put in line‐ups every fortnight, where prospective foster parents would view all the children. I wasn't quite the child they were looking for.
Confidential evidence 133, Victoria: man removed at 6 months in the 1960s; institutionalised for 3 years before being fostered by a succession of white families.
I was interested to read the history of my state of South Australia. I do not intend to read all of it out, but there are lines that are really just quite shocking. Page 120 states:
Despite the early attempts at protectionism—
This is in South Australia—

the pattern elsewhere of violence and dispossession of indigenous people repeated itself in South Australia. Matthew Moorhouse, Protector from 1839 till 1856, himself presided over a massacre of 30 indigenous people in 1841. In 1856 the office of protector was abolished and by 1860 35 of the 42 reserves set aside for Aborigines had been leased to settlers.
I think the concept of a protector presiding over a massacre really is beyond words. On page 121:
A Royal Commission—
This is the royal commission in 1913 in South Australia—
was established `to inquire into and report upon the control, organisation and management of institutions . . . set aside for the benefit of Aborigines'.
The royal commission also heard protests against forcible removals. On page 122:

In regard to the taking of our children in hand by the State to learn trades etc., our people would gladly embrace the opportunity of betterment . . . but to be subjected to complete alienation from our children is to say the least an unequalled act of injustice, and no parent worthy of the name would either yield to or urge such a measure (Matthew Kropinyeri quoted by Mattingley and Hampton 1992 on page 119).
I suppose I have been reading quotes and picking out those that leap at me because of the pain of the mothers as well as the children. On page 127:

PARA.EMPHASIS: I grew up Oodnadatta area . . . with my grandmother and she would see the missionary coming . . . she would run away with me. She would keep running away and the police . . . would come sometimes and shoot the dogs and that and my grandmother would run in the creek and hide me away till about really dark and come back home . . . I might [have] been about 10 or 11 years . . . we seen one missionary coming . . . one of my auntie roll me up like a swag sort of thing, you know, and hid me away . . . but I must have moved and he got me out and he said to me `I'll give you a lolly and we will go for a ride, go to Oodnadatta' . . . they put me on a train and my grandmother was following the train—she was running behind the train, singing out for me . . . then I was singing out `I'll be back', I thought I was going for a holiday or something.
Confidential evidence 382, South Australia: woman removed from her grandmother's care in the 1960s. She was never informed of the grounds of her removal.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Bob Collins in this place today I think was giving the example of a niece of his who only in the last 12 months has actually found her mother, who I believe Senator Collins said is the sister of his wife. He was reminding us that this is not 19th century history, this is not even pre‐Second World War history—this is our contemporary history. These things were happening to people growing up and living alongside us for much of our lives.

For me, the 1970s is not a very long time ago. I find it absolutely shocking to read these stories and to somehow know that, while I did not know as a child, I had a faint idea, I suppose, as a doctor in South Australia in the 1960s. I was certainly becoming aware of a lot of this, and I was assisted in this matter because I have a brother who worked with Aboriginal people for many years, so perhaps I had access to closer information. But even so I had no idea that we were talking about the history of a planned campaign—and I do think that genocide is the right word—to eliminate a race from the face of the human earth, that those people were actually having this kind of pain and anguish visited upon them right alongside of us. On page 130 it quotes from Fiona's story:

I guess the government didn't mean it as something bad but our mothers weren't treated as people having feelings. Naturally a mother's got a heart for her children and for them to be taken away, no‐one can ever know the heartache. She was still grieving when I met her in 1968.

I do urge everybody who can to read this report and to just think about what sort of pain this history shows, what it says about us as a race and why I believe it is critically important that we as a nation, let alone as individuals, apologise. I so do. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I gave notice of a motion asking the Senate to note the Victorian state government's abolition of the Victorian Land Conservation Council, a body set up by the Liberal government in 1970 in Victoria. I set out some details of the work done by the LCC and its valuable role in reviewing the ecologically sound use of public land.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say tonight that this council has not by any stretch of the imagination jumped on the environment bandwagon. In fact, its most recent report and recommendations on marine parks in Victoria met with quite some opposition, both from the conservation groups in the state and the Democrats. We argued that the percentage of Victoria's coastline set apart for marine parks was far too small. There has been very little research done on Victoria's temperate waters but there is evidence of depleted fish stocks through what is understood to be overfishing, inappropriate development, and damaging practices such as scallop dredging and the importation of exotic pests in ballast water and the like.

The point I want to make here is that the LCC cannot be accused of being unduly influenced by pro‐development or even pro‐conservation groups. The Victorian state government simply says that the time has come for the LCC. Today it repealed the Land Conservation Act and so abolished the LCC. It intends to put in its place a three‐person body which will be directly controlled by the minister. This body will only take on inquiries at the direction of the minister. It will be limited in its opportunity to conduct public consultation over land use decisions and there are no clear commitments to a defined public decision making process.

Yesterday Senator Campbell challenged my notice of motion saying that it was not the business of the Senate to deal with what was a state government issue. I want to say tonight that not only is the Victorian LCC relevant to this place but it has relied and still does rely on the work of the LCC. The federal government's forest task force has used the LCC's land use recommendations in establishing its deferred forest agreements for some time, I gather.

It is no coincidence that the Victorian state government has refused to allow the LCC to release its report on the box ironbark forests and woodlands of northern Victoria before abolishing this organisation. There is nothing particularly controversial in that report. As I understand it, it is a descriptive report and it does not even come up with recommendations.

The problem is that this report will no doubt reveal that there remains in Victoria just 15 per cent of the original box ironbark forests which once covered northern Victoria. Australians have not fought to retain these very special dryland forests in quite the same way as perhaps they have for rainforests and other forests. This study of the LCC covers the vast area of northern Victoria from the Grampians across to Wodonga, including areas around Bendigo, Shepparton, Ballarat, Wangaratta and Stawell.

Unfortunately for the preservation of these magnificent dryland forests, ironbark makes extremely good firewood and extremely long‐lasting fenceposts. We have almost no areas of box ironbark which have not at some time been logged for timber or for eucalyptus oils. Ironbark trees take a very long time to grow and they grow in poor and fragile soils, which are highly prone to erosion. The Eaglehawk regional park, near Bendigo, was recommended as a national park in 1981. It still awaits placement on the register of the National Estate—as I understand it, that is a matter for the federal parliament—and it awaits the release of the LCC report.

Of course, this apparent reluctance of the Victorian state government to have this LCC report released has another objective. Not only is ironbark highly prized, but also this part of Victoria, as I outlined here yesterday, is the same area where most of Victoria was mined for gold 100 years ago. The new threat to these forests is the extraction of minute quantities of gold by the open‐cut method, in which cyanide is used to extract that gold. I spoke at length on this issue last night. I pointed out the damage being done by the huge quarries which are currently proposed all over this part of Victoria and the effects that this will have on the thousands of residents who live there.

We also understand the threat to our box ironbark and woodland forests from this very crude and environmentally destructive form of mining. Mining currently threatens 30 hec tares of the Diamond Hill historic reserve and the important and rare wild flowers there. Two new mines are proposed near Heathcote at McIvor Range and in the Argyle state forest west of Heathcote. There is a proposal to extend the mine by 190 hectares at Fosterville, east of Bendigo.

The mining industry will tell us that mining is about jobs and about local prosperity. We all know that these claims have been widely exaggerated in the past. We know that gold mining is a highly speculative industry. Mining companies regularly go into liquidation, leaving behind them a trail of environmental destruction. I heard today that a mining contractor at Costerfield has stopped work because the organisation has not been paid by the mining company. This is just one example of the litany of economic destruction that is left behind so often by mining companies.

According to the 1990-91 census, a total of 300 people were employed in the mining industry in Victoria. I do not believe we can rely on the figures that the mining industry tell us. I do not believe the benefits, where there are any, will flow on to the local community. In fact this story was told to the people of Dunnolly. As I understand it, the mining company which came in there brought its own specialised work force with it and they commuted to the area.

What is going on in Victoria should be of concern to the federal government. It should be of concern to the members of parliament in those electorates and it should be of concern to senators from Victoria. The protection of remaining box ironbark forests, the protection of residents' rights to live decent lives without the threat of mining on their doorstep, the protection of the environment so that future generations do not have to live with these enormous scars on the landscape for so little return—these are the issues and this is why the Senate should be interested in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 November last year in the adjournment debate, I spoke about litigation that was then in train between Impulse Airlines, a regional airline operator in New South Wales, and Jetstream, a subsidiary company of British Aerospace. On that occasion, I referred to this ongoing litigation, which had experienced significant delays and was causing concern to me and others as to the future operations of the regional airline, Impulse Airlines.

SPEECH.PARA: I have pleasure tonight in being able to put on the record that the parties in that litigation have reached an agreement. Whilst I, firstly, am not aware of what the terms of that agreement are and, secondly, am therefore not able to nor would wish to outline them, I still want to record publicly that the matter has been resolved apparently to the satisfaction of all parties concerned. This is important because it brings to an end, as I said, some lengthy litigation which had attracted some public comment. The judge had expressed concern as to the unnecessary length of the litigation.

It is, however, also good news because both of these companies are substantial operators in the aerospace airline industry in this country, albeit in different sectors. But both companies are also going to be major employers in the Newcastle region. Late last year, Impulse Airlines opened up a maintenance facility at the Williamtown airport in Newcastle and is expanding its operations in that regard. Equally, British Aerospace was the successful tenderer for the lead-in fighter contract with the air force and also, I understand, is likely to become a substantial employer in the Newcastle region.

Often times we criticise the operations of multinational companies. Nevertheless, I am pleased tonight to congratulate British Aerospace on their success and on the fact that they have publicly committed themselves to building a major and successful operation within the Australian defence industry and defence support industry.

Their previous acquisition of AWA and their commitment to expanding their operations as a result of winning this contract demonstrate how a multinational company can benefit this country when it bases its operations in, and makes a commitment to, Australia. I am pleased to be able to stand here tonight and congratulate both companies and wish them well in their success in the future—success which I believe is going to be important to the creation of jobs and to the promotion of investment and employment in the Newcastle region, and throughout Australia, in the aviation sector.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 March 1997 (Official Hansard page 2361) Senator Sherry asked me a question without notice concerning whether section 58 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 had to be amended for the operation of the superannuation contributions surcharge on high income earners.

QUESTION.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

Section 58 of Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (SIS) limits the extent to which a trustee can be subject to direction from third parties, including employer sponsors. This section does not need to be amended for the operation of the surcharge.
